<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=28,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=221384,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DG75605A.;51',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DG75605_1_20">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	REGULATION OF THE NATURAL GAS AND LIQUIDS PIPELINES BUSINESSES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canada
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Natural Gas Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Canadian Mainline, NGTL System and most of the
	other Canadian pipelines owned or operated by TransCanada (collectively, the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Systems
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) are regulated by the NEB under the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	National Energy Board Act
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(Canada). The NEB regulates the
	construction and operation of facilities, and the terms and conditions of services, including rates, for the Company's Canadian regulated natural gas transmission systems.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	NEB generally sets tolls that provide TransCanada the opportunity to recover costs of transporting natural gas, including the return of capital (depreciation) and return on the average investment
	base for each of the Systems. Generally, Canadian natural gas pipelines request the NEB to approve the pipeline's cost of service and tolls once a year, and recover or refund the variance between
	actual and expected revenues and costs in future years. The Canadian Mainline, however, operates under a fixed toll arrangement for its longer term firm transportation service and has the flexibility
	to price its shorter term and discretionary services in order to maximize its revenue. Further information relating to the decision from the&nbsp;NEB regarding the Canadian Restructuring Proposal as
	well as the LDC Settlement can be found in the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	General Developments of the business&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Developments in the Natural Gas Pipelines
	business&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Canadian Mainline, Tolls and Tariff Applications (LDC&nbsp;Settlement)
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	section&nbsp;above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	New
	facilities on or associated with the Systems are approved by the NEB before construction begins and the NEB regulates the operations of each of the Systems. Net earnings of the Systems may be
	affected by changes in investment base, the allowed ROE, and any incentive earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Natural Gas Pipelines Projects
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Coastal GasLink and PRGT projects are being
	proposed and developed primarily under the regulatory regime administered by the OGC and the EAO. The OGC is responsible for
	overseeing oil and gas operations in B.C., including exploration, development, pipeline transportation and reclamation. The EAO is an agency that manages the review of proposed major projects in B.C.,
	as required by the B.C.
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Environmental Assessment&nbsp;Act
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Liquids Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The NEB regulates the terms and conditions of
	service, including rates, facilities and the physical operation of the Canadian portion of the Keystone Pipeline System.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Liquids Pipelines Projects
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TC&nbsp;Terminals, Northern Courier Pipeline, and
	Grand Rapids Pipeline were approved by the AER in February, July and October&nbsp;2014 respectively. All three projects
	are currently under construction. The Heartland Pipeline application is currently under regulatory review by the AER. The AER administers approvals required to construct and operate the pipelines and
	associated facilities in accordance with
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Directive 56
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, approvals to obtain land access under the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Public Land
	Act,
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and environmental approvals under the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Environmental and Protection Enhancement Act
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Energy
	East Pipeline is being proposed and developed under the regulatory regime administered by the&nbsp;NEB.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	United&nbsp;States
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Natural Gas Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's wholly owned and partially owned
	U.S.&nbsp;pipelines are considered
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	natural gas companies
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	operating under the
	provisions of the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Natural Gas Act of 1938
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, and are subject to the
	jurisdiction of the FERC.
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	The Natural Gas Act of 1938
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	grants the FERC authority over the construction and operation of pipelines and related facilities.
	The FERC also has authority to regulate rates for natural gas transportation and interstate commerce. The ANR System's natural gas storage facilities in Michigan are also regulated by&nbsp;FERC.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Liquids Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The FERC regulates the terms and conditions of
	service, including transportation rates, of interstate liquids pipelines, including the U.S.&nbsp;portion of the Keystone
	Pipeline System and Cushing Marketlink. The siting and construction of pipeline facilities are regulated by the specific state commissions where the pipeline crosses. Pipeline safety is regulated by
	the U.S.&nbsp;Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration. Liquids pipelines that cross the international border between Canada and the United&nbsp;States,
	such as the Keystone Pipeline System and the proposed Keystone&nbsp;XL project, are required to obtain a Presidential Permit from the&nbsp;DOS.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	20&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=29,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=801016,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DG75605A.;51',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DG75605_1_21">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mexico
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Natural Gas Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's pipelines in Mexico are regulated by
	the Comisi&oacute;n Reguladora de Energ&iacute;a or Energy Regulatory Commission who approve construction of
	new pipeline facilities and ongoing operations of the infrastructure. Our Mexican pipelines have approved tariffs, services and related rates, however, the contracts underpinning the construction and
	operation of the facilities are long-term negotiated fixed rate contracts. These rates are only subject to change under specific circumstances such as certain types of force majeure events or changes
	in law.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	ENERGY&nbsp;BUSINESS
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our Energy business includes a portfolio of power generation assets in Canada and the
	U.S., and unregulated natural gas storage assets in&nbsp;Alberta.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	own, control or are developing generation capacity powered by natural gas, nuclear, coal, hydro, wind and solar assets. Our power business in Canada is mainly located in Alberta, Ontario and
	Qu&eacute;bec. Our power business in the U.S. is located in New&nbsp;York, New&nbsp;England, and Arizona. The assets are largely supported by long-term contracts and some represent low
	cost baseload generation, while others are critically located, essential capacity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	conduct wholesale and retail electricity marketing and trading throughout North America from our offices in Alberta, Ontario and Massachusetts to actively manage our commodity exposure and provide
	higher&nbsp;returns.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	own or control unregulated natural gas storage capacity in Alberta and regulated natural gas storage in Michigan (part of the Natural Gas Pipelines segment).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	are the operator of all of our Energy assets, except for the Sheerness, Sundance A and Sundance B PPAs, Cartier Wind, Bruce A and B and Portlands Energy.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=31,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=541678,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DG75605A.;51',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DG75605_1_23">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own or have the rights to power supply in Alberta and Arizona through three long-term PPAs, five natural gas-fired cogeneration facilities, and through
	Coolidge, a simple-cycle, natural gas peaking facility in&nbsp;Arizona.
</FONT>
</P>

</DT>

	Power
	generation has been suspended since 2008. We continue to receive capacity payments while generation is suspended.
</FONT>

<FONT SIZE=4>
	General
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_21"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	EMPLOYEES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At Year End, TransCanada's principal operating subsidiary, TCPL, had 6,059 full time
	active employees, substantially all of whom were employed in Canada and the U.S., as set
	forth in the following table.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	HEALTH, SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND SOCIAL POLICIES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Health, Safety and Environment committee of TransCanada's Board of Directors (the&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Board
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) oversees operational risk,
	people and process safety, security of personnel and environmental risks, and monitors compliance with our health, safety and environment (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	HSE
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	)
	corporate policy through regular reporting from management. We have an integrated HSE management system that establishes a framework for managing HSE issues that is used to capture, organize and
	document our related policies, programs and procedures.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	management system for HSE is modeled after international standards, conforms to external industry consensus standards and voluntary programs, and complies with applicable legislative requirements
	and various other internal management systems. It follows a continuous improvement cycle organized into four key&nbsp;areas:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Planning:
	risk and regulatory assessment, objectives and targets, and structure and responsibility
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Implementing:
	development and implementation of programs, plans, procedures and practices aimed at operational risk&nbsp;management
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Reporting:
	document and records management, communication and reporting, and
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Action:
	ongoing audit and review of HSE performance.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	committee reviews HSE performance and operational risk management on a quarterly basis. It receives detailed reports on:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	overall
	HSE corporate governance
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	operational
	performance and preventive maintenance metrics
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	asset
	integrity programs
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	emergency
	preparedness, incident response and evaluation
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	people
	and process safety performance metrics, and
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	developments
	in and compliance with applicable legislation and regulations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	committee also receives updates on any specific areas of operational and construction risk management review being conducted by&nbsp;management and the results and corrective action plans
	emanating from internal and third party audits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Environmental policies
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's facilities are subject to federal, state, provincial, and local
	environmental statutes and regulations governing environmental protection, including, but not
	limited to, air emissions and GHG emissions, water quality, wastewater discharges and waste management. Such laws and regulations generally require facilities to obtain or comply with a wide variety
	of environmental registrations, licences, permits and other approvals and requirements. Failure to comply with these laws and regulations may result in the assessment of administrative, civil or
	criminal penalties, the imposition of remedial requirements and/or the issuance of orders respecting future operations. We have implemented inspection and audit programs designed to keep all of our
	facilities in compliance with environmental requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	24&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=33,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=518539,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DI75605A.;36',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_25">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Safety and asset integrity
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As one of TransCanada's priorities, safety is an integral part of the way our employees
	work. Since 2008, we have sustained year over year improvement in our safety
	performance. Overall, TransCanada's incident frequency rates in 2014 continued to meet or exceed most industry benchmarks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	safety and integrity of our existing and newly developed infrastructure is a top priority. All new assets are designed, constructed and commissioned with full consideration given to safety and
	integrity, and are brought in service only after all necessary requirements have been&nbsp;satisfied.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	annually conducts emergency response exercises to practice effective coordination between the Company, local emergency responders, regulatory agencies and government officials in the event
	of an emergency. TransCanada uses the Incident Command System which supports a unified approach to emergency response with these community members. TransCanada also provides annual training to all
	field staff in the form of table top exercises, online and vendor lead&nbsp;training.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Social Policies
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada has a number of policies, guiding principles and practices in place to help
	manage Aboriginal and other stakeholder relations. We have adopted a Code of business
	ethics (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Code
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) which applies to all employees, officers and directors as well as contract workers of TransCanada and its wholly-owned subsidiaries and
	operated entities in countries where we conduct business. All employees (including executive officers) and directors must certify their compliance with the Code every year. The Code is based on the
	Company's four core values of integrity, collaboration, responsibility and innovation, which guide the interaction between and among the Company's employees and contractors, and serve as a standard
	for us in our dealings with all stakeholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	approach to stakeholder engagement is based on building relationships, mutual respect and trust while recognizing the unique values, needs and interests of each community. Our stakeholder
	relations framework provides the structure to guide our teams' behavior and actions, so they understand their responsibility and extend respect, courtesy and the opportunity to respond to every
	stakeholder.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	strive for continuous improvement in how we navigate the interconnections and complexity of environmental, social and economic issues related to our business. These issues are of great importance
	to our stakeholders, and have an impact on our ability to build and operate energy infrastructure.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Risk factors
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A discussion of our risk factors can be found in the MD&amp;A in the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Natural Gas Pipelines&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Business
	Risks, Liquids Pipelines&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Business Risks, Energy&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Business Risks
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Other
	information&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Risks and risk management
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	sections, which sections of the MD&amp;A are incorporated by reference into this&nbsp;AIF.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Dividends
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our Board has not adopted a formal dividend policy. The Board reviews the financial performance of TransCanada quarterly and makes a determination of the
	appropriate level of dividends to be declared in the following quarter. Currently, our payment of dividends is primarily funded from dividends it receives as the sole common shareholder of TCPL.
	Provisions of various trust indentures and credit arrangements to which TCPL is a party restrict TCPL's ability to declare and pay dividends to TransCanada under certain circumstances
	and, if such restrictions apply, they may, in turn, have an impact on our ability to declare and pay dividends. In the opinion of TransCanada's management, such provisions do not currently restrict or
	alter TransCanada's ability to declare or pay&nbsp;dividends.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;25
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_26">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Dividends
	on our preferred shares are payable quarterly, as and when declared by the Board. The dividends declared on our common and preferred shares during the past three completed financial years
	are set out in the following table:
</FONT>
</P>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Issued
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. TransCanada announced on December&nbsp;31, 2014 that 12,501,577 of its 22,000,000&nbsp;Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares were tendered for
	conversion effective December&nbsp;31, 2014 on a one-for-one basis into Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares. As a result of the conversion, TransCanada had 9,498,423&nbsp;Series&nbsp;1 preferred
	shares and 12,501,577&nbsp;Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares issued and outstanding as at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares will pay on a quarterly basis, for the
	five-year period beginning on December&nbsp;31, 2014, as and when declared by the Board, a fixed dividend based on an annual rate of 3.266&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent. The Series&nbsp;2 preferred
	shares will pay a floating quarterly dividend for the five-year period beginning on December&nbsp;31, 2014, as and when declared by the Board. The floating quarterly dividend rate for the
	Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares for the first quarterly floating rate period (being the period from December&nbsp;31, 2014 to but excluding March&nbsp;31, 2015) is an annual rate of
	2.815&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent which will be reset every quarter.
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">

	March&nbsp;4, 2013.
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>

	(3)
</FONT>

	January&nbsp;20, 2014.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We increased the quarterly dividend on our outstanding common shares by eight per&nbsp;cent to $0.52 per share for the quarter ending March&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>

	Description of capital structure

<BR>

	TransCanada's authorized share capital consists of an unlimited number of common shares,
	of which 708,662,996&nbsp;were issued and outstanding at Year End, and an unlimited
	number of first preferred shares and second preferred shares, issuable in series, of which the following were issued and outstanding as at Year End, or as otherwise indicated below.
</FONT>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>

	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Issued
	upon conversion of Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares on December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</DD>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>

	Issued
	January&nbsp;20, 2014.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following is a description of the material characteristics of each of these classes of&nbsp;shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Common shares
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The common shares entitle the holders thereof to one vote per share at all meetings of
	shareholders, except meetings at which only holders of another specified class of shares
	are entitled to vote, and, subject to the rights, privileges, restrictions and conditions attaching to the first preferred shares and the second preferred shares, whether as a class or a series, and
	to any other class or series of shares of TransCanada which rank prior to the common shares, entitle the holders thereof to receive (i)&nbsp;dividends if, as and when declared by the Board out of
	the assets of TransCanada properly applicable to the payment of the dividends in such amount and payable at such times and at such place or places as the Board may from time to time determine, and
	(ii)&nbsp;the remaining property of TransCanada upon a&nbsp;dissolution.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have a shareholder rights plan that is designed to ensure, to the extent possible, that all shareholders of TransCanada are treated fairly in connection with any take-over bid for the Company. The
	plan creates a right attaching to each common share outstanding and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	26&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=35,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=237130,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DI75605A.;36',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_27">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	to
	each common share subsequently issued. Each right becomes exercisable ten trading days after a person has acquired (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	an acquiring person
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	), or
	commences a take-over bid to acquire, 20&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent or more of the common shares, other than by an acquisition pursuant to a take-over bid permitted under the terms of the plan
	(
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	a permitted bid
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	). Prior to a flip-in event (as&nbsp;described below), each right permits registered holders to purchase from the Company common
	shares of TransCanada at an exercise price equal to three times the market price of such shares, subject to adjustments and anti-dilution provisions (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	the exercise
	price
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	). The beneficial acquisition by any person of 20&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent or more of the common shares, other than by way of permitted bid, is referred to as a
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	flip-in event
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	. Ten
	trading days after a flip-in event, each right will permit registered holders other than an acquiring person to receive, upon payment
	of the exercise price, the number of common shares with an aggregate market price equal to twice the exercise&nbsp;price.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	has a dividend reinvestment and share purchase plan (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	DRP
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) which permits eligible holders of TransCanada common or preferred shares and
	preferred shares of TCPL to elect to reinvest their dividends and make optional cash payments to buy TransCanada common shares acquired on the open market at 100&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the weighted
	average purchase price. Participants may also make additional cash payments of up to $10,000 per quarter to purchase additional common shares, which optional purchases are not eligible for any
	discount on the price of common shares. Participants are not responsible for payment of brokerage commissions or other transaction expenses for purchases made pursuant to the&nbsp;DRP.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	also has stock based compensation plans that allow some employees to purchase common shares of TransCanada. Option exercise prices are equal to the closing price on the Toronto Stock
	Exchange (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	TSX
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) on the last trading day immediately preceding the grant date. Options granted under the plans are generally fully exercisable after three
	years and expire seven years after the date of&nbsp;grant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	First preferred shares
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Subject to certain limitations, the Board may, from time to time, issue first preferred
	shares in one or more series and determine for any such series, its designation, number
	of shares and respective rights, privileges, restrictions and conditions. The first preferred shares as a class have, among others, the provisions described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	first preferred shares of each series rank on a parity with the first preferred shares of every other series, and are entitled to preference over the common shares, the second preferred shares and
	any other shares ranking junior to the first preferred shares with respect to the payment of dividends, the repayment of capital and the distribution of assets of TransCanada in the event of its
	liquidation, dissolution or winding&nbsp;up.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Except
	as provided by the CBCA, the holders of the first preferred shares will not have any voting rights nor will they be entitled to receive notice of or to attend shareholders' meetings. The
	holders of any particular series of first preferred shares will, if the directors so determine prior to the issuance of such series, be entitled to such voting rights as may be determined by the
	directors if TransCanada fails to pay dividends on that series of preferred shares for any period as may be so determined by the directors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	provisions attaching to the first preferred shares as a class may be modified, amended or varied only with the approval of the holders of the first preferred shares as a class. Any such approval
	to be given by the holders of the first preferred shares may be given
	by the affirmative vote of the holders of not less than sixty-six and two thirds per&nbsp;cent of the first preferred shares represented and voted at a meeting or adjourned meeting of such holders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	holders of Series&nbsp;1, 3, 5, 7 and&nbsp;9 preferred shares will be entitled to receive quarterly five-year fixed rate cumulative preferential cash dividends, as and when declared by the
	Board, at an annualized rate equal to the sum of the then five-year Government of Canada bond yield, calculated at the start of the applicable five-year period, and a spread as set forth in the table
	below and have the right to convert their shares into cumulative redeemable Series&nbsp;2, 4, 6, 8, and 10&nbsp;preferred shares, respectively, subject to certain conditions, on such conversion
	dates as set forth in the table below. The Series&nbsp;1, 3, 5, 7 and&nbsp;9 preferred shares are redeemable by TransCanada in whole or in part on such redemption dates as set forth in the table
	below, by the payment of an amount in cash for each share to be redeemed equal to $25.00 plus all accrued and unpaid dividends thereon.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	holders of Series&nbsp;2, 4, 6, 8 and&nbsp;10 preferred shares will be entitled to receive quarterly floating rate cumulative preferential cash dividends, as and when declared by the Board, at
	an annualized rate equal to the sum of the then 90-day Government of Canada treasury bill rate, recalculated quarterly, and a spread as set forth in the table below and have the right to convert their
	shares into Series&nbsp;1, 3, 5, 7 and&nbsp;9 preferred shares, respectively, subject to certain conditions, on such conversion dates as set forth in the table below. The Series&nbsp;2, 4, 6, 8
	and&nbsp;10 preferred shares are redeemable by TransCanada in whole or in part after their respective initial redemption date as set forth in the table below, by the payment of an amount in cash for
	each share to be redeemed equal to (i)&nbsp;$25.00 in the case of redemptions on such redemption dates as set out in the table below, or (ii)&nbsp;$25.50 in the case of redemptions on any other
	date, in each case plus all accrued and unpaid dividends thereon.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_24"></A>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;27
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=36,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=194417,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DI75605A.;36',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_28">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	the event of liquidation, dissolution or winding up of TransCanada, the holders of Series&nbsp;1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and&nbsp;10 preferred shares shall be entitled to receive $25.00 per
	preferred share plus all accrued and unpaid dividends thereon in preference over the common shares or any other shares ranking junior to the first preferred shares.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Except as provided by the CBCA, the respective holders of the first preferred shares of each outstanding series are not entitled to receive notice of, attend
	at, or vote at any meeting of shareholders unless and until TransCanada shall have failed to pay eight quarterly dividends on such series of preferred shares, whether or not consecutive, in which case
	the holders of the first preferred shares of such series shall have the right to receive notice of and to attend each meeting of shareholders at which directors are to be elected and which take place
	more than 60&nbsp;days after the date on which the failure first occurs, and to one vote with respect to resolutions to elect directors for each of the first preferred share of such series, until
	all arrears of dividends have been paid. Subject to the CBCA, the series provisions attaching to the first preferred shares may be amended with the written approval of all the holders of such series
	of shares outstanding or by at least two thirds of the votes cast at a meeting of the holders of such shares duly called for the purpose and at which a quorum is&nbsp;present.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Second preferred shares
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The rights, privileges, restrictions and conditions attaching to the second preferred
	shares are substantially identical to those attaching to the first preferred shares,
	except that the second preferred shares are junior to the first preferred shares with respect to the payment of dividends, repayment of capital and the distribution of assets of TransCanada in the
	event of a liquidation, dissolution or winding up of&nbsp;TransCanada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Credit ratings
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Although TransCanada Corporation has not issued debt to the public, it has been assigned credit ratings by Moody's Investors Service,&nbsp;Inc.
	(
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Moody's
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) and Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	S&amp;P
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) and its outstanding preferred shares have also been
	assigned credit ratings by Moody's, S&amp;P and DBRS Limited (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	DBRS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	). Moody's has assigned an issuer rating of Baa1&nbsp;with a stable outlook and S&amp;P has
	assigned a long-term corporate credit rating of A- with a stable outlook. TransCanada Corporation does not presently intend to issue debt securities to the public in its own name and any
	future debt financing requirements are expected to continue to be funded primarily through its subsidiary, TCPL. The following table sets out the current credit ratings assigned to those outstanding
	classes of securities of the Company and TCPL which have been rated by DBRS, Moody's and&nbsp;S&amp;P:
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	28&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014

<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=37,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1004455,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DI75605A.;36',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_29">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Credit ratings are intended to provide investors with an independent measure of credit quality of an issue of securities. Credit ratings are not recommendations
	to purchase, hold or sell securities and do not address the market price or suitability of a specific security for a particular investor. There is no assurance that any rating will remain in effect
	for any given period of time or that any rating will not be revised or withdrawn entirely by a rating agency in the future if, in its judgment, circumstances so&nbsp;warrant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Each
	of the Company and TCPL paid fees to each of DBRS, Moody's and S&amp;P for the credit ratings rendered their outstanding classes of securities noted above. Other than annual monitoring fees for the
	Company and TCPL and their rated securities, no additional payments were made to DBRS, Moody's and S&amp;P in respect of any other services provided to us during the past two&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	information concerning our credit ratings relates to our financing costs, liquidity and operations. The availability of our funding options may be affected by certain factors, including the global
	capital market environment and outlook as well as our financial performance. Our access to capital markets at competitive rates is dependent on our credit rating and rating outlook, as determined by
	credit rating agencies such as DBRS, Moody's and S&amp;P, and if our ratings were downgraded TransCanada's financing costs and future debt issuances could be unfavorably impacted. A description of the
	rating agencies' credit ratings listed in the table above is set out&nbsp;below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	DBRS
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	DBRS has different rating scales for short- and long-term debt and preferred shares.
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	High
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	or
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	low
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	grades are used to indicate the relative standing within all rating categories other than AAA and D and other than in respect of DBRS' ratings
	of
	commercial paper and short-term debt, which utilize
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	high, middle
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	low
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	subcategories for its R-1 and
	R-2&nbsp;rating categories. In respect of long-term debt and preferred share ratings, the absence of either a
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	high
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	or
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	low
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	designation indicates the rating
	is in the middle of the category. The R-1 (low) rating assigned to TCPL's short-term debt is in the
	third highest of 10 rating categories and indicates good credit quality. The capacity for payment of short-term financial obligations as they fall due is substantial. The overall strength is not as
	favourable as higher rating categories. Short-term debt rated R-1 (low) may be vulnerable to future events, but qualifying negative factors are considered manageable. The A&nbsp;(low) rating
	assigned to TCPL's senior unsecured debt is in the third highest of ten categories for long-term debt. Long-term debt rated&nbsp;A&nbsp;is&nbsp;good credit quality. The capacity
	for the payment of interest and principal is substantial, but of lesser credit quality than that of AA rated securities. Long-term debt rated A may be vulnerable to future events but qualifying
	negative factors are considered manageable. The BBB rating assigned to junior subordinated notes is in the fourth highest of the ten categories for long-term debt. Long- term debt rated BBB is of
	adequate credit quality. The capacity for the payment of interest and principal is considered acceptable, but long-term debt rated BBB may be vulnerable to future events. The Pfd-2 (low) rating
	assigned to TCPL's and TransCanada's preferred shares is in the second highest of six rating categories for preferred shares. Preferred shares rated Pfd-2&nbsp;are of satisfactory
	credit quality. Protection of dividends and principal is still substantial; however, earnings, the balance sheet and coverage ratios are not as strong as Pfd-1&nbsp;rated companies. In general,
	Pfd-2&nbsp;ratings correspond with companies whose long-term debt is rated in the A&nbsp;category.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	MOODY'S
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Moody's has different rating scales for short- and long-term obligations. Numerical
	modifiers 1, 2 and 3&nbsp;are appended to each rating classification from Aa through Caa.
	The modifier 1&nbsp;indicates that the obligation ranks in the higher end of its generic rating category; the modifier 2&nbsp;indicates a mid-range ranking; and a modifier 3&nbsp;indicates a
	ranking in the lower end of that generic rating category. The A3&nbsp;rating assigned to TCPL's senior unsecured debt is in the third highest of nine rating categories for long-term
	obligations. Obligations rated A are judged to be upper medium-grade and are subject to low credit risk. The Baa1 and Baa2&nbsp;ratings assigned to TCPL's junior subordinated debt and
	preferred shares, respectively, are in the fourth highest of nine rating categories for long-term obligations, with the junior subordinated debt ranking higher within the Baa rating category with a
	modifier of 1&nbsp;as opposed to the modifier of 2&nbsp;on the preferred shares. Obligations rated Baa are judged to be medium-grade and are subject to moderate credit risk and, as such, may
	possess certain speculative characteristics.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	S&amp;P
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	S&amp;P has different rating scales for short- and long-term obligations. Ratings
	from AA through CCC may be modified by the addition of a plus (+) or minus (-) sign to
	show the relative standing within a particular rating category. The A- rating assigned to TCPL's senior unsecured debt is in the third highest of ten rating categories for
	long-term obligations. An A rating indicates the obligor's capacity to meet its financial commitment is strong; however, the obligation is somewhat more susceptible to the adverse effects of changes
	in circumstances and economic conditions than obligations in higher rated categories. As guarantor of a U.S.&nbsp;subsidiary's commercial paper program, TCPL has been assigned a commercial paper
	rating of A-2&nbsp;which is the second highest of eight rating categories for short-term debt issuers. Short-term debt issuers rated A-2&nbsp;have satisfactory capacity to meet their financial
	commitments, however they are somewhat more susceptible to adverse effects of changes in circumstances and economic conditions than obligors in the highest rating category. The BBB rating assigned to
	TCPL's junior subordinated notes is in the fourth highest of ten rating categories for long-term debt obligations and the P-2&nbsp;rating assigned to TransCanada's preferred shares is
	the second highest of eight rating categories for Canadian preferred shares. The BBB and P-2&nbsp;ratings assigned to TCPL's junior subordinated notes and TransCanada's preferred
	shares exhibit adequate protection parameters. However, adverse economic conditions or changing circumstances are more likely to lead to a weakened capacity of the obligor to meet its financial
	commitment on the&nbsp;obligation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;29
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75605_1_30">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Market for securities
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's common shares are listed on the TSX and the New&nbsp;York Stock Exchange (
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	NYSE
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	) under the symbol
	TRP. Our Series&nbsp;1, 2, 3, 5, 7 and&nbsp;9 preferred shares have been listed for trading on the TSX since September&nbsp;30, 2009, December&nbsp;31, 2014, March&nbsp;11, 2010,
	June&nbsp;29, 2010, March&nbsp;4, 2013 and January&nbsp;20, 2014 under the symbols TRP.PR.A, TRP.PR.F, TRP.PR.B, TRP.PR.C, TRP.PR.D, and TRP.PR.E, respectively. The following tables set out the
	reported monthly high, low, and month end closing trading prices and monthly trading volumes of the common shares of TransCanada on the TSX and the NYSE, and the respective Series&nbsp;1, 2, 3, 5, 7
	and&nbsp;9 preferred shares on the TSX, for the period indicated:
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=40,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=777381,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DI75605A.;36',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DK75605_1_32">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Directors and officers
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As of February&nbsp;12, 2015, the directors and officers of TransCanada as a group beneficially owned, or exercised control or direction over, directly or
	indirectly, an aggregate of 441,744 common shares of TransCanada. This constitutes less than one per&nbsp;cent of TransCanada's common shares. The Company collects this information from our
	directors and officers but otherwise we have no direct knowledge of individual holdings of TransCanada's securities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	DIRECTORS
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following table sets forth the names of the directors who serve on the Board, as of
	February&nbsp;12, 2015 (unless otherwise indicated), together with their jurisdictions
	of residence, all positions and offices held by them with TransCanada, their principal occupations or employment during the past five years and the year from which each director has continually served
	as a director of TransCanada and, prior to the Arrangement, with TCPL. Positions and offices held with TransCanada are also held by such person at TCPL. Each director holds office until the next
	annual meeting or until his or her successor is earlier elected or&nbsp;appointed.
</FONT>
</P>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->

	and Entertainment&nbsp;Ltd. (sports, property management) since August&nbsp;2012. Director, CH Group Limited Partnership from August&nbsp;2009 to August&nbsp;2012.

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Canwest
	Global Communications Corp. (
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<B>
	Canwest
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	) voluntarily entered into the
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<I>
	Companies' Creditors Arrangement
	Act
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<B>
	CCAA
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	) and obtained an order from the Ontario Superior Court of Justice (Commercial Division) to start proceedings on
	October&nbsp;6, 2009. Although no cease trade orders were issued, Canwest shares were de-listed by the TSX after the filing and started trading on the TSX Venture Exchange. Canwest emerged from CCAA
	protection and Postmedia Network acquired its newspaper business on July&nbsp;13, 2010 while Shaw Communications&nbsp;Inc. acquired its broadcast media business on October&nbsp;27, 2010.
	Mr.&nbsp;Burney ceased to be a director of Canwest on October&nbsp;27,&nbsp;2010.
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	As
	President and CEO of TransCanada, Mr.&nbsp;Girling is not a member of any Board Committees, but is invited to attend committee meetings as required.
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(3)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Ms.&nbsp;Salomone
	was a director of Crucible Materials Corp. (
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<B>
	Crucible
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	) from May&nbsp;2008 to May&nbsp;1, 2009. On May&nbsp;6,
	2009, Crucible and one of its affiliates filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the United&nbsp;States Bankruptcy Code in the U.S.&nbsp;Bankruptcy Court for the District
	of Delaware (the&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<B>
	Bankruptcy Court
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	). On August&nbsp;26, 2010, the Bankruptcy Court entered an order confirming Crucible's Second Amended
	Chapter&nbsp;11 Plan of&nbsp;Liquidation.
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	(4)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja
	joined the Board effective May&nbsp;2, 2014.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_30"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	BOARD COMMITTEES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada has four committees of the Board: the Audit committee, the Governance committee, the Health,
	Safety and Environment committee and the Human Resources committee. The
	voting members of each of these committees, as of February&nbsp;12, 2015, are identified below. Ms.&nbsp;Reynolds was appointed as the Chair of the Human Resources committee effective
	May&nbsp;2,&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<A NAME="FIS_NAME_AND_TITLE_3"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	OFFICERS
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All of the executive officers and corporate officers of TransCanada reside in Calgary,
	Alberta, Canada. Positions and offices held with TransCanada are also held by such person
	at TCPL. As of the date hereof, the officers of TransCanada, their present positions within TransCanada and their principal occupations during the five preceding years are as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>

<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="48%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Vice-President, Risk Management since October&nbsp;2001.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="19%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	G. Glenn Menuz
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="28%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Vice-President and Controller
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="48%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Vice-President and Controller since June&nbsp;2006.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	CONFLICTS OF INTEREST
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Directors and officers of TransCanada and its subsidiaries are required to disclose any existing or
	potential conflicts in accordance with TransCanada policies governing
	directors and officers and in accordance with the CBCA. Our Code covers potential conflicts of&nbsp;interest.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Serving on other boards
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Board believes that it is important for it to be composed of qualified and
	knowledgeable directors. As a result, due to the specialized nature of the energy infrastructure
	business, some of our directors are associated with or sit on the boards of companies that ship natural gas or liquids through our pipeline systems. Transmission services on most of TransCanada's
	pipeline systems in Canada and the U.S.&nbsp;are subject to regulation and accordingly we generally cannot deny transportation services to a creditworthy shipper. The Governance committee monitors
	relationships among directors to ensure that business associations do not affect the Board's performance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	34&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=43,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=486767,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DK75605A.;29',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DK75605_1_35">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Board considers whether directors serving on the boards of all entities including public and private companies, Crown corporations and other state-owned entities, and non-profit organizations pose
	any potential conflict. The Board reviews these relationships annually to determine that they do not interfere with any of our director's ability to act in our best interests. If a director declares a
	material interest in any material contract or material transaction being considered at the meeting, the director is not present during the discussion and does not vote on the&nbsp;matter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	Code requires employees to receive consent before accepting a directorship with an entity that is not an affiliate. The chief executive officer and executive vice-presidents must receive the
	consent of the Governance committee. All other employees must receive the consent of their immediate supervisor.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Affiliates
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Board closely oversees relationships between TransCanada and any affiliates to
	avoid any potential conflicts of interest. This includes our relationship with the TCLP, a
	master limited partnership listed on the&nbsp;NYSE.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Corporate governance
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our Board and management are committed to the highest standards of ethical conduct and corporate governance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	is a public company listed on the TSX and the NYSE, and we recognize and respect rules and regulations in both Canada and the&nbsp;U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	corporate governance practices comply with the Canadian governance guidelines, which include the governance rules of the TSX and Canadian Securities Administrators:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	National
	Instrument&nbsp;52-110,
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Audit Committees
</I>
</FONT>
<BR>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	National
	Policy&nbsp;58-201,
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Corporate Governance Guidelines
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, and
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	National
	Instrument&nbsp;58-101,
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Disclosure of Corporate Governance Practices
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	also comply with the governance listing standards of the NYSE and the governance rules of the SEC that, in each case, apply to foreign private issuers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	governance practices comply with the NYSE standards for U.S.&nbsp;companies in all significant respects, except as summarized on our website (www.transcanada.com). As a non-U.S.&nbsp;company,
	we are not required to comply with most of the governance listing
	standards of the NYSE. As a foreign private issuer, however, we must disclose how our governance practices differ from those followed by U.S.&nbsp;companies that are subject to the
	NYSE&nbsp;standards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	benchmark our policies and procedures against major North American companies to assess our standards and we adopt best practices as appropriate. Some of our best practices are derived from the NYSE
	rules and comply with applicable rules adopted by the SEC to meet the requirements of the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer
	Protection&nbsp;Act.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Audit committee
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Audit committee is responsible for assisting the Board in overseeing the integrity of our financial statements and our compliance with legal and regulatory
	requirements. It is also responsible for overseeing and monitoring the internal accounting and reporting process and the process, performance and independence of our internal and external auditors.
	The charter of the Audit committee can be found in
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Schedule&nbsp;B
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	of this&nbsp;AIF.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	RELEVANT EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE OF MEMBERS
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The members of the Audit committee as of February&nbsp;12, 2015 are Kevin E. Benson
	(Chair), Derek H. Burney, Mary Pat Salomone, D.&nbsp;Michael G.&nbsp;Stewart, and Siim
	A. Vanaselja. Richard E. Waugh attended the Audit committee meetings as an observer until he retired as Deputy Chairman of Scotiabank on January&nbsp;31, 2014 and was a voting member of the
	committee from February&nbsp;1 until May&nbsp;2, 2014. Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja was appointed as a member of the Audit committee effective May&nbsp;2,&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Board believes that the composition of the Audit committee reflects a high level of financial literacy and expertise. Each member of the Audit committee has been determined by the Board to be
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	independent
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	financially literate
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	within the meaning of the definitions under Canadian and
	U.S.&nbsp;securities laws and the NYSE rules. In addition, the Board has determined that Mr.&nbsp;Benson and Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja are
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Audit Committee Financial
	Experts
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	as that term is defined under U.S.&nbsp;securities laws. The Board has made these determinations based on the education and breadth and depth of experience of each
	member of the Audit committee. The following
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;35
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=44,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=984834,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK128:[14ZDF5.14ZDF75605]DK75605A.;29',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='13-FEB-2015;10:32' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DK75605_1_36">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	is
	a description of the education and experience, apart from their respective roles as directors of TransCanada, of each member of the Audit committee that is relevant to the performance of his
	responsibilities as a member of the Audit committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Kevin E. Benson
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mr.&nbsp;Benson is a Chartered Accountant (South Africa) and was a member of the South
	African Society of Chartered Accountants. He serves as a director of the Winter Sport
	Institute, and was the President and Chief Executive Officer of Laidlaw International,&nbsp;Inc. until October&nbsp;2007. In prior years, he has held several executive positions including one as
	President and Chief Executive Officer of The Insurance Corporation of British Columbia and has served on other public company boards and on the audit committees of certain of those&nbsp;boards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Derek H. Burney
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mr.&nbsp;Burney earned a Bachelor of Arts (Honours) and Master of Arts from Queen's
	University. He is currently a senior advisor at Norton Rose Fulbright. He previously
	served as President and Chief Executive Officer of CAE&nbsp;Inc. and as Chair and Chief Executive Officer of Bell Canada International&nbsp;Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Burney was the lead director at Shell
	Canada Limited until May&nbsp;2007 and was the Chair of Canwest Global Communications Corp. until October&nbsp;2010. He has served on one other organization's audit committee and has participated
	in Financial Reporting Standards Training offered by&nbsp;KPMG.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mary Pat Salomone
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Ms.&nbsp;Salomone has a Bachelor of Engineering in Civil Engineering from Youngstown
	State University and a Master of Business Administration from Baldwin Wallace College.
	She completed the Advanced Management Program at Duke University's Fuqua School of Buiness in 2011. Ms.&nbsp;Salomone was the Senior Vice-President and Chief Operating Officer of B&amp;W until
	June&nbsp;2013. She previously held a number of senior roles with B&amp;W Nuclear, including serving as the Manager of Business Development from 2009 to 2010 and Manager of Strategic Acquisitions from
	2008 to 2009, and served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Marine Mechanical Corporation 2001 through 2007, which B&amp;W acquired in&nbsp;2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	D. Michael G. Stewart
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mr.&nbsp;Stewart earned a Bachelor of Science in Geological Sciences with First Class
	Honours from Queen's University. He has served and continues to serve on the boards of
	several public companies and other organizations and on the audit committee of certain of those boards. Mr.&nbsp;Stewart held a number of senior executive positions with Westcoast Energy&nbsp;Inc.
	including Executive Vice-President, Business Development. He has also been active in the Canadian energy industry for over 40&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Siim A. Vanaselja
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja is a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Ontario and
	holds an Honours Bachelor of Business degree from the Schulich School of Business.
	Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja has been the Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer of BCE&nbsp;Inc. and Bell Canada since January&nbsp;2001, having previously served as Executive
	Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer of Bell Canada International. Prior to that, he was a partner at the accounting firm KPMG Canada in Toronto. Mr.&nbsp;Vanaselja has served and continues to
	serve as a board director for several other companies including Great-West Lifeco&nbsp;Inc. and Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment&nbsp;Ltd. He has served as a member of the Conference Board of
	Canada's National Council of Financial Executives, the Corporate Executive Board's Working Council for Chief Financial Officers and Moody's Council of Chief Financial Officers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	PRE-APPROVAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's Audit committee has adopted a pre-approval policy with respect to
	permitted non-audit services. Under the policy, the Audit committee has granted pre-approval for
	specified non-audit services. For engagements of up to $250,000, approval of the Audit committee Chair is required, and the Audit committee is to be informed of the engagement at the next scheduled
	Audit committee meeting. For all engagements of $250,000 or more, pre-approval of the Audit committee is required. In all cases, regardless of the dollar amount involved, where there is a potential
	for conflict of interest involving the external auditor to arise on an engagement, the Audit committee must pre-approve the&nbsp;assignment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	To
	date, all non-audit services have been pre-approved by the Audit committee in accordance with the pre-approval policy described above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	36&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Legal proceedings and regulatory actions
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Legal proceedings, arbitrations and actions are part of doing business. While we cannot predict the final outcomes of proceedings and actions with certainty,
	management does not expect any current proceeding or action to have a material impact on our consolidated financial position, results of operations or liquidity. We are not aware of any potential
	legal proceeding or action that would have a material impact on our consolidated financial position, results of operations or&nbsp;liquidity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Transfer agent and registrar
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's transfer agent and registrar is Computershare Trust Company of Canada with its Canadian transfer facilities in the cities of Vancouver, Calgary,
	Toronto, Halifax and&nbsp;Montr&eacute;al.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Material contracts
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada did not enter into any material contracts outside the ordinary course of business during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, nor has it entered
	into any material contracts outside the ordinary course of business prior to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 which are still in effect as at the date of this&nbsp;AIF.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Interest of experts
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	KPMG&nbsp;LLP are the auditors of TransCanada and have confirmed that they are independent with respect to TransCanada within the meaning of the relevant
	rules and related interpretations prescribed by the relevant professional bodies in Canada and any applicable legislation or regulations and also that they are independent accountants with respect to
	all relevant U.S.&nbsp;professional and regulatory standards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=4>
	Additional information
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Additional
	information in relation to TransCanada may be found under TransCanada's profile on SEDAR (www.sedar.com).
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2.
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Additional
	information including directors' and officers' remuneration and indebtedness, principal holders of TransCanada's securities and securities authorized for issuance under
	equity compensation plans (all&nbsp;where applicable), is contained in TransCanada's Management information circular for its most recent annual meeting of shareholders that involved the election of
	directors and can be obtained upon request from the Corporate Secretary of&nbsp;TransCanada.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	3.
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Additional
	financial information is provided in TransCanada's audited consolidated financial statements and MD&amp;A for its most recently completed financial&nbsp;year.
</FONT>

	bitumen

<FONT SIZE=2>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->

<FONT SIZE=5>

<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->

	&nbsp;

</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=5>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The conversion factors set out below are approximate factors. To convert from Metric to Imperial multiply by the factor indicated. To convert from Imperial to Metric divide by the factor indicated.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="83%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="24%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</TD>

	Cubic feet
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="42%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	35.3
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</TD>

<TD WIDTH="24%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Kilopascals
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="24%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Pounds per square inch
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;

</TD>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	0.15
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="24%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Degrees Celsius
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="24%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Degrees Fahrenheit
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="42%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	to convert to Fahrenheit multiply by 1.8, then add 32&nbsp;degrees; to convert to Celsius subtract 32&nbsp;degrees, then divide by 1.8
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>

</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	*
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	conversion is based on natural gas at a base pressure of 101.325&nbsp;kilopascals and at a base temperature of 15&nbsp;degrees Celsius.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Annual information form
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;39
</FONT>
</P>
