<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	an
	ROE of 9.70&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on deemed common equity of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and included an annual fixed amount for certain OM&amp;A&nbsp;costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	EBITDA and EBIT for the Canadian pipelines reflect the variances discussed above as well as variances in depreciation, financial charges and income tax which are substantially recovered in
	revenue on a flow-through basis and, therefore, do not have a significant impact on net&nbsp;income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S. and International Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	EBITDA for our U.S.&nbsp;operations is affected by contracted volume levels, actual volumes delivered and the rates charged, as well as by the
	cost of providing services,
	including OM&amp;A and other costs as well as property&nbsp;taxes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANR
	is also affected by the level of contracting and the determination of rates driven by the market value of its storage capacity, storage related transportation services, and incidental commodity
	sales. ANR's pipeline and storage volumes and revenues are generally higher in the winter months because of the seasonal nature of its&nbsp;business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	EBITDA for the U.S. and International Pipelines was US$90&nbsp;million higher in 2014 than 2013. This was due to the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from the Tamazunchale Extension which was placed in service in&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	transportation revenue at Great Lakes mainly due to colder winter weather and increased demand
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	contributions from GTN and Bison following the reductions in our effective ownership in each pipeline in July&nbsp;2013 (GTN&nbsp;and Bison) and
	October&nbsp;2014&nbsp;(Bison)
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	stronger U.S.&nbsp;dollar had a positive impact on the Canadian dollar equivalent comparable earnings from our U.S. and International operations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	EBITDA for the U.S. and International Pipelines was US$119&nbsp;million lower in 2013 than 2012. This was due to the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>

	transportation and storage revenues at ANR partially offset by higher incidental commodity&nbsp;sales

</FONT>
</DT>

<FONT SIZE=2>

	OM&amp;A and other costs relating to services provided by other pipelines to&nbsp;ANR
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	revenue at Great Lakes because of uncontracted capacity
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>

	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>

	lower
	contributions from GTN and Bison due to the reduction of our effective ownership in each pipeline from 83&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent in 2012 to 50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent,
	effective July&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2013
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>

</FONT>
</DT>

	contributions from Portland due to higher short term revenues

</FONT>
</DT>

	a
	stronger U.S.&nbsp;dollar had a positive impact on the Canadian dollar equivalent comparable earnings from our U.S. and International operations.
</FONT>
</DD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Comparable depreciation and amortization
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable depreciation and amortization was $50&nbsp;million higher in 2014 than in 2013 mainly because of a higher rate base for the
	NGTL System. Depreciation and
	amortization was $80&nbsp;million higher in 2013 than in 2012 mainly because of a higher rate base for the NGTL System, as well as the impact of the Mainline NEB&nbsp;2013 Decision discussed
	above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Business development
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In 2014, business development expenses were $18&nbsp;million lower than 2013 due to a change in scope on the Alaska project and lower administrative costs,
	partially offset
	by higher spending on Mexican projects. Business development expenses were $6&nbsp;million higher in 2013 compared to 2012 mainly due to a change in scope on the Alaska project. See page&nbsp;54
	for further discussion on&nbsp;Alaska.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=101,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=81825,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DI75607A.;18',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75607_1_46">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	OUTLOOK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Earnings
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Earnings for Canadian Pipelines
	are affected most significantly by changes in investment base, ROE and regulated capital structure, and also by the terms of toll settlements or
	other toll proposals approved by the&nbsp;NEB.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	2015, the Canadian Mainline will operate under the terms of the 2015&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;2030 Tolls and Tariff Application, the fundamentals of which were approved by the NEB
	in November&nbsp;2014. The terms of the application decision include a lower ROE of 10.10&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on deemed common equity of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent, an incentive mechanism that has
	both upside and downside risk and a $20&nbsp;million after-tax contribution through tolls from us. As a result, we expect Canadian Mainline 2015 earnings to be lower than&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	expect the NGTL System investment base to continue to grow as we connect new natural gas supply in northeastern B.C. and western Alberta and respond to rising demand in the oil sands market in
	northeastern Alberta. We expect the growing investment base to have a positive impact on NGTL System earnings in&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	also anticipate a modest level of investment in our other Canadian rate-regulated natural gas pipelines, but expect the average investment bases of these pipelines to continue to decline as annual
	depreciation outpaces capital investment, reducing their year-over-year earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under
	the current regulatory model, earnings from Canadian rate-regulated natural gas pipelines are not materially affected by short-term fluctuations in the commodity price of natural gas, changes in
	throughput volumes or changes in contracted capacity levels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Earnings
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	U.S.&nbsp;Pipeline earnings are
	affected by the level of contracted capacity and the rates charged to customers. Our ability to recontract or sell capacity at favourable
	rates is influenced by prevailing market conditions and competitive factors, including alternatives available to end use customers in the form of competing natural gas pipelines and supply sources, in
	addition to broader macroeconomic conditions that might impact demand from certain customers or market segments. Earnings are also affected by the level of OM&amp;A and other costs, which includes the
	impact of safety, environmental and other regulator's decisions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Many
	of our U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipelines are backed by long-term take-or-pay contracts that are expected to deliver stable and consistent financial performance. ANR and Great Lakes have had more
	commercial exposure from transportation and storage contract renewals in recent years, which resulted in reduced earnings in 2013 and 2014 as transportation and storage values were depressed to
	historically low&nbsp;levels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANR
	has secured new long term contracts and extended terms at maximum recourse rates for significant volumes originating from the Utica/Marcellus shale plays with contract start dates from late 2014
	through late 2015. We continue to seek opportunities to expand upon this success along with those opportunities associated with continued growth in end use markets for natural gas. In addition, ANR
	and Great Lakes are examining commercial, regulatory and operational changes to continue to optimize their position
	in response to positive developments in supply fundamentals. As a result, we expect 2015 earnings from our U.S.&nbsp;Pipelines to increase slightly from&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mexican Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The 2015 earnings for our current operating assets in Mexico are expected to be consistent with 2014 due to the nature of the long-term contracts applicable to
	our Mexican
	pipeline systems.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Capital spending
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We spent a total of $2.1&nbsp;billion in 2014 for our natural gas pipelines in Canada, the U.S. and Mexico, and expect to spend $3.4&nbsp;billion in 2015
	primarily on the
	NGTL System expansion projects, the Topolobampo and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	46&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=102,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=343546,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DI75607A.;18',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DI75607_1_47">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Mazatlan
	pipelines in Mexico and Canadian Mainline capacity projects. See page&nbsp;105 for further discussion on liquidity&nbsp;risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	UNDERSTANDING THE NATURAL GAS PIPELINES BUSINESS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Natural gas pipelines move natural gas from major sources of supply to locations or markets that use natural gas to meet their
	energy&nbsp;needs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	natural gas pipeline business builds, owns and operates a network of natural gas pipelines in North America that connects locations where gas is produced or interconnects with other pipelines to
	end customers such as local distribution companies, power generation facilities, industrial operations and other pipeline interconnects or end-users. The network includes pipelines that are buried
	underground and transport natural gas under high pressure, compressor stations that act like pumps to move the large volumes of natural gas along the pipeline and meter stations that record the amount
	of natural gas coming on the network at receipt locations and leaving the network at delivery locations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Regulation of tolls and cost recovery
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our natural gas pipelines are generally regulated in Canada by the NEB, in the U.S.&nbsp;by the FERC and in Mexico by the CRE. The regulators
	approve construction of new
	pipeline facilities and ongoing operations of the infrastructure.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Regulators
	in Canada, the U.S. and Mexico allow us to recover costs to operate the network by collecting tolls, or payments, for services. Costs of operating the systems include a return on our
	capital invested in the assets or rate base, as well as the recovery of the rate base over time through depreciation. Other costs recovered include OM&amp;A costs, income and property taxes, and interest
	on debt. The regulator reviews our costs to ensure they are prudent and approves tolls that provide us a reasonable opportunity to recover&nbsp;them.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Within
	their respective jurisdictions, the FERC and CRE approve maximum transportation rates. These rates are cost based and are designed to recover the pipeline's investment, operating expenses and a
	reasonable return for our investors. As the pipeline operator within these jurisdictions, we may negotiate lower rates with&nbsp;shippers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Sometimes
	we enter into agreements or settlements with our shippers for tolls and cost recovery, which may include mutually beneficial performance incentives. The regulator must approve a settlement,
	including performance incentives, for it to be put into&nbsp;effect.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Generally,
	Canadian natural gas pipelines request the NEB to approve the pipeline's cost of service and tolls once a year, and recover or refund the variance between actual and expected revenues and
	costs in future years. The Canadian Mainline, however, operates under a fixed toll arrangement for its longer-term firm transportation services and has the flexibility to price its shorter-term and
	interruptible services in order to maximize its&nbsp;revenue.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	FERC does not require U.S.&nbsp;interstate pipelines to calculate rates annually, nor do they allow for the collection or refund of the variance between actual and expected revenue and costs
	into future years. This difference in U.S.&nbsp;regulation puts our U.S.&nbsp;pipelines at risk for the difference in expected and actual costs and revenues between rate cases. If revenues no
	longer provide a reasonable opportunity to recover costs, we can file with the FERC for a new determination of rates, subject to any moratorium in effect. Similarly, the FERC may institute proceedings
	to lower tolls if they consider the return on the capital invested to be too&nbsp;high.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	Mexican pipelines have approved tariffs, services and related rates. However, most of the contracts underpinning the construction and operation of the facilities in Mexico are long-term negotiated
	fixed-rate contracts. These rates are only subject to change under specific circumstances such as certain types of force majeure events or changes in&nbsp;law.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;47
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=103,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=503438,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DI75607A.;18',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_48">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Business environment and strategic priorities
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The North American natural gas pipeline network has developed to connect supply to market. Use and growth of this infrastructure is
	affected by changes in the location and
	relative cost of natural gas supplies as well as changes in the location of markets and level of&nbsp;demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have a significant pipeline footprint in the WCSB and transport approximately 75&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of total WCSB production to markets within and outside of the basin. Our pipelines also
	source natural gas, to a lesser degree, from the other major basins including the Appalachian (Utica and Marcellus), Rockies, Williston, Haynesville, Fayetteville and Anadarko as well as the Gulf
	of&nbsp;Mexico.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/02/13/0001047469-15-000798_G916400.JPG" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="756" HEIGHT="460">
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Increasing supply
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The WCSB spans almost all of
	Alberta and extends into B.C., Saskatchewan, Yukon and Northwest Territories and is Canada's primary source of natural gas supply. The WCSB is
	currently estimated to have 150&nbsp;trillion cubic&nbsp;feet of remaining conventional resources and a technically accessible unconventional resource base of over 700&nbsp;trillion
	cubic&nbsp;feet. The total recoverable WCSB resource base has recently more than quadrupled with the advent of technology that can economically access unconventional gas areas in the basin.
	Production from the WCSB increased slightly in 2014 after decreasing every year since 2007 and is expected to continue to increase over the next several years. The Montney and Horn River shale play
	formations and the Liard basin in northeastern B.C. are also part of the WCSB and have recently become a significant source of natural gas. We expect production from the Montney play that is currently
	just under 3&nbsp;Bcf/d, to grow to approximately 6&nbsp;Bcf/d by 2020, depending on the economics of exploration and production compared to other, mainly U.S., sources and the progress of
	proposed B.C. west coast LNG&nbsp;exports.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	48&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=104,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=75707,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_49">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	primary sources of natural gas in the U.S.&nbsp;are the U.S.&nbsp;shale areas, Gulf of Mexico and the Rockies. The U.S.&nbsp;shales are the biggest area of growth which we estimate will meet
	almost 50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the overall North American gas demand by 2020. The largest shale developments for natural gas are the Utica/Marcellus basins in the northeast U.S.&nbsp;These
	basins have grown from essentially no production prior to 2008 up to 16&nbsp;Bcf/d at the end of 2014. They are forecast to grow to 25&nbsp;Bcf/d by 2020. Other natural gas supply from shale in
	the U.S.&nbsp;includes the Haynesville, Barnett, Eagle Ford and Fayetteville plays.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	overall supply of natural gas in North America is forecast to increase significantly over the next decade (by&nbsp;almost 20&nbsp;Bcf/d or 22&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent by 2020), and is expected
	to continue to increase over the long term for several reasons:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	continued
	technological progress with horizontal drilling and multi-stage hydraulic fracturing or fracking. This is increasing the technically accessible resource base of
	existing basins and emerging regions, such as the Marcellus and Utica in the U.S.&nbsp;northeast, and the Montney and Horn River areas in northeastern&nbsp;B.C.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	these
	technologies are also being applied to existing oil fields where further recovery of the resource is now possible. There is often associated gas discovered in the
	exploration and production of liquids-rich hydrocarbon basins, (for&nbsp;example, the Bakken oil fields) which also contributes to an increase in the overall gas supply for North&nbsp;America.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	development of shale gas basins that are located close to existing markets, particularly in the northeast U.S., has led to an increase in the number of supply choices and is expected to change
	historical gas pipeline flow patterns, generally from long-haul, long-term firm contracted capacity to shorter-distance, shorter-term contracts. Along with our competitors, we are restructuring our
	tolls and service offerings to capture this growing northeast supply and North American demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Canadian Mainline is well positioned to offer optionality of supply to eastern Canadian and northeast U.S.&nbsp;markets, while still ensuring the opportunity to recover our costs including a
	return on the investment for both existing and new infrastructure as&nbsp;required.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Growing
	northeast supply has had a positive impact for both the Mainline, with new proposed facilities in eastern Canada, and our ANR U.S.&nbsp;pipeline assets, with significant new long-term
	contracts for service. The increase in supply in northeastern B.C. has created opportunities for us to plan and build, subject to regulatory approval and a positive final investment decisions (FID),
	new large pipeline infrastructure on the NGTL System to move the natural gas to markets, including proposed LNG exports and growing Alberta market&nbsp;demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Changing demand
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The growing supply of natural gas
	has resulted in relatively low natural gas prices in North America, which have supported increased demand for natural gas particularly in the
	following areas:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	natural
	gas-fired power generation
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	petrochemical
	and industrial facilities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	production of Alberta oil sands
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	exports
	to Mexico to fuel new power generation facilities.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Natural
	gas producers continue to progress opportunities to sell natural gas to global markets, which involves connecting natural gas supplies to new LNG export terminals which are proposed primarily
	along the west coast of B.C. and the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf of Mexico. Assuming the receipt of all necessary regulatory and other approvals, the proposed facilities along the west coast of B.C. are expected
	to become operational later in this decade. The U.S Gulf Coast also has several LNG export facilities in various stages of development or construction. LNG exports are expected to ramp up from this
	area, with initial deliveries beginning as early as late 2015. The demand created by the addition of these new markets creates opportunities for us to build new pipeline infrastructure and to increase
	throughput on our existing pipelines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;49
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=105,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=80627,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_50">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Commodity Prices
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In general, the profitability of
	our gas pipelines business is not directly tied to commodity prices given we are a transporter of the commodity and the transportation costs
	are not tied to the price of natural gas. However, the cyclical supply and demand nature of commodities and its price impact can have an indirect impact on our business where our shippers may choose
	to accelerate or delay certain projects. This can impact the timing for the demand of transportation services and/or new gas pipeline infrastructure.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	More competition
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Changes in supply and demand
	levels and locations have resulted in increased competition for transportation services throughout North America. Development of technology for
	shale gas supply basins that are closer to markets historically served by long-haul pipelines has resulted in changes to flow patterns of existing natural gas pipeline infrastructure that includes
	reversing direction of flow and different distances of haul, particularly with the large development of U.S.&nbsp;northeast supply. Along with other pipelines, we are restructuring our tolls and
	service offerings to capture this growing northeast supply and North American demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Strategic priorities
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are focused on capturing
	opportunities resulting from growing natural gas supply, and connecting new markets, while satisfying increasing demand for natural gas within
	existing markets.We are also focused on adapting our existing assets to the changing gas flow&nbsp;dynamics.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Canadian Mainline continued to be a focal point of our strategy in 2014. The cold 2013/14&nbsp;winter coupled with the ability to price our discretionary services at market prices, resulted in a
	significant increase in long-haul firm transportation originating at Empress as well as increased revenue collection from the utilization of Mainline transportation services. The regulatory framework
	in place at the time did not allow us the opportunity to meet growing demand for new gas supplies to eastern Canada and recover the
	costs for those investments. As a result, an application for approval of 2015 to 2030 tolls was filed with the NEB based on the components reached in a settlement with the three major LDCs in Ontario
	and Qu&eacute;bec. In November&nbsp;2014, the NEB approved the application as filed (2015&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;2030 Tolls and Tariff Application). This approval sets the
	stage to advance capital projects in eastern Canada to meet the needs of our eastern Canada and northeast U.S.&nbsp;shippers seeking alternative supply sources. It also ensures a reasonable
	opportunity to recover the costs associated with our existing assets as well as those related to new pipeline investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2015, we will continue to advance the planned conversion of portions of the Canadian Mainline from natural gas service to crude oil service. The Energy East Pipeline is a planned project, subject
	to regulatory approval, to convert approximately 3,000&nbsp;km (1,864&nbsp;miles) of the Canadian Mainline from the Alberta border to a point in eastern Ontario, southeast of Ottawa, to crude oil
	service. We are committed to ensuring that our gas shipper community continues to receive transportation service to meet their firm service requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	NGTL System is the major natural gas gathering and transportation system for the WCSB, connecting most of the natural gas production in western Canada to domestic and export markets. It faces
	competition for connection to supply, particularly in northeastern B.C., where the largest new source of natural gas has access to two other existing competing pipelines. Connections to new supply and
	new or growing demand continues to support new capital expansions of the NGTL System. We expect supply in the WCSB to grow from its current level of approximately 14&nbsp;Bcf/d to approximately
	16&nbsp;Bcf/d by 2020. The NGTL System is well positioned to connect WCSB supply to meet expected demand for proposed LNG exports on the B.C. coastline. Obtaining the necessary regulatory approvals
	to extend and expand the NGTL System in northeastern B.C. to connect the Montney shale area was a key focus in 2014. A hearing process that examined the merits of our North Montney Pipeline project
	concluded in December&nbsp;2014 and the NEB decision is expected by the end of April&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	50&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=106,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=818859,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_51">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	U.S.&nbsp;pipeline assets are positioned for further connections to growth in supply and markets for the following reasons:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Utica/Marcellus
	supply growth and increased demand for natural gas to supply Gulf Coast LNG export development supports additional ANR utilization, including the Lebanon
	Lateral project. We have attracted Utica supply to the ANR System with additional phases of further expansion expected
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	expected
	continued growth in gas-fired generation should lead to increased load on our pipelines, including the proposed Carty lateral on the GTN system to deliver natural
	gas to a new power plant in&nbsp;Oregon
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	growth
	in industrial load in response to robust levels of natural gas supply, including connections to the ANR System to serve a new customer in&nbsp;Iowa.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Management
	expects to drop down our remaining U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipeline assets into TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP as a means of funding a portion of our capital growth program, subject to the
	approvals of TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP's board and our board as well as market conditions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	focus in Mexico in 2015 is to advance the construction phase for the Mazatlan and Topolobampo pipelines and to continue operating our existing facilities safely and reliably. We continue to be
	very interested in the further development of natural gas infrastructure in Mexico and will work to advance future projects, that align with our strategic priorities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	SIGNIFICANT EVENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Regulated Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	NGTL System
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We continue to experience
	significant growth on the NGTL System as a result of growing natural gas supply in northwestern Alberta and northeastern B.C. from unconventional gas
	plays and substantive growth in intra-basin delivery markets. This demand growth is driven primarily by oil sands development, gas-fired electric power generation and expectations of B.C. west coast
	LNG projects. This demand for NGTL System services is expected to result in approximately 4.0&nbsp;Bcf/d of incremental firm services with approximately 3.1&nbsp;Bcf/d related to firm receipt
	services and 0.9&nbsp;Bcf/d related to firm delivery services. We will be seeking regulatory approvals in 2015 to construct new facilities to meet service requests of approximately 540&nbsp;km
	(336&nbsp;miles) of pipeline, seven compressor stations, and 40&nbsp;meter stations that will be required in 2016 and 2017 (2016/17&nbsp;Facilities). The estimated total capital cost for the
	facilities is approximately $2.7&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Including
	the new 2016/17&nbsp;Facilities, the North Montney Mainline, the Merrick Mainline, and other new supply and demand facilities, the NGTL System has approximately $6.7&nbsp;billion of
	commercially secured projects in various stages of&nbsp;development.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	North Montney Mainline
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The $1.7&nbsp;billion
	North Montney Pipeline is a proposed extension and expansion of the NGTL System to receive and transport natural gas from the North Montney area of B.C.
	The hearing for the application before the NEB to build and operate this project concluded in December&nbsp;2014. We expect the NEB to issue its report and recommendations for the project by the end
	of April&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Merrick Mainline
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In June&nbsp;2014, we
	announced the signing of agreements for approximately 1.9&nbsp;Bcf/d of firm natural gas transportation services to underpin the development of a
	major extension of our NGTL&nbsp;System.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	proposed Merrick Mainline will transport natural gas sourced through the NGTL System to the inlet of the proposed Pacific Trail Pipeline that will terminate at the Kitimat LNG Terminal at Bish
	Cove near Kitimat, B.C. The proposed project will be an extension from the existing Groundbirch Mainline section of the NGTL System beginning near Dawson Creek, B.C. to its end point near the
	community of Summit Lake, B.C. The $1.9&nbsp;billion project will consist of approximately 260&nbsp;km (161&nbsp;miles) of 48-inch diameter&nbsp;pipe.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;51
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=107,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=490571,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_52">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Subject
	to the necessary approvals, which includes the regulatory approval from the NEB for us to build and operate the pipeline, and a positive final investment decision for the Kitimat LNG project,
	we expect the Merrick Mainline to be in service in first quarter&nbsp;2020.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	2015 Revenue Requirement Settlement
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We received NEB approval
	on February 2, 2015 for our revenue requirement settlement with our shippers for 2015 on the NGTL System. The terms of the one year settlement include
	continuation of the 2014 ROE of 10.10&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent deemed equity, continuation of the 2014 depreciation rates and a mechanism for sharing variances above and
	below a fixed operating, maintenance and administrative expense amount that is based on an escalation of 2014 actual costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Mainline
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	2015&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;2030 Tolls and Tariff Application
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On November&nbsp;28, 2014, the NEB approved the
	Canadian Mainline's 2015&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;2030 Tolls and Tariff Application. The application reflected
	components of a settlement between the Canadian Mainline and the three major LDCs in Ontario and Qu&eacute;bec. The approval of this application provides a long term commercial platform for
	both the Canadian Mainline and its shippers with a known toll design for 2015 to 2020 and certain parameters for a toll-setting methodology up to 2030. The platform balances the needs of our shippers
	while at the same time ensuring a reasonable opportunity to recover the capital from our existing facilities and any new facilities required to serve existing and new&nbsp;markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Highlights
	of the approved application include:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	our
	commitment to add increased pipeline capacity that allows eastern Canadian markets more access to Dawn and Niagara area&nbsp;supplies
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	renewal
	provisions that will give us the tools to gain more certainty over capacity requirements
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	fixed
	price tolls on one-year and longer firm transportation service
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	continued
	pricing discretion for shorter term and interruptible service
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	known revenue requirement along with an incentive sharing mechanism that targets a return of 10.10&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on a deemed common equity of
	40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent, with a possible range of outcomes from 8.70&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent to 11.50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	continued use of a deferral account that compensates for the differences between actual revenues and the fixed toll arrangement, plus an agreement that any overall
	variance in revenues for the 2015-2020 period is assigned to the eastern area shippers for the period beyond&nbsp;2020.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Eastern Mainline Project
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In October&nbsp;2014, we
	filed an application seeking NEB approval to build, own and operate new facilities for our existing Canadian Mainline natural gas transmission system
	in southeastern Ontario (Eastern Mainline Project). The new facilities are a result of the proposed transfer of a portion of the Canadian Mainline capacity from natural gas service to crude oil
	service as part of our Energy East Pipeline and an open season that closed in January&nbsp;2014. The $1.5&nbsp;billion capital project will add 0.6&nbsp;Bcf/d of new capacity in the Eastern
	Triangle segment of the Canadian Mainline and will ensure appropriate levels of capacity are available to meet the requirements of existing shippers as well as new firm service commitments. The
	project is contingent upon the Energy East Pipeline and is subject to regulatory approvals expected to be issued simultaneously with regulatory approvals for the Energy East Pipeline. The project is
	expected to be in service by second quarter&nbsp;2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Other Canadian Mainline Expansions
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In addition to the Eastern
	Mainline Project, we have executed new short haul arrangements in the Eastern Triangle portion of the Canadian Mainline that require new facilities,
	or modifications to existing facilities with a total capital cost of approximately $475&nbsp;million with expected in-service dates between November&nbsp;1, 2015 and November&nbsp;1, 2016. These
	projects are subject to regulatory approval and, once constructed, will provide capacity needed to meet customer requirements in eastern&nbsp;Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	52&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=108,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=532188,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_53">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Sale of Bison Pipeline to TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In October&nbsp;2014, we closed the
	sale of our remaining 30&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in Bison Pipeline&nbsp;LLC to our master limited partnership, TC
	PipeLines,&nbsp;LP, for cash proceeds of US$215&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Sale of GTN Pipeline to TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In November&nbsp;2014, we announced
	an offer to sell the remaining 30&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in Gas Transmission Northwest&nbsp;LLC (GTN) to
	TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP. Subject to the satisfactory negotiation of terms and TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP's board approval, the transaction is expected to close in late first
	quarter&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, we held a 28.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in TC PipeLines,&nbsp;LP for which we are the General Partner.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	ANR Pipeline
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We have secured nearly
	2.0&nbsp;Bcf/d of firm natural gas transportation commitments for existing and expanded capacity on ANR Pipeline's Southeast Main Line (SEML). The
	capacity sales and expansion projects include reversing the Lebanon Lateral in western Ohio, additional compression at Sulphur Springs, Indiana, expanding the Rockies Express pipeline interconnect
	near Shelbyville, Indiana and 600&nbsp;MMcf/d of capacity as part of a reversal project on the SEML. Capital costs associated with the ANR System expansions required to bring the additional capacity
	to market are currently estimated to be US$150&nbsp;million. The capacity was subscribed at maximum rates for an average term of 23&nbsp;years with approximately 1.25&nbsp;Bcf/d of new contracts
	beginning service in late 2014. These secured contracts on the SEML will move Utica and Marcellus shale gas to points north and south on the&nbsp;system.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANR
	is also assessing further demand from our customers to transport natural gas from the Utica/Marcellus formation, which is expected to result in incremental opportunities to enhance and expand
	the&nbsp;system.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mexican Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Tamazunchale Pipeline Extension
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Construction of the
	US$600&nbsp;million extension was completed November&nbsp;6, 2014. Delays from the original service commencement date of March&nbsp;9, 2014 were
	attributed primarily to archeological findings along the pipeline route. Under the terms of the Transportation Service Agreement, these delays were recognized as a force majeure with provisions
	allowing for collection of revenue from the original service commencement&nbsp;date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Topolobampo and Mazatlan Pipelines
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Permitting, engineering, and
	construction activities are advancing as planned for these two northwest Mexico pipelines. The Topolobampo project is a 530&nbsp;km
	(329&nbsp;miles), 30-inch pipeline with a capacity of 670&nbsp;MMcf/d and a cost of US$1&nbsp;billion that will deliver gas to Topolobampo, Sinaloa from interconnects with third party pipelines
	in El Oro, Sinaloa and El Encino, Chihuahua in Mexico. The Mazatlan project is a 413&nbsp;km (257&nbsp;miles), 24-inch pipeline running from El Oro to Mazatlan within the state of Sinaloa with a
	capacity of 200&nbsp;MMcf/d and an estimated cost of US$400&nbsp;million. Both projects are supported by 25-year contracts with the CFE and are expected to be in service mid to late&nbsp;2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	International Gas Pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Gas Pacifico/INNERGY sale
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In November&nbsp;2014, we closed
	the sale of our 30&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent equity interests in Gas Pacifico/INNERGY at a price of $9&nbsp;million. This sale marks our exit
	from the Southern Cone region of South&nbsp;America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;53
</FONT>

<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=109,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=267431,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_54">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	LNG Pipeline Projects
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Coastal GasLink
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In October&nbsp;2014, the B.C.
	Environmental Assessment Office issued an Environmental Assessment Certificate (EAC) for Coastal GasLink. In 2014, we also submitted
	applications to the B.C. Oil and Gas Commission (BC&nbsp;OGC) for the permits required under the Oil and Gas Activities Act to build and operate Coastal GasLink. Regulatory review of those
	applications is progressing on schedule, with permit decisions anticipated in first quarter 2015. We are currently continuing our engagement with Aboriginal groups and stakeholders along the pipeline
	route and are progressing detailed engineering and construction planning work to support the regulatory applications and refine the capital cost estimates. Pending the receipt of all required
	regulatory approvals and a positive FID from our customer, construction is anticipated in 2016, with an in-service date by the end of the decade. Should the project not proceed, our project costs
	(including AFUDC) are fully recoverable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Prince Rupert Gas Transmission
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On November&nbsp;25, 2014, we
	received an EAC from the B.C. Environmental Assessment Office. We have submitted our pipeline permit applications to the BC OGC for construction
	of the pipeline and anticipate receiving these permits in first quarter&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have made significant changes to the project route since first announced, increasing it by 150&nbsp;km (93&nbsp;miles) to 900&nbsp;km (559&nbsp;miles), taking into account Aboriginal and
	stakeholder input. We continue to work closely with First Nations and stakeholders along the proposed route to create and deliver appropriate benefits to all impacted groups. In October&nbsp;2014,
	we concluded a benefits agreement with the Nisga'a First Nation to allow 85&nbsp;km (52&nbsp;miles) of the proposed natural gas pipeline to run through Nisga'a&nbsp;Lands.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	December&nbsp;3, 2014, our customer announced the deferral of an FID. We continue to work with our contractors to refine capital cost estimates for the project. Once the permitting process with
	the BC OGC is complete and Pacific NorthWest LNG secures the necessary regulatory approvals and proceeds with a positive FID, we will be in a position to begin construction. All costs would be fully
	recoverable should the project not proceed. The deferral of an FID past the end of 2014 has resulted in a deferral of the expected in-service date for the pipeline. The in-service date will depend on
	when our customer receives the necessary regulatory approvals and is in a position to make an&nbsp;FID.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Alaska
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In April&nbsp;2014, the State of
	Alaska passed new legislation to provide a framework for us, the three major Alaska North Slope producers (ANS&nbsp;Producers), and the
	Alaska Gasline Development Corp. (AGDC) to advance the development of an LNG export project, which is believed to be the best opportunity to commercialize Alaska North Slope gas resources in current
	market conditions. In June&nbsp;2014, we executed an agreement with the State of Alaska to abandon the previous project governance and framework and executed a new precedent agreement where we will
	act as the transporter of the State's portion of natural gas under a long-term shipping contract in the Alaska LNG Project. We also entered into a Joint Venture Agreement with the three major ANS
	Producers and AGDC to commence the pre-front end engineering and design (pre-FEED) phase of Alaska LNG Project. The pre-FEED work is anticipated to take two years to complete with our share of the
	cost to be approximately US$100&nbsp;million. The precedent agreement also provides us with full recovery of development costs in the event the project does not&nbsp;proceed.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	July&nbsp;2014, the ANS Producers filed an export permit application with the U.S.&nbsp;Department of Energy for the right to export 20&nbsp;million tonnes per annum of liquefied natural gas
	for 30&nbsp;years. In September&nbsp;2014, the FERC approved the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) pre-file request jointly made by us, the three major ANS Producers and AGDC. This approval
	triggers the NEPA environmental review process, which includes a series of community consultations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	54&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=110,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=754317,FOLIO='54',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_55">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	BUSINESS RISKS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following are risks specific to our natural gas pipelines business. See page&nbsp;99 for information about general risks that affect the company as a whole,
	including
	other operational risks, health, safety and environment (HSE) risks, and financial risks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	WCSB supply for downstream connecting pipelines
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Although we have diversified our sources of natural gas supply, many of our North American natural gas pipelines and transmission
	infrastructure assets depend largely on supply
	from the WCSB. We continue to monitor changes in the capital programs of our customers and how these changes may impact our project schedules.There is competition for this supply from several
	pipelines, demand within the basin and, in the future, demand for pipelines proposed for LNG exports from the west coast of B.C. An overall decrease in production and/or competing demand for supply,
	could impact throughput on WCSB connected pipelines that in turn could impact overall revenues generated. The WCSB has considerable reserves, but the amount actually produced depends on many
	variables, including the price of natural gas, basin-on-basin competition, downstream pipeline tolls, demand within the basin and the overall value of the reserves, including liquids content.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Market access
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We compete for market share with other natural gas pipelines. New supply basins being developed closer to markets we have historically served may reduce the
	throughput and/or
	distance of haul on our existing pipelines that may impact revenue. The long-term competitiveness of our pipeline systems and the avoidance of bypass pipelines will depend on our ability to adapt to
	changing flow patterns by offering alternative transportation services at prices that are acceptable to the&nbsp;market.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Competition for greenfield expansion
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We face competition from other pipeline companies seeking opportunities to invest in greenfield natural gas pipeline development
	opportunities. This competition could result in
	fewer projects being available that meet our investment hurdles or projects that proceed with lower overall financial returns.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Demand for pipeline capacity
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Demand for pipeline capacity is ultimately the key driver that enables pipeline transportation services to be sold. Demand for pipeline capacity is
	created by supply and market
	competition, variations in economic activity, weather variability, natural gas pipeline and storage competition and pricing of alternative fuels. Renewal of expiring contracts, and the opportunity to
	charge and collect a toll that the market requires depends on the overall demand for transportation service. A change in the level of demand for our pipeline transportation services could impact
	revenues.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Commodity Prices
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The cyclical supply and demand nature of commodities and related pricing can have a secondary impact on our business where our shippers may choose to accelerate or
	delay
	certain projects. This can impact the timing for the demand of transportation services and/or new gas pipeline infrastructure. As well, sustained low gas prices could impact our shippers' financial
	situation and their ability to meet their transportation service cost obligations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Regulatory risk
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Decisions by regulators can have an impact on the approval, timing, construction, operation and financial performance of our natural gas pipelines. There is a risk
	that
	decisions are delayed or are not favourable and therefore could impact revenues and the opportunity to further invest capital in our systems. There is also risk of a regulator disallowing a portion of
	our prudently incurred costs, now or at some point in the&nbsp;future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;55
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=111,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=510532,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DM75607_1_56">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	regulatory approval process for larger infrastructure projects, including the time it takes to receive a decision could be slowed or unfavorable due to the influence from the evolving role of
	activists and their impact on public opinion and government policy related to natural gas pipeline infrastructure development.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Increased
	scrutiny of operating processes by the regulator or other enforcing agencies has the potential to increase operating costs. There is a risk of an impact to income if these costs are not
	fully recoverable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	continuously monitor regulatory developments and decisions to determine the possible impact on our gas pipelines business. We also work closely with our stakeholders in the development of rate,
	facility and tariff applications and negotiated settlements, where&nbsp;possible.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Operational
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Keeping our pipelines operating safely and reliably is essential to the success of our business. Interruptions in our pipeline operations impact our throughput
	capacity and may
	result in reduced revenue and can affect corporate reputation as well as customer and public confidence in our operations. We manage this by investing in a highly skilled workforce, operating
	prudently, using risk-based preventive maintenance programs and making effective capital investments. We use internal inspection equipment to check our pipelines regularly, and repair or replace them
	whenever necessary. We also calibrate the meters regularly to ensure accuracy, and continuously maintain compression equipment to ensure safe and reliable operation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	56&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=112,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=788607,FOLIO='56',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DM75607A.;23',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DO75607_1_57">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT COLOR="#0033E1" SIZE=4>
	Liquids Pipelines
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our existing liquids pipeline infrastructure connects Alberta and U.S.&nbsp;crude oil supplies to U.S.&nbsp;refining markets in Illinois, Oklahoma and
	Texas, as well as connecting U.S.&nbsp;crude oil supplies from the Cushing, Oklahoma hub to refining markets in the U.S Gulf Coast. Our proposed future pipeline infrastructure would also connect
	Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;crude oil supplies to refining markets in eastern Canada and overseas export markets, expand Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;crude oil to U.S.&nbsp;markets and connect condensate
	supplies to U.S. and Canadian markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="33%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="6%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=0>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="43%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Strategy at a glance
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="6%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=0>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="43%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	With the increasing production of crude oil in Alberta and the U.S. and the growing demand for secure, reliable sources of energy, developing new liquids pipeline capacity and related infrastructure
	is&nbsp;essential.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="6%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=0>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="43%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	We continue to focus on accessing and delivering growing North American liquids supply to key markets, and are planning to expand our liquids transportation infrastructure to deliver supply directly from producing regions seamlessly along a
	contiguous path to the&nbsp;market.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="6%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=0>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="43%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	We see the potential for expanding transportation service offerings to other areas of the liquids pipelines value chain such as condensate transportation or ancillary services such as short and long-term storage of liquids, which complement our
	pipeline transportation infrastructure.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="6%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=0>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="43%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	Construction of these infrastructure projects will provide North America with a key liquids transportation network to transport growing crude oil supply directly to key markets and provide opportunities for us to further expand our liquids pipelines
	business.
<BR>
<BR>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;57
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	1,897&nbsp;km
<BR>
	(1,179&nbsp;miles)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="48%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	To transport crude oil from Hardisty, Alberta to Steele City, Nebraska to expand capacity of the Keystone Pipeline System
</FONT>

	Liquids Pipelines segmented earnings were $240&nbsp;million higher in 2014 than in 2013 and $50&nbsp;million higher in 2013 than in 2012. Liquids Pipelines segmented earnings are
	equivalent to comparable EBIT, which along with comparable EBITDA, are discussed below.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Comparable EBITDA
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable EBITDA for the Keystone Pipeline System was $307&nbsp;million higher this year than in 2013. This increase was primarily due&nbsp;to:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	incremental
	earnings from the Keystone Gulf Coast extension which was placed in service in January&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	stronger U.S.&nbsp;dollar which had a positive impact on the Canadian dollar equivalent comparable earnings from our U.S.&nbsp;operations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	EBITDA for the Keystone Pipeline System was $54&nbsp;million higher in 2013 than in 2012. This increase reflected higher revenues primarily resulting&nbsp;from:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	volumes
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	impact of higher final fixed tolls on committed pipeline capacity to Cushing, Oklahoma, which came into effect in July&nbsp;2012
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	stronger U.S.&nbsp;dollar which had a positive impact on the Canadian dollar equivalent comparable earnings from our U.S.&nbsp;operations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Comparable depreciation and amortization
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable depreciation and amortization was $67&nbsp;million higher in 2014 than in 2013 due to the Keystone Gulf Coast extension being
	placed in&nbsp;service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	60&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
