<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=116,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=694401,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DQ75607A.;12',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_61">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	OUTLOOK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Earnings
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our 2015 earnings are not expected to be significantly different than our 2014 earnings. We continue to seek further operational efficiencies which would, depending on
	market
	demand, improve capacity and flows on the Keystone Pipeline System.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Over
	time, Liquids Pipelines' earnings will increase as projects currently in development are placed in&nbsp;service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Capital spending
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We spent a total of $2.0&nbsp;billion in 2014 on capital spending in Liquids Pipelines. We expect to spend approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion on capital spending and
	equity
	investments in 2015, primarily on Grand Rapids, Northern Courier, Energy East and Heartland. See page&nbsp;105 for further discussion on liquidity&nbsp;risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	UNDERSTANDING THE LIQUIDS PIPELINES BUSINESS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In general, pipelines move crude oil from major supply sources to refinery markets so the crude oil can be refined into various
	petroleum products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	generate earnings from our liquids pipelines mainly by providing pipeline capacity to shippers in exchange for fixed monthly payments that are not linked to actual throughput volumes. Uncontracted
	capacity is offered to the market on a spot basis which provides opportunities to generate incremental earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	terms of service and fixed monthly payments are determined by transportation service arrangements negotiated with shippers. These arrangements are typically long term, and provide for the recovery
	of costs we incur to construct and operate the&nbsp;system.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Business environment and strategic priorities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/02/13/0001047469-15-000798_G906416.JPG" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="756" HEIGHT="459">
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;61
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=117,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=702440,FOLIO='61',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_62">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Over
	the past decade, North American crude oil production has increased significantly in response to growth in global energy consumption and increased demand for crude oil. This growth in crude oil
	supply has increased the demand for new liquids pipeline infrastructure to connect these supplies to key North American and overseas markets. We have successfully secured a $25&nbsp;billion
	portfolio of commercially secured projects to develop this infrastructure and we continue to pursue additional opportunities to expand our transportation service offerings to other areas of the value
	chain such as the long-term storage of&nbsp;liquids.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Recently,
	crude oil prices have declined sharply as continued growth in U.S.&nbsp;light oil supply, which has displaced North American imports, and growth in other global supplies has outpaced
	incremental demand. Although supplies from high cost production may be reduced if lower prices persist, our business is not expected to be significantly impacted by commodity price changes or supply
	reductions. Our existing operations and development projects are supported by long-term contracts where we have agreed to provide pipeline capacity to our customers in exchange for fixed monthly
	payments. The cyclical supply and demand nature of commodities and its price movements can have a secondary impact on our business where our shippers may choose to accelerate or delay certain new
	projects. This can impact the timing for the demand of transportation services and/or new liquids pipeline infrastructure.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Commodity
	price fluctuations are a normal part of the business cycle. Longer-term, we expect global demand for crude oil will continue to grow resulting in continued growth in North American crude oil
	supply production and demand for new pipeline infrastructure. Our growing position in the crude oil transportation business is creating a significant platform to capture these future growth
	opportunities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Supply outlook
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canada
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Alberta produces the majority of
	the crude oil in the WCSB which is the primary source of crude oil supply for the Keystone Pipeline System. In its 2014 Crude Oil Forecast,
	Markets and Transportation report, the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP) estimated 2015 WCSB crude oil production of 1.4&nbsp;million Bbl/d of conventional crude oil and condensate
	and 2.2&nbsp;million Bbl/d of oil sands crude oil, a total of approximately 3.6&nbsp;million Bbl/d. The report forecasted WCSB crude oil production will increase to 4.6&nbsp;million Bbl/d by
	2020 and to 6.4&nbsp;million Bbl/d by&nbsp;2030.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	a January&nbsp;2015 press release, CAPP announced estimated 2015 industry capital spending in western Canada, including oil sands development, would decline to $46&nbsp;billion,
	$23&nbsp;billion lower than forecasted in 2014. CAPP forecasts a slowing in the growth of crude oil production from the 2014 Crude Oil Forecast, Markets and Transportation report by
	65,000&nbsp;Bbl/d in 2015 and 120,000&nbsp;Bbl/d in 2016. Although CAPP anticipates a decrease in capital spending, the revised forecast for total western Canadian crude oil production is
	approximately 150,000&nbsp;higher in 2015 than in&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	According
	to the May&nbsp;2014
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Alberta's Energy Reserves 2013 and Supply/Demand Outlook 2014-2023
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, the Alberta Energy Regulator (AER) estimated there
	is approximately 167&nbsp;billion barrels of economically and technically recoverable conventional and oil sands reserves in Alberta. Oil sands projects have a long reserve life. It is estimated
	that a typical oil sands mine has a 25 to 50&nbsp;year lifespan, while an in-situ operation will run 10 to 15&nbsp;years on average. This longevity aligns with the producer's desire to secure
	long-term connectivity of their reserves to market. The Keystone Pipeline System, including Keystone XL, and the proposed Energy East Pipeline are underpinned by long term&nbsp;contracts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	According to the International
	Energy Agency World Energy Outlook 2014 Report, by 2020 the U.S.&nbsp;is set to surpass Saudi Arabia as the world's largest crude oil producer.
	The U.S.&nbsp;Energy Information Administration (EIA) projects over 1.0&nbsp;million Bbl/d of U.S.&nbsp;production growth from 2014 to 2019, peaking at 9.6&nbsp;million Bbl/d by 2019. Higher
	production volumes are mainly a result of recent advancements in shale oil production. EIA forecasts shale oil production peaking at approximately 4.8&nbsp;million Bbl/d by 2020 and declining
	after&nbsp;2022.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	62&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=118,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=34295,FOLIO='62',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_63">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	U.S.&nbsp;shale
	oil supply growth is mainly originating from the Bakken formation of the Williston basin in North Dakota and Montana, the Permian basin in south Texas and Woodford shale area of the
	Arkoma basin in Oklahoma. These shale production areas also represent some of the sources of crude oil supply for our Bakken Marketlink and Cushing Marketlink projects.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Growing
	U.S.&nbsp;production has contributed to increased crude oil supply at the Cushing, Oklahoma market hub and resulted in increased demand for additional pipeline capacity between Cushing,
	Oklahoma and the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf Coast refining market. Cushing Marketlink, which use facilities that form part of the Keystone Pipeline System, provides pipeline capacity to transport growing crude
	oil supply at Cushing, Oklahoma to the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf&nbsp;Coast.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Even
	with growth in U.S.&nbsp;crude oil production, the EIA report predicts the U.S.&nbsp;will remain a net importer of crude oil, importing 7.7&nbsp;million Bbl/d into 2040. Growing production
	in the west Texas Permian, south Texas Eagle Ford and Williston basins is primarily light crude oil and is expected to compete with light imports from countries such as Nigeria and Saudi Arabia. Gulf
	Coast refiners are expected to continue to prefer Canadian heavy crude oil because these refineries are mainly configured to process heavy and medium crude oil and cannot easily switch to processing
	the new light shale oil in large quantities without significant capital investments. Gulf Coast refineries currently require approximately 3.5&nbsp;million Bbl/d of heavy and medium crude oil, and
	the level of demand is not expected to change significantly in the future. The Keystone Pipeline System is well positioned to deliver Canadian crude oil to this significant market.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Strategic priorities
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are focused on advancing our current portfolio of commercially secured projects to connect growing Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;crude oil supply to
	key&nbsp;markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Securing
	regulatory approval for our $12&nbsp;billion Energy East Pipeline is a key priority. In 2014, we filed necessary regulatory applications for approval to construct and operate this project
	and we are actively engaged with stakeholders as we work towards securing regulatory approval. Refineries in eastern Canada currently process primarily light crude oil imported from west Africa and
	the Middle East, and therefore could process North American light crude oil. According to the 2014
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Crude Oil Forecast, Markets and Transportation
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	report, total refining capacity in eastern Canada is approximately 1.2&nbsp;million Bbl/d, and western Canada supplied only 354,000&nbsp;Bbl/d to these eastern refineries. Due to insufficient
	pipeline capacity, many of these refineries have begun receiving domestic light crude oil in small quantities by rail at a cost significantly higher than the cost to ship by pipeline. This has created
	a significant demand for pipelines to connect eastern Canada with growing Bakken and WCSB light crude oil production. We anticipate that our Energy East Pipeline, once approved and constructed, will
	meet this&nbsp;demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	also remain fully committed to Keystone XL despite the unprecedented regulatory delays we have faced on this project. Keystone XL would expand the Keystone Pipeline System to provide more than
	800,000&nbsp;Bbl/d of additional capacity. This project is supported by long-term contracts and will transport crude oil from Canada as well as growing U.S.&nbsp;crude oil supplies to the large
	refining markets found in the American Midwest and along the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf&nbsp;Coast.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Within
	Alberta, we are leveraging our extensive natural gas pipeline footprint and experience to develop a regional liquids pipeline business. Growth in oil sands production is driving the need for
	new intra-Alberta pipelines, like our Grand Rapids Pipeline, that can move crude oil production from the source to market hubs at Edmonton/Heartland and Hardisty, Alberta as well as diluent from
	Edmonton/Heartland region to the production area in northern Alberta. The Heartland Pipeline and TC Terminals projects are intended to support these market hubs which will allow shippers the ability
	to connect with the Keystone Pipeline System, Energy East Pipeline and other pipelines that transport crude oil outside of Alberta to ultimately provide our customers with a contiguous seamless path
	from production to&nbsp;market.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	our liquids pipeline footprint continues to grow throughout North America, we are also pursuing other opportunities to expand our service offerings.These opportunities also include the development
	of rail transportation solutions, transportation of other liquids such as condensate, and the addition of terminal and liquids storage services to complement our existing infrastructure.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;63
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=119,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=749681,FOLIO='63',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_64">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	SIGNIFICANT EVENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Keystone Pipeline System
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The completion of the Gulf Coast extension in January&nbsp;2014 expanded the Keystone Pipeline System to a 4,247&nbsp;km (2,639&nbsp;miles) pipeline
	system that
	transports crude oil from Hardisty, Alberta, to markets in the U.S.&nbsp;Midwest and the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf&nbsp;Coast.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	To
	date, the Keystone Pipeline System has delivered more than 830&nbsp;million barrels of crude oil from Canada to the&nbsp;U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Cushing Marketlink
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Construction was completed on the Cushing Marketlink facilities at Cushing, Oklahoma in September&nbsp;2014. Cushing Marketlink transports crude oil from the
	market hub at
	Cushing, Oklahoma to the U.S.&nbsp;Gulf Coast refining market on facilities that form part of the Keystone Pipeline System.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Houston Lateral and Terminal
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Construction continues on the 77&nbsp;km (48&nbsp;miles) Houston Lateral pipeline and tank terminal which will extend the Keystone Pipeline System to
	Houston, Texas
	refineries. The terminal is expected to have initial storage capacity for 700,000&nbsp;barrels of crude oil. The pipeline and terminal are expected to be completed in the second half of&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Keystone XL
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In January&nbsp;2014, the DOS released its Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (FSEIS) for the Keystone XL project. The results included in the report
	were
	consistent with previous environmental reviews of Keystone XL. The FSEIS concluded Keystone XL is "unlikely to significantly impact the rate of extraction in the oil sands" and that all other
	alternatives to Keystone XL are less efficient methods of transporting crude oil, and would result in significantly more greenhouse gas emissions, oil spills and risks to public safety. The report
	initiated the National Interest Determination period of up to 90&nbsp;days which involves consultation with other governmental agencies and provides an opportunity for public comment. In
	April&nbsp;2014, the DOS announced that the national interest determination period has been extended indefinitely to allow them to consider the potential impact of the case discussed below on the
	Nebraska portion of the pipeline&nbsp;route.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	February&nbsp;2014, a Nebraska district court ruled that the state Public Service Commission, rather than Governor Dave Heineman, has the authority to approve an alternative route through
	Nebraska for Keystone&nbsp;XL. Nebraska's Attorney General filed an appeal which was heard by the Nebraska State Supreme Court on September&nbsp;5, 2014. On January&nbsp;9, 2015, the Nebraska
	State Supreme Court vacated the lower court's ruling that the law was unconstitutional. As a result, the Governor's January&nbsp;2013 approval of the alternate route through Nebraska for Keystone XL
	remains valid. Landowners have filed lawsuits in two Nebraska counties seeking to enjoin Keystone XL from condemning easements on state constitutional grounds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	September&nbsp;2014, we filed a certification petition for Keystone XL with the South Dakota Public Utilities Commission (PUC). This certification confirms that the conditions under which
	Keystone XL's original June&nbsp;2010 PUC&nbsp;construction permit was granted continue to be satisfied. The formal hearing for the certification is scheduled for May&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	January&nbsp;16, 2015, the DOS reinitiated the national interest review and requested the eight federal agencies, with a role in the review, to complete their consideration of whether Keystone XL
	serves the national interest and to provide their views to the DOS by February&nbsp;2, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	February&nbsp;2, 2015, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) posted a comment letter to its website suggesting that, among other things, the FSEIS issued by the DOS has not fully and
	completely assessed the environmental impacts of Keystone&nbsp;XL and that, at lower oil prices, Keystone&nbsp;XL may increase the rates of oil sands production and greenhouse gas emissions. On
	February&nbsp;10, 2015, we sent a letter to the DOS refuting
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	64&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=120,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=642592,FOLIO='64',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_65">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	these
	and other comments in the EPA letter but also offering to work with the DOS to ensure it has all the relevant information to allow it to reach a decision to approve Keystone&nbsp;XL.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	timing and ultimate approval of Keystone&nbsp;XL remain uncertain. In the event the project does not proceed as planned, we would reassess and reduce its carrying value to its recoverable amount
	if necessary and appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	estimated capital costs for Keystone XL are expected to be approximately US$8.0&nbsp;billion. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, we have invested US$2.4&nbsp;billion in the&nbsp;project and
	have also capitalized interest in the amount of US$0.4&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Keystone Hardisty Terminal
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Keystone Hardisty Terminal will be constructed in conjunction with Keystone XL and is expected to be completed approximately two years from the date
	the Keystone XL permit
	is&nbsp;received.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Energy East Pipeline
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In March&nbsp;2014, we filed the project description for the Energy East Pipeline with the NEB. This was the first formal step in the regulatory process to
	receive the
	necessary approvals to build and operate the&nbsp;pipeline.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	October&nbsp;30, 2014, we filed the necessary regulatory applications for approvals to construct and operate the Energy East Pipeline and terminal facilities with the NEB. The project is
	estimated to cost approximately $12&nbsp;billion, excluding the transfer value of Canadian Mainline natural gas assets. Subject to regulatory approvals, the pipeline is anticipated to commence
	deliveries by the end of&nbsp;2018.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Energy East Pipeline includes a proposed marine terminal near Cacouna, Qu&eacute;bec which would be adjacent to a beluga whale habitat. On December&nbsp;8, 2014, the Committee on the
	Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada recommended that beluga whales
	be placed on the endangered species list. As a result, we have made the decision to halt any further work at Cacouna and will be analyzing the recommendation, assessing any impacts to the project and
	reviewing all viable&nbsp;options. We intend to make a decision on how to proceed by the end of first quarter&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	1.1&nbsp;million Bbl/d Energy East Pipeline received approximately one million Bbl/d of firm, long-term contracts to transport crude oil from western Canada that were secured during binding
	open&nbsp;seasons.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Northern Courier Pipeline
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In July&nbsp;2014, the AER issued a permit approving our application to construct and operate the Northern Courier Pipeline. Construction has started on
	the
	$900&nbsp;million, 90&nbsp;km (56&nbsp;miles) pipeline to transport bitumen and diluent between the Fort Hills mine site and Suncor Energy's terminal located north of Fort McMurray, Alberta. We
	currently expect the pipeline to be ready for service in&nbsp;2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Heartland Pipeline and TC Terminals
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Heartland Pipeline is a 200&nbsp;km (125&nbsp;miles) crude oil pipeline connecting the Edmonton/Heartland, Alberta market region to
	facilities in Hardisty, Alberta. TC
	Terminals is a terminal facility in the Heartland industrial area north of Edmonton, Alberta.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	pipeline could transport up to 900,000&nbsp;Bbl/d, while the terminal is expected to have initial storage capacity for up to 1.9&nbsp;million barrels of crude oil. In February&nbsp;2014, the
	application for the terminal facility was approved and construction commenced in October&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	These
	projects together have a combined estimated cost of $900&nbsp;million and are expected to be placed in service in late&nbsp;2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Grand Rapids Pipeline
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On October&nbsp;9, 2014, the AER issued a permit approving our application to construct and operate the Grand Rapids Pipeline. We have a partner through a
	joint venture, to
	develop Grand Rapids, a 460&nbsp;km (287&nbsp;miles) crude oil and diluent pipeline system connecting the producing area northwest of Fort McMurray, Alberta to
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;65
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=121,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1033742,FOLIO='65',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DU75607_1_66">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	terminals
	in the Edmonton/Heartland, Alberta region. Each partner will own 50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the $3&nbsp;billion pipeline project, and we will be the operator. Our partner has also
	entered into a long-term transportation service contract in support of Grand Rapids. Construction has commenced with initial crude oil transportation planned in&nbsp;2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Upland Pipeline
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In November&nbsp;2014, we completed a successful binding open season for the Upland Pipeline. The $600&nbsp;million pipeline would provide crude oil transportation
	from,
	and between multiple points in North Dakota and interconnect with the Energy East Pipeline System at Moosomin, Saskatchewan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Subject
	to regulatory approvals, we anticipate the Upland Pipeline to be in service in 2018. The commercial contracts we have executed for Upland Pipeline are conditioned on Energy East proceeding.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	BUSINESS RISKS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following are risks specific to our liquids pipelines business. See page&nbsp;99 for information about general risks that affect the company as a whole,
	including other
	operational risks, health, safety and environment (HSE) risks, and financial risks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Operational
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Optimizing and maintaining availability of our liquids pipelines is essential to the success of our liquids pipelines business. Interruptions in our pipeline
	operations impact
	our throughput capacity and may result in reduced fixed payment revenues and spot volume opportunities. We manage this by investing in a highly skilled workforce, operating prudently, using risk-based
	preventive maintenance programs and making effective capital investments. We use internal inspection equipment to check our pipelines regularly and repair them whenever necessary.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Regulatory
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Decisions by Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;regulators can have a significant impact on the approval, construction, operation and financial performance of our liquids
	pipelines.
	Public opinion about crude oil development and production may also have an adverse impact on the regulatory process. There are some individuals and interest groups that are expressing their opposition
	to crude oil production by lobbying against the construction of liquids pipelines. We manage this risk by continuously monitoring regulatory developments and decisions to determine their possible
	impact on our liquids pipelines business and by working closely with our stakeholders in the development and operation of the&nbsp;assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Execution, capital costs and permitting
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We make substantial capital commitments in large infrastructure projects based on the assumption that the new assets will offer an
	attractive return on investment in the
	future. Under some contracts, we share the cost of these risks with customers. While we carefully consider the expected cost of our capital projects, under some contracts we bear capital cost risk
	which may impact our return on these projects. Our capital projects are also subject to permitting risk which may result in construction delays, increased capital cost and, potentially, reduced
	investment returns.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Crude oil supply and demand for pipeline capacity
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A decrease in demand for refined crude oil products could adversely impact the price that crude oil producers receive for their
	product. Lower prices for crude oil could mean
	producers may curtail their investment in the further development of crude oil supplies. Depending on their severity, these factors would negatively impact the opportunities we have to expand our
	crude oil pipeline infrastructure and, in the longer term, to re-contract with shippers as current agreements expire.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Competition
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As we continue to develop a competitive position in the North American liquids transportation market to transport growing WCSB, Williston, Permian and Arkoma basins
	crude oil
	supplies to key North American refining markets and export markets, we face
	competition from other pipeline companies, and to a lesser extent, rail companies which also seek to transport these crude oil supplies to the same markets. Our success is dependent on our ability to
	offer and contract transportation services on terms that are market competitive.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	66&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=122,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=725406,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DU75607A.;34',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DW75607_1_67">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT COLOR="#0033E1" SIZE=4>
	Energy
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our Energy business includes a portfolio of power generation assets in Canada and the U.S., and unregulated natural gas storage assets in&nbsp;Alberta.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	own, control or are developing approximately 11,800&nbsp;MW of generation capacity powered by natural gas, nuclear, coal, hydro, wind and solar assets. Our power business in Canada is mainly
	located in Alberta, Ontario and Qu&eacute;bec. Our power business in the U.S.&nbsp;is located in New&nbsp;York, New&nbsp;England, and Arizona. The assets are largely supported by
	long-term contracts and some represent low-cost baseload generation, while others are critically located, essential capacity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	conduct wholesale and retail electricity marketing and trading throughout North America from our offices in Alberta, Ontario and Massachusetts to actively manage our commodity exposure and provide
	higher&nbsp;returns.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	own and operate approximately 118&nbsp;Bcf of unregulated natural gas storage capacity in Alberta and hold a contract with a third party for additional storage, in total accounting for
	approximately one-third of all storage capacity in the province. When combined with the regulated natural gas storage in Michigan (part of the Natural Gas Pipelines segment), we provide over
	350&nbsp;Bcf of natural gas storage and related services.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_79"></A>
<TABLE WIDTH="84%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="39%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Strategy at a glance
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	We are focusing on growing a portfolio of low-cost, long-life power generation and natural gas storage assets located in core North American markets, while maximizing the value of our existing investments through safe and reliable operations.
<BR>
<BR>
	Growth opportunities in the North American power generation sector are arising from increasing demand for power and the need to replace aging power generation infrastructure with gas-fired and renewable generation plants as societal trends and
	policies continue to focus on lowering the carbon intensity of the generation fleet. We are well positioned to participate in the development of this new power generation infrastructure due to our strong presence and experience in core markets and
	the strategic locations of existing operations. Our recent investments in solar generation and the construction of the Napanee Generating Station in Ontario, both of which are underpinned with long-term contracts, are examples of such growth and
	opportunity. The potential for further nuclear refurbishment at Bruce Power is another example of the opportunities for us to further develop our diverse portfolio of generation technologies, fuel types, markets and contract structures.
<BR>
<BR>
	Natural gas storage's role in balancing and providing reliability and flexibility to the natural gas system is expected to grow as the market expands and becomes more dynamic as a result of the electric grid's increased reliance on gas-fired capacity
	and from the addition of LNG export terminals. In the long-term, we expect an increased dependence on natural gas storage will drive higher returns from our gas storage operations.
<BR>
<BR>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="52%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/02/13/0001047469-15-000798_G783552.JPG" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="231" HEIGHT="237">
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Includes facilities under construction.
<BR>
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Energy segmented earnings were $62&nbsp;million lower in 2014 than in 2013 and $534&nbsp;million higher in 2013 than in&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Energy
	segmented earnings included the following specific items:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	gain of $108&nbsp;million on the sale of Cancarb Limited and its related power generation business, which closed in April&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	net loss of $43&nbsp;million resulting from the contract termination payment to Niska Gas Storage effective April&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	net loss of $20&nbsp;million resulting from the Sundance A PPA arbitration decision in July&nbsp;2012 related to&nbsp;2011
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The year over year variances in these unrealized gains and losses reflect the impact of changes in forward natural gas and power prices and the volume of our
	position for these particular derivatives over a certain period of time; however, they do not accurately reflect the gains and losses that will be realized on settlement, or the offsetting impact of
	other derivative and non-derivative transactions that make up our business as a whole. As a result, we do not consider them part of our underlying operations.
</FONT>
</P>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	four solar facilities acquired between June and December&nbsp;2013, three solar facilities acquired in September&nbsp;2014, one solar facility acquired in
	December&nbsp;2014 and Cartier Wind phase two of Gros-Morne completed in November&nbsp;2012.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	our share of equity income from our equity accounted for investments in ASTC Power Partnership, Portlands Energy, Bruce Power and CrossAlta up to
	December&nbsp;2012. In December&nbsp;2012, we acquired the remaining 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in CrossAlta, bringing our ownership interest to 100&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent, and commenced
	consolidating their operations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable EBITDA for Energy was $15&nbsp;million lower in 2014 than in 2013. The decrease was the effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	earnings from Western Power due to lower realized prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from U.S.&nbsp;Power mainly because of higher realized capacity prices in New&nbsp;York and higher realized power prices at our New&nbsp;York and
	New&nbsp;England facilities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	incremental
	earnings from Eastern Power primarily due to four solar facilities acquired in each of 2013 and&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	earnings from Natural Gas Storage due to lower realized natural gas storage price&nbsp;spreads.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	72&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=128,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=212797,FOLIO='72',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DY75607A.;22',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DY75607_1_73">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	EBITDA for Energy was $460&nbsp;million higher in 2013 compared to 2012. This increase was the effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	equity income from Bruce Power due to incremental earnings from Units 1 and 2 and lower planned outage days at Unit 4&nbsp;as well as an insurance recovery related
	to the May&nbsp;2012 Unit 2&nbsp;electrical generation failure
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from U.S.&nbsp;Power mainly because of higher realized capacity prices in New&nbsp;York and higher realized power&nbsp;prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from Western Power primarily because of higher purchased volumes under the&nbsp;PPAs.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	OUTLOOK
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Earnings
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We expect 2015 earnings from the Energy segment to be slightly lower than 2014, assuming the net effect of the following expectations:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	power prices in Alberta
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	Bruce Power equity income due to increased planned maintenance activity and higher operating&nbsp;costs
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	contributions from our Natural Gas Storage operations
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	earnings as a result of the sale of Cancarb in April&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	realized capacity prices in New&nbsp;York
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	contributions from U.S.&nbsp;Power assets due to increased net energy margins and&nbsp;production
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	full year of earnings from Ontario solar facilities acquired in 2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	contributions from our power operations in Qu&eacute;bec.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Although
	a significant portion of Energy's output is sold under long-term contracts, revenue from power that is sold under shorter-term forward arrangements or at spot prices will continue to be
	impacted by fluctuations in commodity prices and changes in seasonal natural gas storage price spreads will impact Natural Gas Storage earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Weather,
	unplanned outages and unforeseen regulatory changes can play a role in spot markets and can drive fluctuations in our Energy&nbsp;results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Western Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2015 average spot power prices are expected to be slightly lower than 2014. The Alberta power market was relatively well supplied in 2014 and that trend is expected
	to be
	further entrenched in 2015 with the addition of a large gas-fired power plant in the Calgary area which is expected to be placed in service in first half 2015. Average spot market power prices in 2014
	($50/MWh) were much lower than 2013 ($80/MWh) primarily due to strong coal fleet availability and new wind generation capacity despite strong annual power demand growth of just over three
	per&nbsp;cent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Alberta Electric System Operator is forecasting healthy supply growth over the next 10&nbsp;years in order to meet continued demand growth of over three per&nbsp;cent per year over the next
	10&nbsp;years. While some of this robust growth outlook in Alberta is underpinned by oil and gas activity and demand, it is also driven by the anticipated coal fleet turnover and need to replace
	other aging generation capacity being retired over time. We remain cautiously optimistic that the Alberta market will continue to outpace growth in other regions of North&nbsp;America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Natural Gas Storage
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Natural gas price spreads are expected to modestly improve from cyclical lows, however, extreme gas price volatility experienced in first quarter 2014 is not
	expected to repeat
	in first quarter 2015. As a result, the 2015 segment contribution is expected to be slightly lower compared to 2014&nbsp;results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;73
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=129,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=306739,FOLIO='73',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]DY75607A.;22',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_DY75607_1_74">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Eastern Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In January&nbsp;2015, the OPA and the Independent Electricity System Operator (IESO) merged and now operate as one organization which is continuing under the name
	IESO. This
	merger does not impact the terms of any of our contracts with the&nbsp;OPA.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All
	of our energy assets in eastern Canada are fully contracted. The Ontario assets are contracted with the IESO and are largely sheltered from spot market pricing. Eastern Power earnings in 2015 are
	expected to be higher as a result of a full year of operations from the additional solar assets acquired in 2014 as well as higher contractual earnings at&nbsp;B&eacute;cancour.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Ontario power market is currently well supplied despite the fact that the coal-fired fleet is now fully retired. The combination of flat system demand growth, partly due to conservation programs
	and increased nuclear and renewable output, is enabling Ontario to be a net exporter of&nbsp;electricity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bruce Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We expect 2015 equity income from Bruce Power to be lower than 2014 primarily due to increased planned maintenance activity and higher costs at each of Bruce A and
	Bruce B.
	During second quarter 2015, all Bruce B units are expected to be removed from service for approximately one month to allow for inspection of the Bruce B vacuum building. The vacuum building is a key
	component of the site's safety systems and is required to be inspected approximately once every decade. Additional planned maintenance at Bruce B is scheduled to occur during second
	quarter&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Planned
	maintenance at Bruce A is scheduled for first and third quarters of&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Overall
	plant availability percentages in 2015 are expected to be in the mid 80s for Bruce A and Bruce&nbsp;B.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Ontario government's 2013 Long-Term Energy Plan outlined their intentions on nuclear power's role in the fuel mix going forward. The potential refurbishment of six Bruce Power units was included
	within the plan and Bruce Power is actively considering the site's refurbishment options within this&nbsp;context.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	U.S.&nbsp;northeast markets experienced a colder than normal winter in 2014 with multiple polar vortex events and natural gas pipeline constraints causing high
	price
	volatility in the winter months. However, the summer months experienced below normal temperatures that reduced air conditioning power demand. In 2015, we expect to continue to experience price
	volatility in the winter months due to pipeline constraints; however, recent reductions in fuel oil prices are anticipated to keep peak price excursions limited compared to previous years. The
	New&nbsp;York and New&nbsp;England ISO forecasts growth in the demand for power of about one per&nbsp;cent per year in the coming&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	northeastern U.S.&nbsp;power facilities also earn significant revenues through participation in regional capacity markets. Capacity markets compensate power suppliers for being available to
	provide power, and as a result are intended to promote investment in new and existing power resources needed to meet customer demand and maintain a reliable power system. New&nbsp;York Spot capacity
	prices are on average expected to be lower in 2015 than&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	timing of recognizing earnings from our U.S.&nbsp;power marketing business is impacted by different pricing profiles between the prices we charge our customers and the prices we pay for volumes
	purchased to fulfill our sales obligations over the term of the contracts. The costs on volumes purchased to fulfill power sales commitments to wholesale, commercial and industrial customers includes
	the impact of certain contracts to purchase power over multiple periods at a flat price. Because the price we charge our customers is typically shaped to the market, the impact of these two contract
	pricing profiles has generally resulted in higher earnings in January to March, offset by lower earnings between April and December with overall positive margins over the term of the contracts. Due to
	increased volatility of forward natural gas and power prices in the New&nbsp;England market, these timing differences will be more significant in&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	74&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Capital spending
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We spent a total of $0.2&nbsp;billion in 2014, and expect to spend approximately $0.3&nbsp;billion on capital spending in Energy in 2015. See page&nbsp;105 for
	further
	discussion on liquidity&nbsp;risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Equity investments and acquisitions
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In 2014, we also invested $0.2&nbsp;billion on the acquisition of four Ontario solar facilities and $0.1&nbsp;billion in Bruce Power for
	capital projects. We expect to
	spend approximately $0.2&nbsp;billion on Bruce Power investments in&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	UNDERSTANDING THE ENERGY BUSINESS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our Energy business is made up of three groups:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Canadian
	Power
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Natural
	Gas Storage
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Energy comparable EBIT&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;contribution by group, excluding business development expenses
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>

</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Power
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Western Power
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own or have the rights to
	approximately 2,600&nbsp;MW of power supply in Alberta and Arizona through three long-term PPAs, five natural gas-fired cogeneration facilities,
	and through Coolidge, a simple-cycle, natural gas peaking facility in&nbsp;Arizona.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Power
	purchased under long-term contracts is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	Power purchased under a 20-year PPA
<BR>
	(own&nbsp;50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent through the ASTC Power Partnership)
</FONT>
</TD>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada

<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;75
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=131,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=11652,FOLIO='75',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_76">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Power sold under long-term contracts is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="17%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Coolidge
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="37%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Power sold under a 20-year PPA
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="26%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Salt River Project Agricultural Improvements&nbsp;&amp; Power District
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2031
</FONT>
</TD>

<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Earnings in the Western Power business are maximized by maintaining and optimizing the operations of our power plants, and through various marketing activities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A
	disciplined operational strategy is critical to maximizing output and revenue at our cogeneration facilities and maximizing Coolidge earnings, where revenue is based on plant availability, and is
	not a function of market&nbsp;price.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	marketing function is critical for optimizing returns and managing risk through direct sales to medium and large industrial and commercial companies and other market participants. Our marketing
	group sells power sourced through the PPAs, markets uncommitted volumes from the cogeneration plants, and buys and sells power and natural gas to maximize earnings from our
	assets. To reduce exposure associated with uncontracted volumes, we sell a portion of our power in forward sales markets when acceptable contract terms are&nbsp;available.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A
	portion of our power is retained to be sold in the spot market or under shorter-term forward arrangements. This ensures we have adequate power supply to fulfill our sales obligations if we have
	unexpected plant outages and provides the opportunity to increase earnings in periods of high spot&nbsp;prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	amount sold forward will vary depending on market conditions and market liquidity and has historically ranged between 25 to 75&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of expected future production with a higher
	proportion being hedged in the near term periods. Such forward sales may be completed with medium to large industrial and commercial companies as well as other market participants and will affect our
	average realized price (versus spot price) in future&nbsp;periods.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Eastern Power
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own or are developing
	approximately 3,000&nbsp;MW of power generation capacity in eastern Canada. All of the power produced by these assets is sold under long-term
	contracts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Disciplined
	maintenance of plant operations is critical to the results of our Eastern Power assets, where earnings are based on plant availability and performance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Assets
	currently operating under long-term contracts are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>

	generation has been suspended since 2008. We continue to receive capacity payments while generation is&nbsp;suspended.

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	realized and unrealized gains and losses from financial derivatives used to manage Canadian Power's assets are presented on a net basis in Western and Eastern Power
	revenues. The unrealized gains and losses from financial derivatives included in Revenue are excluded to arrive at Comparable EBITDA.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	four solar facilities acquired between June and December&nbsp;2013, three solar facilities acquired in September&nbsp;2014, one solar facility acquired in
	December&nbsp;2014 and Cartier Wind phase two of Gros-Morne completed in November&nbsp;2012.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	Revenue from the sale of unused natural gas transportation, sale of excess natural gas purchased for generation and Cancarb sales of thermal carbon black up to
	April&nbsp;15, 2014 when it was&nbsp;sold.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	our share of equity income from our investments in ASTC Power Partnership, which holds the Sundance B PPA, and Portlands Energy. Equity income does not include
	any earnings related to our risk management activities.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

	Management's discussion and analysis

	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;77

<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_78">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Sales volumes and plant availability
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Includes our share of volumes from our equity investments.
</FONT>
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="72%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=3 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	year ended December&nbsp;31
</B>

<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	96%
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	95%
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	96%
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<FONT SIZE=2>
	Eastern Power
<SUP>
	1,5
</SUP>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	four solar facilities acquired between June and December&nbsp;2013, three solar facilities acquired in September&nbsp;2014, and one solar facility acquired in
	December&nbsp;2014 and Cartier Wind phase two of Gros-Morne completed in November&nbsp;2012.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	our 50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent ownership interest of Sundance B volumes through the ASTC Power Partnership. Sundance A Unit 1&nbsp;returned to service in
	September&nbsp;2013 and Unit 2&nbsp;returned to service in October&nbsp;2013.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	percentage of time in a period that the plant is available to generate power, regardless of whether it is&nbsp;running.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Does
	not include facilities that provide power to us under PPAs.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	5
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Does
	not include B&eacute;cancour because power generation has been suspended since&nbsp;2008.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Western Power
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Western Power's comparable EBITDA in 2014 was
	$103&nbsp;million lower than in 2013, due to the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	realized power prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	incremental
	earnings from the return to service of the Sundance A PPA Unit 1&nbsp;in September&nbsp;2013 and Unit 2&nbsp;in October&nbsp;2013 which also resulted in
	increased volume purchases
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	sale
	of Cancarb in April&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Average
	spot market power prices in Alberta decreased by 38% from approximately $80/MWh in 2013 to approximately $50/MWh in 2014. Despite strong power demand growth of just over three per&nbsp;cent,
	ten of the twelve months of 2014 saw relatively soft price levels as the Alberta power market was well supplied during the year. Weather events in February&nbsp;2014 and July&nbsp;2014 tightened
	the supply demand balance resulting in strong prices during those months. Realized power prices on power sales can be higher or lower than spot market power prices in any given period as a result of
	contracting activities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, Western Power's comparable EBITDA was $44&nbsp;million higher than 2012. The increase was mainly due to higher purchased volumes under the PPAs following the return to service of Sundance A
	Units 1 and&nbsp;2.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Approximately
	75&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of Western Power sales volumes were sold under contract in 2014 compared to 72&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent in 2013 and 85&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent in&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	78&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=134,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=626893,FOLIO='78',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_79">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Eastern Power
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Eastern Power's comparable EBITDA
	in 2014 was $28&nbsp;million higher than 2013 due to the net effect&nbsp;of incremental earnings from the four solar facilities acquired
	in 2013, the additional four facilities acquired in late 2014 and higher contractual earnings at&nbsp;B&eacute;cancour.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, Eastern Power's comparable EBITDA was similar to 2012 due to the net effect of incremental earnings from Cartier Wind and from the four solar facilities acquired in 2013 and lower contractual
	earnings at&nbsp;B&eacute;cancour.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bruce Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Bruce Power is a nuclear power generation facility located near Tiverton, Ontario and is comprised of Bruce A and Bruce B. Bruce A Units 1 to 4&nbsp;have a combined
	capacity
	of approximately 3,000&nbsp;MW and Bruce B Units 5 to 8&nbsp;have a combined capacity of approximately 3,300&nbsp;MW. Bruce B leases the eight nuclear reactors from Ontario Power Generation and
	subleases Units 1 to 4 to Bruce&nbsp;A.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Results
	from Bruce Power fluctuate primarily due to the frequency, scope and duration of planned and unplanned outages.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under
	a contract with the IESO, all of the output from Bruce A is sold at a fixed price/MWh which is adjusted annually on April&nbsp;1 for inflation and other provisions under the contract. Bruce A
	also recovers fuel costs from the&nbsp;IESO.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="71%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</TD>
</TR>

</B>

</FONT>

	Per MWh
</B>
</FONT>

</TR>

</FONT>

</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under the same contract, all output from Bruce B Units 5 to 8&nbsp;is subject to a floor price adjusted annually for inflation on April&nbsp;1.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="71%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>

</TD>
</TR>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="86%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_92"></A>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bruce B floor price
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Per MWh
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="86%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	April&nbsp;1, 2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;March&nbsp;31, 2015
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$52.86
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="86%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	April&nbsp;1, 2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;March&nbsp;31, 2014
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$52.34
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="86%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	April&nbsp;1, 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;March&nbsp;31, 2013
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$51.62
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Amounts received under the Bruce B floor price mechanism within a calendar year are subject to repayment if the average spot price in a month exceeds the floor
	price. The first quarter 2014 average spot price exceeded the floor price; however, spot prices fell below the floor price for the remainder of 2014. As a result, Bruce B recognized annual revenues at
	the floor price throughout 2014 and amounts received above the floor price in first quarter 2014 were repaid to the IESO in January&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Bruce
	B also enters into fixed-price contracts under which it receives or pays the difference between the contract price and the spot&nbsp;price.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	contract also provides for payment if the IESO reduces Bruce Power's generation to balance the supply of and demand for electricity and/or manage other operating conditions of the Ontario power
	grid. The amount of the reduction is considered "deemed generation", for which Bruce Power is paid the fixed price, floor price or spot price as applicable under the&nbsp;contract.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;79
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	Bruce B
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
