<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Represents
	our 48.9&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent ownership interest in Bruce A and 31.6&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent ownership interest in Bruce B. Sales volumes include deemed
	generation.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	percentage of time in a year the plant is available to generate power, regardless of whether it is&nbsp;running.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Plant
	availability and sales volumes include the incremental impact of Unit 1 and Unit 2&nbsp;which were returned to service in October&nbsp;2012.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Calculation
	based on actual and deemed generation. Bruce B realized sales prices per MWh includes revenues under the floor price mechanism and revenues from contract
	settlements.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Equity income from Bruce A in 2014 was $7&nbsp;million higher than 2013. The increase was mainly due to lower depreciation and operating expenses and higher
	volumes partially offset by recognition of an insurance recovery of approximately $40&nbsp;million in the first quarter 2013. The negative impact of increased outage days in 2014 is offset by higher
	generation levels while operating.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Equity
	income from Bruce B in 2014 was $3&nbsp;million lower than 2013. The decrease was mainly due to higher lease expense recognized based on the terms of the lease agreement with Ontario Power
	Generation, partially offset by higher volumes and lower operating costs resulting from lower outage&nbsp;days.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	80&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=136,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=159022,FOLIO='80',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_81">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, equity income from Bruce A was $351&nbsp;million higher than 2012. The increase was mainly due&nbsp;to:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	incremental
	earnings from Units 1 and 2&nbsp;which returned to service in October&nbsp;2012
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	incremental earnings from Unit 3&nbsp;due to the West Shift Plus planned outage during first and second quarter&nbsp;2012
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	recognition
	in first quarter 2013 of an insurance recovery of approximately $40&nbsp;million related to the May&nbsp;2012 Unit 2&nbsp;electrical generator failure that
	impacted Bruce A in 2012 and&nbsp;2013
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	incremental earnings from Unit 4&nbsp;due to the planned life extension outage which began in third quarter 2012 and was completed in April&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, equity income from Bruce B was $55&nbsp;million lower than 2012. The decrease was mainly due to lower volumes and higher operating costs resulting from higher planned outage&nbsp;days.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own approximately 3,800&nbsp;MW of power generation capacity in New&nbsp;York and New&nbsp;England, including plants powered by natural gas, oil, hydro
	and&nbsp;wind.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	earn revenues in both New&nbsp;York and New&nbsp;England in two ways&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;by providing capacity and by selling energy. Capacity markets compensate power
	suppliers for being available to provide power, and are intended to promote investment in new and existing power resources needed to meet customer demand and maintain a reliable power system. The
	energy markets compensate power providers for the actual energy they&nbsp;supply.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Providing capacity
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Capacity revenues in
	New&nbsp;York and New&nbsp;England are a function of two factors&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;capacity prices and plant availability. It is
	important for us to keep our plant availability high to maximize the amount of capacity for which we get&nbsp;paid.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Capacity
	prices paid to capacity suppliers in New&nbsp;York are determined by a series of voluntary forward auctions and a mandatory spot auction. The forward auctions are bid based while the
	mandatory spot auction is affected by a demand curve price setting process that is driven by a number of established parameters that are subject to periodic review by the New&nbsp;York ISO and FERC.
	The parameters are determined for each zone and include the forecasted cost of a new unit entering the market, available existing operable supply and fluctuations in the forecasted demand.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	price paid for capacity in the New&nbsp;England Power Pool is determined by annual competitive auctions which are held three years in advance of the applicable capacity year. Auction results are
	impacted by actual and projected power demand, power supply, and other&nbsp;factors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Selling energy
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We focus on selling power
	under short and long-term contracts to wholesale, commercial and industrial customers in the following power&nbsp;markets:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	New&nbsp;York,
	operated by the New&nbsp;York ISO
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	New&nbsp;England,
	operated by the New&nbsp;England ISO
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	PJM
	Interconnection area (PJM).
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	also earn additional revenues by bundling power sales with other energy services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	meet our power sales commitments using power we generate ourselves or with power we buy at fixed prices, reducing our exposure to changes in commodity prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;81
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

<TD WIDTH="61%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Capacity
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;

</TD>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	realized and unrealized gains and losses from financial derivatives used to manage U.S.&nbsp;Power's assets are presented on a net basis in power revenues. The
	unrealized gains and losses from financial derivatives included in Revenue are excluded to arrive at Comparable EBITDA.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	the costs of fuel consumed in generation.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power's comparable EBITDA in 2014 was US$53&nbsp;million higher than 2013. This reflected the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	realized capacity prices primarily in New&nbsp;York
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	realized power prices for the New&nbsp;England and New&nbsp;York facilities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	generation volumes primarily at the Ravenswood facility
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	prices and related costs on increased volumes purchased to fulfill power sales commitments to wholesale, commercial and industrial customers.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, U.S.&nbsp;Power's comparable EBITDA was US$114&nbsp;million higher than 2012. This reflected the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	realized capacity prices in New&nbsp;York
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	realized power prices partially offset by the impact of higher fuel&nbsp;costs
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	revenues and certain adjustments on sales to wholesale, commercial and industrial customers.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	82&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=138,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=915460,FOLIO='82',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_83">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Average
	New&nbsp;York Zone J spot capacity prices were approximately 27&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent higher in 2014 than in 2013. The increase in spot prices and the impact of hedging activities resulted
	in higher realized capacity prices in New&nbsp;York in&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Wholesale
	electricity prices in New&nbsp;York and New&nbsp;England were higher in 2014 compared to 2013 primarily due to colder winter temperatures and gas transmission constraints. This resulted
	in higher natural gas prices in the predominantly gas-fired New&nbsp;England and New&nbsp;York power markets in first quarter 2014 compared to the same period in 2013. Average spot power prices in
	2014 in New&nbsp;England increased approximately 14&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and in New&nbsp;York spot power prices increased approximately 11&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent compared to&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Physical
	sales volumes in 2014 rose compared to 2013. Generation volumes increased primarily due to higher generation at the Ravenswood facility throughout 2014 compared to 2013. Purchased volumes
	were also higher in 2014 compared to 2013 due to increased sales to commercial and industrial customers in both the New&nbsp;England and PJM&nbsp;markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	at December&nbsp;31, 2014, approximately 3,700&nbsp;GWh or 30&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of U.S.&nbsp;Power's planned generation is contracted for 2015, and 1,600&nbsp;GWh or
	14&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent for 2016. Planned generation fluctuates depending on hydrology, wind conditions, commodity prices and the resulting dispatch of the assets. Power sales fluctuate based on
	customer&nbsp;usage.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_97"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Natural Gas Storage
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own and operate 118&nbsp;Bcf of non-regulated natural gas storage capacity in Alberta. This business operates independently from our regulated natural gas
	transmission
	business and from ANR's regulated storage business, which are included in our Natural Gas Pipelines segment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>

	Storage capacity
</B>

<FONT SIZE=2>

<TD WIDTH="23%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>

<FONT SIZE=2>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	1,275
</FONT>
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We also hold a contract for Alberta-based storage capacity with a third party.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	natural gas storage business helps balance seasonal and short-term supply and demand, and adds flexibility to the delivery of natural gas to markets in Alberta and the rest of North America.
	Market volatility creates arbitrage opportunities and our natural gas storage facilities also give customers the ability to capture value from short-term price movements. The natural gas storage
	business
	is affected by the change in seasonal natural gas price spreads which are generally determined by the differential in natural gas prices between the traditional summer injection and winter withdrawal
	seasons.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	gas storage business contracts with third parties, typically participants in the Alberta and interconnected gas markets, for a fixed fee to provide gas storage services on a short, medium, and/or
	long term&nbsp;basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	also enter into proprietary natural gas storage transactions, which include a forward purchase of our own natural gas to be injected into storage and a simultaneous forward sale of natural gas for
	withdrawal at a later period, typically during the winter withdrawal season. By matching purchase and sales volumes on a back-to-back basis, we lock in future positive margins, effectively eliminating
	our exposure to changes in gas&nbsp;prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	These
	forward natural gas contracts provide highly effective economic hedges but do not meet the specific criteria for hedge accounting and, therefore, are recorded at their fair value through net
	income based on the forward market prices for the contracted month of delivery. We record changes in the fair value of these contracts in revenues. We do not include changes in the fair value of
	natural gas forward purchase and sales
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;83
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=139,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=296998,FOLIO='83',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_84">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	contracts
	when we calculate comparable earnings because they do not represent the amounts that will be realized on&nbsp;settlement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Natural Gas Storage and other results
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable EBITDA in 2014 was $19&nbsp;million lower than 2013, mainly due to decreased third party storage revenue as a result of lower
	realized natural gas storage
	price&nbsp;spreads.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, comparable EBITDA was $4&nbsp;million lower than 2012, mainly due to lower realized natural gas storage price spreads, partially offset by incremental earnings from CrossAlta resulting from
	the acquisition of the remaining 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in December&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	SIGNIFICANT EVENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Power
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Ontario Solar
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As part of a purchase agreement
	with Canadian Solar Solutions&nbsp;Inc. signed in 2011, we completed the acquisition of three Ontario solar facilities for $181&nbsp;million
	in September&nbsp;2014 and acquired a fourth facility for $60&nbsp;million in December&nbsp;2014. In 2013, we completed the acquisition of four solar facilities for $216&nbsp;million. Our
	total investment in the eight solar facilities is $457&nbsp;million. All power produced by the solar facilities is sold under 20-year FIT contracts with the&nbsp;IESO.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Napanee
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In January&nbsp;2015, we began
	construction activities of a 900&nbsp;MW natural gas-fired power plant at Ontario Power Generation's Lennox site in eastern Ontario in the
	town of Greater Napanee. We expect to invest approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion in the Napanee facility during construction and commercial operations are expected to begin in late 2017 or early 2018.
	Production from the facility is fully contracted with the&nbsp;IESO.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	B&eacute;cancour
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In May&nbsp;2014, Hydro-Qu&eacute;bec
	exercised its option in the amended suspension agreement to extend suspension of all electricity generation to the end of 2017,
	and requested further suspension of generation to the end of 2018. Under the December&nbsp;2013 amended suspension agreement, Hydro-Qu&eacute;bec has the option each year to further extend
	the suspension by an additional year (subject to certain conditions). We continue to receive capacity payments while generation is&nbsp;suspended.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Cancarb Limited and Cancarb Waste Heat Facility
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The sale of Cancarb Limited, a
	thermal carbon black facility, and its related power generation facility closed in April&nbsp;2014 for gross proceeds of $190&nbsp;million.
	We recognized a gain of $99&nbsp;million, net of tax, in second quarter&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bruce Power
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In March&nbsp;2014, Cameco
	Corporation sold its 31.6&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent limited partnership interest in Bruce B to BPC Generation Infrastructure Trust (BPC). We are
	considering our option to increase our Bruce B ownership percentage.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	New&nbsp;Canadian
	federal legislation is expected to come into force in 2015 respecting the determination of liability and compensation for a nuclear incident in Canada resulting in personal
	injuries and damages. This proposed legislation will replace existing legislation which currently provides that the licensed operator of a nuclear facility has absolute and exclusive liability and
	limits the liability to a maximum of $75&nbsp;million. The proposed new law is fundamentally consistent with the existing regime although the maximum liability will increase to $650&nbsp;million
	and increase in increments over three years to a maximum of $1&nbsp;billion. The operator will also be required to maintain financial assurances such as insurance in the amount of the maximum
	liability. Our indirect subsidiary owns one-third of the shares of Bruce Power&nbsp;Inc., the licensed operator of Bruce Power, and as such Bruce Power is subject to this liability in the event of
	an incident and the legislation's other requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	84&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=140,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=37579,FOLIO='84',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_85">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Ravenswood
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In late September&nbsp;2014, the
	972&nbsp;MW Unit 30&nbsp;at the Ravenswood Generating Station experienced an unplanned outage as a result of a problem with the generator
	associated with the high pressure turbine. Insurance is expected to cover the repair costs and lost revenues associated with the unplanned outage, which are yet to be finalized. As a result of the
	expected insurance recoveries, net of deductibles, the Unit 30&nbsp;unplanned outage is not expected to have a significant impact on our earnings although the recording of earnings may not coincide
	with lost revenues due to timing of the anticipated insurance proceeds. The unit is expected to be back in service in first half&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Natural Gas Storage
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Effective April&nbsp;30, 2014, we terminated a 38&nbsp;Bcf long-term natural gas storage contract in Alberta with Niska Gas Storage. The contract contained provisions allowing for possible early
	termination. As a result, we recorded an after tax charge of $32&nbsp;million in 2014. We have re-contracted for new natural gas storage services in Alberta with Niska Gas Storage starting
	May&nbsp;1, 2014 for a six-year period and a reduced average&nbsp;volume.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	BUSINESS RISKS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following are risks specific to our energy business. See page&nbsp;99 for information about general risks that affect the company as a whole,including other
	operational
	risks, health, safety and environment (HSE) risks, and financial risks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Fluctuating power and natural gas market prices
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Power and natural gas prices are affected by fluctuations in supply and demand, weather, and by general economic conditions. The
	power generation facilities in our Western
	Power operations in Alberta, and in our U.S.&nbsp;Power operations in New&nbsp;England and New&nbsp;York, are exposed to commodity price volatility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Earnings
	from these businesses are generally correlated to the prevailing power supply and demand conditions. In New&nbsp;England and New&nbsp;York, the price of natural gas also has a significant
	impact on power prices, as energy prices in these markets are usually set by gas-fired power supplies. Extended periods of low gas prices will generally exert downward pressure on power prices and
	therefore on earnings from our New&nbsp;England and New&nbsp;York facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	Coolidge Generating Station and our portfolio of assets in eastern Canada are fully contracted, and are therefore not subject to fluctuating commodity prices. As these contracts expire in the long
	term, it is uncertain if we will be able to re-contract on similar terms. Bruce Power's exposure to fluctuating power prices is discussed further&nbsp;below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	To
	mitigate the impact of power price volatility in Alberta and the U.S.&nbsp;northeast, we sell a portion of our supply under medium to long-term sales contracts where contract terms are
	acceptable. A portion of our power is retained to be sold in the spot market or under shorter-term forward arrangements to ensure we have adequate power supply to fulfill sales obligations if
	unexpected plant outages occur. This unsold supply is exposed to fluctuating power and natural gas market prices. As power sales contracts expire, new forward contracts are entered into at prevailing
	market&nbsp;prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under
	an agreement with the IESO, Bruce B volumes are subject to a floor price mechanism. When the spot market price is above the floor price, Bruce B's volumes are subject to spot price volatility.
	When spot prices are below the floor price, Bruce B receives the floor price for all of its output. Bruce B also enters into third party fixed-price contracts where it receives the difference between
	the contract price and spot price. All Bruce A output is sold into the Ontario wholesale power spot market under a fixed-price contract with the&nbsp;IESO.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	natural gas storage business is subject to fluctuating seasonal natural gas price spreads which are generally determined by the differential in natural gas prices between the traditional summer
	injection and winter withdrawal seasons.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;85
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=141,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=472312,FOLIO='85',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EC75607A.;36',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EC75607_1_86">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Power capacity payments
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A significant portion of revenues earned by Ravenswood and a portion of revenues earned by our power facilities in New&nbsp;England are driven by
	capacity payments.
	Fluctuations in capacity prices can have a material impact on these businesses, particularly in New&nbsp;York. New&nbsp;York capacity prices are determined by a series of voluntary forward
	auctions and a mandatory spot auction. The forward auctions are bid based while the mandatory spot auction is affected by a demand curve price setting process that is driven by a number of established
	parameters that are subject to periodic review by the New&nbsp;York ISO and FERC. These parameters are determined for each capacity zone and include the forecasted cost of a new unit entering the
	market, available existing operable supply and fluctuations in forecasted demand. Capacity payments are also a function of plant availability which is discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Plant availability
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Optimizing and maintaining plant availability is essential to the continued success of our Energy business. Unexpected outages or extended planned outages at our
	power plants
	can increase maintenance costs, lower plant output and sales revenue and lower capacity payments and margins. We may also have to buy power or natural gas on the spot market to meet our delivery
	obligations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	manage this risk by investing in a highly skilled workforce, operating prudently, running comprehensive, risk-based preventive maintenance programs and making effective capital investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	facilities we do not operate, our purchase agreements include a financial remedy if a plant owner does not deliver as agreed. The Sundance and Sheerness PPAs, for example, require the producers to
	pay us market-based penalties if they cannot supply the amount of power we have agreed to&nbsp;purchase.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Regulatory
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We operate in both regulated and deregulated power markets in both the United&nbsp;States and Canada. These markets are subject to various federal, state and provincial
	regulations in both countries. As power markets evolve across North America, there is the potential for regulatory bodies to implement new rules that could negatively affect us as a generator and
	marketer of electricity. These may be in the form of market rule changes, changes in the interpretation and application of market rules by regulators, price caps, emission controls, cost allocations
	to generators and out-of-market actions taken by others to build excess generation, all of which negatively affect the price of power or capacity, or both. In addition, our development projects rely
	on an orderly permitting process and any disruption to that process can have negative effects on project schedules and costs. We are an active participant in formal and informal regulatory proceedings
	and take legal action where&nbsp;required.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Weather
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Significant changes in temperature and other weather events have many effects on our business, ranging from the impact on demand, availability and commodity prices, to
	efficiency and output capability. Extreme temperature and weather can affect market demand for power and natural gas and can lead to significant price volatility. Extreme weather can also restrict the
	availability of natural gas and power if demand is higher than supply. Seasonal changes in temperature can reduce the efficiency of our natural gas-fired power plants, and the amount of power they
	produce. Variable wind speeds affect earnings from our wind assets, and sun-light hours and intensity affects earnings from our solar&nbsp;assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Hydrology
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our hydroelectric power generation facilities in the northeastern U.S.&nbsp;are subject to hydrology risks that can impact the volume of water available for generation at
	these facilities including weather changes and events, local river management and potential dam failures at these plants or upstream facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Competition
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We face various competitive forces that impact our existing assets and prospects for growth. For instance, our existing power plants in deregulated markets will
	compete over
	time with new power capacity. New supply could come in several forms including supply that employs more efficient power generation technologies, additional supply from regional power transmission
	interconnections and new supply in the form of distributed generation. We also face competition from other power companies in the greenfield power plant development arena.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	86&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable interest expense in 2014 was $214&nbsp;million higher than in 2013 due to the net effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	interest as a result of long term debt issues of:
<BR>
</FONT>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	US$1.25&nbsp;billion
	in February&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	US$1.25&nbsp;billion
	in October&nbsp;2013
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	US$500&nbsp;million
	in July&nbsp;2013
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$750&nbsp;million
	in July&nbsp;2013
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	US$500&nbsp;million
	in July&nbsp;2013 by TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	interest on account of Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated debt&nbsp;maturities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	foreign exchange on interest on U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated debt
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	carrying charges to shippers in 2014 on the positive TSA balance for Canadian Mainline
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	lower
	capitalized interest due to the completion of the Gulf Coast extension of the Keystone Pipeline System in first quarter 2014, partially offset by higher capitalized
	interest primarily for Keystone&nbsp;XL.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

	Coast&nbsp;extension.

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable interest income and other in 2014 was $70&nbsp;million higher than 2013. This was the net result&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	increased
	AFUDC related to our rate-regulated projects, including Energy East Pipeline and our Mexico pipelines,
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	offset
	by higher realized losses in 2014 compared to 2013 on derivatives used to manage our net exposure to foreign exchange rate fluctuations on
	U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated income
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	impact of a fluctuating U.S.&nbsp;dollar on the translation of foreign currency denominated working capital.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2013, comparable interest income and other was $44&nbsp;million lower than 2012. This decrease was mainly due to higher realized losses in 2013 compared to 2012 on derivatives used to manage our
	net exposure to foreign exchange rate fluctuations on U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated income and on translation of foreign denominated working capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable income tax expense increased $197&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to 2013 mainly because of higher pre-tax earnings in 2014, changes in the
	proportion of income earned between Canadian and foreign jurisdictions as well as higher flow-through taxes in 2014 on Canadian regulated pipelines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	income tax expense increased $185&nbsp;million in 2013 compared to 2012 because of higher pre-tax earnings in 2013 combined with changes in the proportion of income earned between
	Canadian and foreign&nbsp;jurisdictions.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net income attributable to non-controlling interests increased by $28&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to 2013 primarily due to the sale of a
	45&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in each of GTN and Bison to TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP in July&nbsp;2013 and the remaining 30&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of Bison in October&nbsp;2014. This was
	partially offset by the redemption of Series&nbsp;U preferred shares in October&nbsp;2013 and Series&nbsp;Y preferred shares in March&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net
	income attributable to non-controlling interest increased $7&nbsp;million in 2013 compared to 2012 primarily due to the sale of a 45&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in each of GTN and Bison to
	TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP in July&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Preferred
	share dividends increased by $23&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to 2013 due to the issuances of Series&nbsp;7 preferred shares in March&nbsp;2013 and Series&nbsp;9 preferred shares in
	January&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Preferred
	share dividends increased $19&nbsp;million in 2013 compared to 2012 due to the issuance of Series&nbsp;7 preferred shares in March&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=145,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=605124,FOLIO='89',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_90">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT COLOR="#0033E1" SIZE=4>
	Financial condition
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We strive to maintain strong financial capacity and flexibility in all parts of the economic cycle. We rely on our operating cash flow to sustain our business,
	pay dividends and fund a portion of our growth. In addition, we access capital markets to meet our financing needs, manage our capital structure and to preserve our credit&nbsp;ratings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	believe we have the financial capacity to fund our existing capital program through our predictable cash flow from our operations, access to capital markets, proceeds from the sale of natural gas
	pipeline assets to TC PipeLines,&nbsp;LP, cash on hand and substantial committed credit facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Balance sheet analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, assets increased by $5.0&nbsp;billion, liabilities increased by $4.5&nbsp;billion and equity rose by $0.5&nbsp;billion compared
	to
	December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/02/13/0001047469-15-000798_G222054.JPG" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="756" HEIGHT="516">
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	increase in assets was primarily due to increases in property, plant and equipment and intangible and other assets. Property, plant and equipment increased by $4.2&nbsp;billion primarily due to
	the completion of the Gulf Coast Extension of the Keystone Pipeline System, further investment in the NGTL System, investment in our Mexican pipelines projects, construction of the Houston Lateral and
	Tank Terminal and the expansion of our ANR pipeline. Intangible and other assets rose by $0.7&nbsp;billion primarily due to spending on our capital projects under development.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	90&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=146,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=283124,FOLIO='90',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_91">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	increase in liabilities was primarily due to an increase in long-term debt and notes payable used to fund our growth. In 2014, we issued $1.4&nbsp;billion and repaid $1.1&nbsp;billion of long
	term debt. The strengthening of the U.S.&nbsp;dollar also contributed a $1.6&nbsp;billion increase on translation of our U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated debt. In&nbsp;2014, notes payable
	increased by $0.6&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Total
	equity increased $0.5&nbsp;billion in 2014 mainly due to a $450&nbsp;million preferred share issuance in January&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated capital structure
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	at December&nbsp;31, 2014
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2015/02/13/0001047469-15-000798_G906039.JPG" ALT="LOGO" WIDTH="278" HEIGHT="169">
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Includes
	non-controlling interests in TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP and Portland
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Net
	of cash and excluding junior subordinated notes
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2014, we had unused capacity of $1.55&nbsp;billion, $2.0&nbsp;billion and US$2.75&nbsp;billion under our equity, Canadian debt
	and U.S.&nbsp;debt shelf prospectuses, respectively, to facilitate future access to the North American debt and equity&nbsp;markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	at December&nbsp;31, 2014, we were in compliance with all of our financial covenants. Provisions of various trust indentures and credit arrangements with certain of our subsidiaries can restrict
	those subsidiaries' ability to declare and pay dividends or make distributions under certain circumstances. If such restrictions apply, they may, in turn, have an impact on our ability to declare and
	pay dividends on our common and preferred shares. In the opinion of management, these provisions do not currently restrict or alter our ability to declare or pay dividends. These trust indentures and
	credit arrangements also require us to comply with various affirmative and negative covenants and maintain certain financial ratios.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We continue to fund our extensive capital program through cash flow from operations supplemented by capital market financing activities and the sale of our
	U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipeline assets to TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Liquidity
	will continue to be comprised of predictable cash flow generated from operations, committed credit facilities, our ability to access debt and equity markets in both Canada and the U.S.,
	additional drop downs of our U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipeline assets into TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP and cash on&nbsp;hand.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Funds generated from operations, a non-GAAP measure, helps us assess the cash generating ability of our operations excluding the timing effects of working
	capital changes. See page&nbsp;24 for more information about non-GAAP measures. The increase in 2014 compared to 2013 was driven by the increase in comparable earnings adjusted for the following
	non-cash items: increased deferred income tax expense and depreciation, higher equity AFUDC income and lower equity earnings. Funds generated from operations also reflected lower distributed earnings
	from equity investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, our current liabilities were higher than our current assets, leaving us with a working capital deficit of $4.0&nbsp;billion. This short-term deficiency was mainly due to
	the use of accounts payable, notes payable and the current portion of our long-term debt to fund our capital program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	This
	short-term deficiency is considered to be in the normal course of a growing business and is managed through:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	our
	ability to generate cash flow from operations
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	our
	access to capital markets
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	approximately
	$5&nbsp;billion of unutilized committed revolving bank lines.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our 2014 capital spending was incurred primarily for expanding our NGTL System, construction of our Mexican pipelines, construction of the Houston Lateral and
	Tank Terminal, development of our Energy East Pipeline and expansion of the ANR pipeline. Also included in investing activities in 2014 was the acquisition of an additional four solar facilities in
	Ontario, proceeds from the sale of Cancarb and its related power generation facilities and our contribution for the construction of Grand Rapids Pipeline.
</FONT>
</P>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(403)
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=7 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	92&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

	TransCanada

	Management's discussion and analysis

	2014

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="23%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_106"></A>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(millions of $)
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Preferred share issuance, redemption and
	conversion
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In January&nbsp;2014, we completed a public offering of 18&nbsp;million Series&nbsp;9 cumulative redeemable first preferred shares at $25 per share resulting in gross
	proceeds of $450&nbsp;million. Investors are entitled to receive fixed cumulative dividends at an annual rate of $1.0625 per share, payable quarterly. The dividend rate will reset on
	October&nbsp;30, 2019 and every five years thereafter to a yield per annum equal to the sum of the then five-year Government of Canada bond yield and 2.35&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent. The preferred
	shares are redeemable by us on or after October&nbsp;30, 2019 and on October&nbsp;30 of every fifth year thereafter at a price of $25 per share plus accrued and unpaid dividends. Investors will
	have the right to convert their shares into Series&nbsp;10 cumulative redeemable first preferred shares on October&nbsp;30, 2019 and on October&nbsp;30 of every fifth year thereafter. The
	holders of Series&nbsp;10 preferred shares will be entitled to receive quarterly floating rate cumulative dividends at an annualized rate equal to the sum of the then 90-day Government of Canada
	treasury bill rate and 2.35&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	March&nbsp;2014, we redeemed all four million Series&nbsp;Y preferred shares of TCPL at a price of $50 per share plus $0.2455 representing accrued and unpaid dividends. The total face value of
	the outstanding Series&nbsp;Y shares was $200&nbsp;million and they carried an aggregate of $11&nbsp;million in annualized dividends.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	December&nbsp;2014, Series&nbsp;1 shareholders elected to convert 12.5&nbsp;million of our 22&nbsp;million outstanding Series&nbsp;1 cumulative redeemable first preferred shares, on a
	one-for-one basis into Series&nbsp;2 floating-rate cumulative redeemable first preferred shares. The Series&nbsp;1 shares will yield an annual fixed dividend rate of 3.266&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent,
	paid on a quarterly basis, for the five-year period which began on December&nbsp;31, 2014. The Series&nbsp;2 shares will pay a floating quarterly dividend at an annualized rate equal to the sum of
	the 90-day Government of Canada treasury bill rate and 1.92&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent for the five-year period which began on December&nbsp;31, 2014. The floating quarterly dividend rate for the
	Series&nbsp;2 shares for the first quarterly floating
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;93
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=149,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=897346,FOLIO='93',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_94">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	rate
	period, commencing December&nbsp;31, 2014, is 2.815&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent per&nbsp;annum and will be reset each quarter going&nbsp;forward.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	net proceeds of the above debt and preferred share offerings were used for general corporate purposes and to reduce short-term indebtedness.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP at-the-market (ATM) equity issuance
	program
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In August&nbsp;2014, TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP initiated its at-the-market equity issuance program (ATM&nbsp;program) under which it is authorized to offer and sell
	common units having an aggregate offering price of up to US$200&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	From
	August until December&nbsp;31, 2014, 1.3&nbsp;million common units were issued under the ATM program generating net proceeds of approximately US$73&nbsp;million. Our ownership interest in
	TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP will decrease as a result of equity issuances under the ATM&nbsp;program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Credit facilities
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We have committed, revolving credit facilities to primarily support our commercial paper programs. The commercial paper programs, along with additional demand
	credit
	facilities, are used for general corporate purposes, including issuing letters of credit and providing additional liquidity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, we had $6.7&nbsp;billion (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6.2&nbsp;billion) in unsecured credit facilities, including:
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our contractual obligations include our long-term debt, operating leases, purchase obligations and other liabilities incurred in our business such as
	environmental liability funds and employee retirement and post-retirement benefit&nbsp;plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Long-term debt
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At the end of 2014, we had $25&nbsp;billion of long-term debt and $1.2&nbsp;billion of junior subordinated notes, compared to $22.9&nbsp;billion of long-term debt
	and
	$1.1&nbsp;billion of junior subordinated notes at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Total
	notes payable were $2.5&nbsp;billion at the end of 2014 compared to $1.8&nbsp;billion at the end of&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	attempt to spread out the maturity profile of our debt. The majority of our debt obligations mature beyond five years with an average term of 12&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, scheduled principal repayments and interest payments related to our long-term debt were as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_109"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>

</B>
</FONT>

<B>
	Principal repayments
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Payments due (by&nbsp;period)
</FONT>
</P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;95
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=151,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=838242,FOLIO='95',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_96">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Operating leases
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our operating leases for premises, services and equipment expire at different times between now and 2052. Some of our operating leases include the option to renew
	the agreement
	for one to five&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	commitments under the Alberta PPAs are considered operating leases and a portion of these PPAs have been subleased to third parties under similar terms and conditions. Fixed payments under these
	PPAs have been included in our summary of future obligations. Variable payments have been excluded as these payments are dependent upon plant availability and other factors. Our share of power
	purchased under the PPAs in 2014 was $391&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$242&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$238&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Purchase obligations
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We have purchase obligations that are transacted at market prices and in the normal course of business, including long-term natural gas transportation and
	purchase
	arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Capital
	expenditure commitments include obligations related to the construction of growth projects and are based on the projects proceeding as planned. Changes to these projects, including
	cancellation, would reduce or possibly eliminate these commitments as a result of cost mitigation efforts.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_110"></A>

	1

<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>

	2
</FONT>

</DT>

	Demand
	rates are subject to change. The contractual obligations in the table are based on demand volumes only and exclude commodity charges incurred when
	volumes&nbsp;flow.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">

	3

<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Amounts
	include capital expenditures and capital projects under development, are estimates and are subject to variability based on timing of construction and project
	enhancements.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>

	estimates of certain amounts which are subject to change depending on plant-fired hours, use of natural gas storage facilities, the consumer price index, actual
	plant maintenance costs, plant salaries as well as changes in regulated rates for transportation.

<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=152,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=560016,FOLIO='96',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_97">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Outlook
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are developing quality projects under our long-term $46&nbsp;billion capital program. These long-life infrastructure assets are supported by long-term commercial
	arrangements, and once completed, are expected to generate significant growth in earnings and cash&nbsp;flow.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	$46&nbsp;billion capital program is comprised of $12&nbsp;billion of small to medium-sized, shorter-term projects and $34&nbsp;billion of commercially secured large-scale,
	medium&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;and longer-term projects each of which are subject to key commercial or regulatory approvals. The portfolio is expected to be financed through our
	growing internally generated cash flow and a combination of funding options including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	senior
	debt
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	project
	financing
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	preferred
	shares
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	hybrid
	securities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	additional
	drop downs of our U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipeline assets to TC PipeLines,&nbsp;LP
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	asset
	sales
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	potential
	involvement of strategic or financial partners
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	portfolio
	management.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Additional
	financing alternatives available include common equity through DRP or, lastly, discrete equity issuances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	GUARANTEES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Bruce Power
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We and our partner, BPC, have each severally guaranteed some of Bruce B's contingent financial obligations related to power sales agreements, a lease agreement and
	contractor
	services. The Bruce B guarantees have terms to 2018 except for one guarantee with no termination date that has no exposure associated with&nbsp;it.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	and BPC have each severally guaranteed half of certain contingent financial obligations of Bruce A related to a sublease agreement, an agreement with the IESO to restart the Bruce A power
	generation units, and certain other financial obligations. The Bruce A guarantees have terms to&nbsp;2019.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, our share of the potential exposure under the Bruce A and B guarantees was estimated to be $634&nbsp;million. The carrying amount of these guarantees was estimated to be
	$6&nbsp;million. Our exposure under certain of these guarantees is&nbsp;unlimited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Other jointly owned entities
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We and our partners in certain other jointly owned entities have also guaranteed (jointly, severally, or jointly and severally) the financial
	performance of these entities
	relating mainly to redelivery of natural gas, PPA payments and the payment of liabilities. The guarantees have terms ranging to&nbsp;2040.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	share of the potential exposure under these assurances was estimated at December&nbsp;31, 2014 to be a maximum of $104&nbsp;million. The carrying amount of these guarantees was
	$14&nbsp;million, and is included in other long-term liabilities. In some cases, if we make a payment that exceeds our ownership interest, the additional amount must be reimbursed by
	our&nbsp;partners.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;97
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=153,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=975324,FOLIO='97',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EG75607A.;29',USER='DCOMBA',CD='13-FEB-2015;09:21' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EG75607_1_98">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	OBLIGATIONS&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;PENSION AND OTHER POST-RETIREMENT
	PLANS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In 2015, we expect to make funding contributions of approximately $70&nbsp;million for the defined benefit pension plans, approximately $7&nbsp;million for the other
	post-retirement benefit plans and approximately $36&nbsp;million for the savings plan and defined contribution pension plans. In addition, the Company expects to provide a $35&nbsp;million letter
	of credit to the Canadian DB Plan for the funding of solvency requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2014, we made funding contributions of $73&nbsp;million to our defined benefit pension plans, $6&nbsp;million for the other post-retirement benefit plans and $37&nbsp;million for the savings
	plan and defined contribution pension plans. We also provided a $47&nbsp;million letter of credit to a defined benefit plan in lieu of cash&nbsp;funding.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Outlook
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The next actuarial valuation for our pension and other post-retirement benefit plans will be carried out as at January&nbsp;1, 2015. Based on current market conditions, we
	expect funding requirements for these plans to approximate 2014 levels for several years. This will allow us to amortize solvency deficiencies in the plans, in addition to normal funding&nbsp;costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	net benefit cost for our defined benefit and other post-retirement plans decreased to $115&nbsp;million in 2014 from $134&nbsp;million, mainly due to a higher discount rate used to measure the
	benefit obligation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Future
	net benefit costs and the amount we will need to contribute to fund our plans will depend on a range of factors, including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	interest
	rates
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	actual
	returns on plan assets
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	changes
	to actuarial assumptions and plan design
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	actual
	plan experience versus projections
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	amendments
	to pension plan regulations and legislation.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	do not expect future increases in the level of funding needed to maintain our plans to have a material impact on our&nbsp;liquidity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	98&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT COLOR="#0033E1" SIZE=4>
	Other information
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	RISKS AND RISK MANAGEMENT
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following is a summary of general risks that affect our company. You can find risks specific to each operating business segment in the business
	segment discussions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Risk
	management is integral to the successful operation of our business. Our strategy is to ensure that our risks and related exposures are in line with our business objectives and
	risk&nbsp;tolerance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	build risk assessment into our decision-making processes at all levels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Board's Governance Committee oversees our risk management activities, which includes ensuring that there are appropriate management systems in place to manage our risks, and adequate Board
	oversight of our risk management policies, programs and practices. Other Board committees oversee specific types of risk: the Audit Committee oversees management's role in monitoring financial risk,
	the Human Resources Committee oversees executive resourcing and compensation, organizational capabilities and compensation risk, and the Health, Safety and Environment Committee oversees operational,
	safety and environmental risk through regular reporting from management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	executive leadership team is accountable for developing and implementing risk management plans and actions, and effective risk management is reflected in their compensation.
</FONT>
</P>

<B>
	Monitoring and Mitigation
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Business interruption
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Operational risks, including labour disputes, equipment malfunctions or breakdowns, acts of terror, or natural disasters and other catastrophic events.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	Decrease in revenues, increase in operating costs or legal proceedings or other expenses all of which could reduce our earnings. Losses not covered by insurance could have an adverse effect on operations, cash flow and financial position.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	We have incident, emergency and crisis management systems to ensure an effective response to minimize further loss or injuries and to enhance our ability to resume operations. We also have a Business Continuity Program that determines critical
	business processes and develops resumption plans to ensure process continuity. We have comprehensive insurance to mitigate certain of these risks, but insurance does not cover all events in all circumstances.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Reputation and relationships
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our reputation and relationship with our stakeholders, such as Aboriginal communities, other communities, landowners, governments and government agencies, and environmental non-governmental organizations is very
	important.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	These stakeholders can have a significant impact on our operations, infrastructure development and overall reputation.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	Our Stakeholder Engagement Framework is our formal commitment to stakeholder engagement. Our four core values&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;integrity, collaboration, responsibility and innovation&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;are at the heart of our commitment to stakeholder
	engagement, and guide us in our interactions with stakeholders.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Execution and capital costs
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Investing in large infrastructure projects involves substantial capital commitments and associated execution risks based on the assumption that these assets will deliver an attractive return on investment in the
	future.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	While we carefully consider the expected cost of our capital projects, under some contracts we bear capital cost overrun risk which may decrease our return on these projects.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	Under some contracts, we share the cost of execution risks with customers, in exchange for the potential benefit they will realize when the project is finished.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>

</TD>
