<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Cyber security
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We rely on our information technology to process, transmit and store electronic information, including information we use to safely operate our assets.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	A breach in the security of our information technology could expose our business to a risk of loss, misuse or interruption of critical information and functions. This could affect our operations, damage our assets, result in safety incidents, damage
	to the environment, reputational harm, competitive disadvantage, regulatory enforcement actions and potential litigation, which could have a material adverse effect on our operations, financial position and results of operations.
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
	We have a comprehensive cyber security strategy which aligns with industry and recognized standards for cyber security. This strategy includes cyber security risk assessments, continuous monitoring of networks and other information sources for
	threats to the organization, comprehensive incident response plans/processes and a cyber security awareness program for employees.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Pipeline abandonment costs
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The NEB's Land Matters Consultation Initiative
	(LMCI) is an initiative that requires all Canadian pipeline companies regulated by the NEB to set aside funds to cover future
	pipeline abandonment costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	NEB provided several key guiding principles under this initiative, including the position that abandonment costs are a legitimate cost of providing pipeline service and are recoverable, upon NEB
	approval, from users of the individual pipeline systems. Pipeline companies are responsible for managing the collection and investment of funds to cover future abandonment costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All
	hearings have been completed and Board decisions have been received, with the final decision in December&nbsp;2014, providing approval to begin collection through an abandonment surcharge in
	January&nbsp;2015. Collection of funds will be held in trusts which will serve to hold and invest funds collected to cover future abandonment costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Health, safety and environment
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Health, Safety and
	Environment committee of TransCanada's Board of Directors (the&nbsp;Board) monitors compliance with our HSE corporate commitment statement through
	regular reporting from management. We have an integrated HSE Management System that is used to capture, organize and document our related policies, programs and&nbsp;procedures.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	HSE Management System is modeled after international standards, conforms to external industry consensus standards and voluntary programs, and complies with applicable legislative requirements and
	various other internal management systems. It follows a continuous improvement cycle.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	committee reviews HSE performance and operational risk management on a quarterly basis. It receives detailed reports on:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	overall
	HSE corporate governance
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	operational
	performance and preventive maintenance metrics
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	asset
	integrity programs
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	emergency
	preparedness, incident response and evaluation
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	people
	and process safety performance metrics
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	developments
	in and compliance with applicable legislation and regulations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	committee also receives updates on any specific areas of operational and construction risk management review being conducted by management and the results and corrective action plans emanating
	from internal and third&nbsp;party audits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	safety and integrity of our existing and newly-developed infrastructure is a top priority. All assets are designed, constructed and commissioned with full consideration given to safety and
	integrity, and are brought in service only after all necessary requirements have been satisfied. In 2014, we spent $550&nbsp;million for pipeline integrity on the natural gas and liquids pipelines
	we operate, an increase of $174&nbsp;million over 2013 primarily
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	100&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=156,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=815300,FOLIO='100',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_101">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	due
	to increased levels of in-line pipeline inspections and related maintenance projects on all systems as well an increased amount of pipe replacement required due to population encroachment on the
	pipelines. Under the approved regulatory models in Canada, non-capital pipeline integrity expenditures on NEB-regulated pipelines are generally treated on a flow-through basis and, as a result, these
	expenditures have minimal impact on our earnings. Under the Keystone contracts, pipeline integrity expenditures are recovered through the tolling mechanism and, as a result, these expenditures
	generally have no impact on our earnings. Our safety record in 2014 continued to meet or exceed industry benchmarks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	Energy operations spending associated with process safety and our various integrity programs is used to minimize risk to employees and the public, process equipment, the surrounding environment,
	and to prevent disruptions to serving the electrical needs of our customers, within the footprint of each&nbsp;facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Spending
	associated with public safety on Energy assets is focused primarily on our hydro dams and associated equipment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	main environmental risks are:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	air
	and GHG emissions
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	product
	releases, including crude oil and natural gas, into the environment (land, water and&nbsp;air)
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	use,
	storage and disposal of chemicals and hazardous materials
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	compliance
	with corporate and regulatory policies and requirements and new regulations.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	described in the Business interruption section, above, we have a set of procedures in place to manage our response to natural disasters which include catastrophic events such as forest fires,
	tornadoes, earthquakes, floods, volcanic eruptions and hurricanes. The procedures, which are included in our Incident Management Program, are designed to help protect the health and safety of our
	employees, minimize risk to the public and limit any operational impacts caused by a natural disaster on the environment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Environmental compliance and liabilities
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our facilities are subject to
	federal, state, provincial and local environmental statutes and regulations governing environmental protection, including air and GHG emissions,
	water quality, wastewater discharges and waste management. Our facilities are required to obtain and comply with a wide variety of environmental registrations, licenses, permits and other approvals
	and requirements. Failure to comply could result in administrative, civil or criminal penalties, remedial requirements or orders affecting future operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	continually monitor our facilities to ensure compliance with all environmental requirements. We routinely monitor proposed changes in environmental policy, legislation and regulation, and where the
	risks are potentially large or uncertain, we comment on proposals independently or through industry associations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	are not aware of any material outstanding orders, claims or lawsuits against us related to releasing or discharging any material into the environment or in connection with environmental protection.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Compliance
	obligations can result in significant costs associated with installing and maintaining pollution controls, fines and penalties resulting from any failure to comply, and potential
	limitations on&nbsp;operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Remediation
	obligations can result in significant costs associated with the investigation and remediation of contaminated properties, and with damage claims arising from the contamination
	of&nbsp;properties.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	It
	is not possible to estimate the amount and timing of all our future expenditures related to environmental matters because:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	environmental
	laws and regulations (and&nbsp;interpretation and enforcement of them) can&nbsp;change
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	new
	claims can be brought against our existing or discontinued assets
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	our
	pollution control and clean up cost estimates may change, especially when our current estimates are based on preliminary site investigation or&nbsp;agreements
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	we
	may find new contaminated sites, or what we know about existing sites could&nbsp;change
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;101
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=157,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=566694,FOLIO='101',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_102">
</A>
<UL>
<BR>
</UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	where
	there is potentially more than one responsible party involved in litigation, we cannot estimate our joint and several liability with&nbsp;certainty.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, we had accrued approximately $30&nbsp;million related to these obligations ($32&nbsp;million at the end of 2013). This represents the amount that we have estimated
	that we will need to manage our currently known environmental liabilities. We believe that we have considered all necessary contingencies and established appropriate reserves for environmental
	liabilities; however, there is the risk that unforeseen matters may arise requiring us to set aside additional amounts. We adjust this reserve quarterly to account for changes in&nbsp;liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Greenhouse gas emissions regulation risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We own assets and have business
	interests in a number of regions where there are regulations to address industrial GHG emissions. We have procedures in place to comply with
	these regulations, including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	under
	the Specified Gas Emitters Regulation in Alberta, established industrial facilities with GHG emissions above a certain threshold have had to reduce their emissions by
	12&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent below an average intensity baseline since 2007. Our NGTL System facilities, Sundance and Sheerness are subject to this regulation. We recover compliance costs on the NGTL
	System through the tolls our customers pay. A portion of the compliance costs for Sundance and Sheerness are recovered through market pricing and contract flow through provisions. We recorded
	$38&nbsp;million for the Alberta Specified Gas Emitters Regulation in 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$25&nbsp;million)
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	B.C.
	has imposed a tax on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from fossil fuel combustion since 2008. We recover the compliance costs for our compressor and meter stations
	through the tolls our customers pay. In 2014, we recorded $6&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6&nbsp;million) for the B.C. carbon&nbsp;tax
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	northeastern
	U.S.&nbsp;states that are members of the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) implemented a CO2&nbsp;cap-and-trade program for electricity generators
	beginning January&nbsp;2009. This program applies to both the Ravenswood and Ocean State Power generation facilities. We recorded $9&nbsp;million in 2014
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6&nbsp;million) to participate in quarterly auctions of allowances under&nbsp;RGGI
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Qu&eacute;bec's
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Regulation Respecting a Cap-and-Trade System for Greenhouse Gas Emission Allowances
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	came into force
	in December&nbsp;2011 with significant amendments finalized in December&nbsp;2012. Beginning in January&nbsp;2013, B&eacute;cancour was required to cover its GHG emissions. As per the
	regulations, the government awarded free emission units for the majority of B&eacute;cancour's compliance requirements for 2013 and 2014. The remaining requirements were purchased through
	auctions. The cost of these emissions units is recovered through commercial contracts.The pipeline facilities in Qu&eacute;bec are also covered under this regulation and have purchased
	compliance instruments. We recorded approximately $1&nbsp;million for compliance with this regulation in 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;less than $1&nbsp;million)
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	in
	2013, California implemented a cap and trade program that impacts electricity importers as well as a number of industrial emitters of GHG emissions. Our costs associated
	with the program were less than $1&nbsp;million in 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;less than $1&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	There
	are federal, regional, state and provincial initiatives currently in development. While economic events may continue to affect the scope and timing of new regulations, we anticipate that most of
	our facilities will be subject to future regulations to manage industrial GHG&nbsp;emissions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Financial risks
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are exposed to market risk, counterparty credit risk and liquidity risk, and have strategies, policies and limits in place to mitigate their impact on our
	earnings, cash
	flow and, ultimately, shareholder value.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	These
	strategies, policies and limits are designed to ensure our risks and related exposures are in line with our business objectives and risk tolerance. We manage market risk and counterparty credit
	risk within limits that are ultimately established by the Board, implemented by senior management and monitored by our risk management and internal audit groups. Management monitors compliance with
	market and counterparty risk management policies and procedures, and reviews the adequacy of the risk management framework, overseen by the Audit Committee. Our internal audit group assists the Audit
	Committee by carrying out regular and ad-hoc reviews of risk management controls and procedures, and reporting up to the Audit Committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	102&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=158,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=749629,FOLIO='102',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_103">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Market risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We build and invest in energy
	infrastructure projects, buy and sell energy commodities, issue short-term and long-term debt (including amounts in foreign currencies) and invest
	in foreign operations. Certain of these activities expose us to market risk from changes in commodity prices and foreign exchange and interest rates which may affect our earnings and the value of the
	financial instruments we&nbsp;hold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	use derivative contracts to assist in managing our exposure to market risk, including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	forwards
	and futures contracts&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;agreements to buy or sell a financial instrument or commodity at a specified price and date in the
	future. We use foreign exchange and commodity forwards and futures to manage the impact of changes in foreign exchange rates and commodity prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	swaps&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;agreements
	between two parties to exchange streams of payments over time according to specified terms. We use interest rate,
	cross-currency and commodity swaps to manage the impact of changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	options&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;agreements
	that give the purchaser the right (but&nbsp;not the obligation) to buy or sell a specific amount of a financial
	instrument or commodity at a fixed price, either at a fixed date or at any time within a specified period. We use option agreements to manage the impact of changes in interest rates, foreign exchange
	rates and commodity prices.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	assess contracts we use to manage market risk to determine whether all, or a portion of it, meets the definition of a&nbsp;derivative.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Commodity price risk
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are exposed to changes
	in commodity prices, especially electricity and natural gas, which may affect our earnings. We use several strategies to reduce this exposure,
	including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	committing
	a portion of expected power supply to fixed price sales contracts of varying terms while reserving a portion of our unsold power supply to mitigate operational
	and price risk in our asset&nbsp;portfolio
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	purchasing
	a portion of the natural gas we need to fuel our natural gas-fired power plants in advance or entering into contracts that base the sale price of our electricity
	on the cost of the natural gas, effectively locking in a&nbsp;margin
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	meeting
	our power sales commitments using power we generate ourselves or with power we buy at fixed prices, reducing our exposure to changes in commodity prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	using
	derivative instruments to enter into offsetting or back-to-back positions to manage commodity price risk created by certain fixed and variable prices in arrangements
	for different pricing indices and delivery points.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Foreign exchange and interest rate risk
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Certain of our businesses
	generate income in U.S.&nbsp;dollars, but since we report in Canadian dollars, changes in the value of the U.S.&nbsp;dollar against the Canadian
	dollar can affect our net income. As our U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated operations continue to grow, this exposure increases. The majority of this risk is offset by interest expense on
	U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated debt and by using foreign exchange derivatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have floating interest rate debt which subjects us to interest rate cash flow risk. We manage this using a combination of interest rate swaps and&nbsp;options.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Average exchange rate&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;U.S.&nbsp;to Canadian
	dollars
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

	table below. Comparable EBIT is a non-GAAP measure. See page&nbsp;24 for more information.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We hedge our net investment in foreign operations (on&nbsp;an after-tax basis) with U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated debt, cross-currency interest rate swaps, foreign exchange forward
	contracts and foreign exchange options.
</FONT>
</P>

	Fair values equal carrying values.
<BR>

</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>

	2

</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Consolidated
	net income in 2014 included net realized gains of $21&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;gains of $29&nbsp;million) related to the
	interest component of cross-currency swap settlements.
</FONT>
</DD>

<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Counterparty credit risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We have exposure to counterparty credit risk in
	the following areas:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	accounts
	receivable
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	104&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=160,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=203774,FOLIO='104',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_105">
</A>
<UL>
<BR>
</UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	portfolio
	investments
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	fair value of derivative assets
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	cash
	and notes receivable.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	If
	a counterparty fails to meet its financial obligations to us according to the terms and conditions of the financial instrument, we could experience a financial loss. We manage our exposure to this
	potential loss using recognized credit management techniques, including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	dealing
	with creditworthy counterparties&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;a significant amount of our credit exposure is with investment grade counterparties or, if
	not, is generally partially supported by financial assurances from investment grade&nbsp;parties
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	setting
	limits on the amount we can transact with any one counterparty&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;we monitor and manage the concentration of risk exposure with
	any one counterparty, and reduce our exposure when we feel we need to and when it is allowed under the terms of our&nbsp;contracts
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	using
	contract netting arrangements and obtaining financial assurances, such as guarantees and letters of credit or cash, when we believe it is&nbsp;necessary.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	There
	is no guarantee that these techniques will protect us from material losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	review our accounts receivable regularly and record allowances for doubtful accounts using the specific identification method. We had no significant credit losses in 2014 and no significant amounts
	past due or impaired at year end. We had a credit risk concentration of $258&nbsp;million (US$222&nbsp;million) at December&nbsp;31, 2014 with one counterparty
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$240&nbsp;million (US$225&nbsp;million)). This amount is secured by a guarantee from the counterparty's parent company and we anticipate collecting
	the full&nbsp;amount.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have significant credit and performance exposure to financial institutions because they hold cash deposits and provide committed credit lines and letters of credit that help manage our exposure to
	counterparties and provide liquidity in commodity, foreign exchange and interest rate derivative markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Liquidity risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Liquidity risk is the risk that
	we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as they come due. We manage our liquidity by continuously forecasting our cash flow for a
	12&nbsp;month period and making sure we have adequate cash balances, cash flow from operations, committed and demand credit facilities and access to capital markets to meet our operating, financing
	and capital expenditure obligations under both normal and stressed economic conditions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	See
	page&nbsp;90 Financial condition for more information about our&nbsp;liquidity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Dealing with legal proceedings
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Legal proceedings, arbitrations
	and actions are part of doing business. While we cannot predict the final outcomes of proceedings and actions with certainty, management does
	not expect any current proceeding or action to have a material impact on our consolidated financial position, results of operations or liquidity. We are not aware of any potential legal proceeding or
	action that would have a material impact on our consolidated financial position, results of operations or&nbsp;liquidity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We meet Canadian and U.S.&nbsp;regulatory requirements for disclosure controls and procedures, internal control over financial reporting and related CEO and
	CFO
	certifications.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Disclosure controls and procedures
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We carried out an evaluation under the supervision and with the participation of management, including our President and CEO and our CFO, of the
	effectiveness of our disclosure
	controls and procedures as at December&nbsp;31, 2014 as required by the Canadian securities regulatory authorities and by the SEC. Based on this evaluation, our President and CEO and our CFO have
	concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures are effective in that they are designed to ensure that the information we are required to disclose in
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;105
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=161,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=134959,FOLIO='105',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_106">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	reports
	we file with or send to securities regulatory authorities is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified under Canadian and
	U.S.&nbsp;securities&nbsp;laws.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's annual report on internal control over financial
	reporting
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, which is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, our
	President and CEO and our CFO, and effected by our board of directors, management and other personnel, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the
	preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with&nbsp;GAAP.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under
	the supervision and with the participation of management, including our President and CEO and our CFO, an evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal control over financial reporting was
	conducted as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 based on the criteria described in "Internal Control&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Integrated Framework" issued in 2013 by the Committee of
	Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. Based on this assessment, management determined that, as of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the internal control over financial reporting
	was&nbsp;effective.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 has been audited by KPMG&nbsp;LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their attestation
	report which is included herein.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Changes in internal control over financial reporting
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Effective January&nbsp;1, 2014, management successfully implemented an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system, and made
	changes to certain related processes. As a result
	of the ERP system, certain processes supporting our internal control over financial reporting changed in&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Other
	than this ERP system implementation there has been no change in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the year covered by this annual report that has materially
	affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting. Although this implementation changed certain specific activities within the accounting function,
	it did not significantly affect the overall controls and procedures we follow in establishing internal controls over financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_GENERAL_DEVELOPMENT_OF_THE_COMPANY>
<EFX_CERTIFICATION>
<A NAME="FIS_CERTIFICATION"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	CEO AND CFO CERTIFICATIONS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our President and CEO and our CFO have attested to the quality of the public disclosure in our fiscal 2014 reports filed with Canadian securities
	regulators and the SEC, and
	have filed certifications with&nbsp;them.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING ESTIMATES
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	When we prepare financial statements that conform with GAAP, we are required to make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the timing and
	amount we record for our
	assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses because these items may be affected by future events. We base the estimates and assumptions on the most current information available, using our best
	judgment. We also regularly assess the assets and liabilities themselves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	following accounting estimates require us to make the most significant assumptions when preparing our financial statements and changes in these assumptions could have a material impact on the
	financial statements from those estimates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Rate-regulated accounting
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Under GAAP, an asset qualifies to use rate-regulated accounting (RRA) when it meets three&nbsp;criteria:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	regulator must establish or approve the rates for the regulated services or&nbsp;activities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	regulated rates must be designed to recover the cost of providing the services or&nbsp;products
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	it
	is reasonable to assume that rates set at levels to recover the cost can be charged to (and&nbsp;collected from) customers because of the demand for services or
	products and the level of direct and indirect competition.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	106&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=162,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=855457,FOLIO='106',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EI75607_1_107">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	believe that the regulated natural gas pipelines and certain liquids pipelines projects we account for using RRA meet these criteria. The most significant impact of using these principles is the
	timing of when we recognize certain expenses and revenues, which is based on the economic impact of the regulators' decisions about our revenues and tolls, and may be different from what would
	otherwise be expected under GAAP. Regulatory assets represent costs that are expected to be recovered in customer rates in future periods. Regulatory liabilities are amounts that are expected to be
	refunded through customer rates in future&nbsp;periods.
</FONT>
</P>

</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Regulatory assets and liabilities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="69%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=6 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=2 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	at December&nbsp;31&nbsp;
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(millions of $)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	2014
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	2013
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=6 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->

</TD>

</FONT>
</TD>

	263
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Impairment of long-lived assets and goodwill
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We review long-lived assets (such as plant, property and equipment) and intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in
	circumstances lead us to believe we might
	not be able to recover an asset's carrying value. If the total of the undiscounted future cash flows we estimate for an asset is less than its carrying value, we consider its fair value to be less
	than its carrying value and we calculate and record an impairment loss to recognize&nbsp;this.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Goodwill
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We test goodwill for impairment
	annually or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances lead us to believe it might be impaired. We first assess qualitative factors
	to determine whether events or changes in circumstances indicate that goodwill might be impaired, and if we conclude that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is
	greater than its carrying value, we use a two-step process to test for&nbsp;impairment:
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	1.
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	First,
	we compare the fair value of the reporting unit to its book value, including its goodwill. If fair value is less than book value, we consider our goodwill to be&nbsp;impaired.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2.
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Next,
	we measure the amount of the impairment by calculating the implied fair value of the reporting unit's goodwill. We do this by deducting the fair value of the tangible and
	intangible net assets of the reporting unit from the fair value we calculated in the first step. If the goodwill's carrying value exceeds its implied fair value, we record an impairment charge.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	base these valuations on our projections of future cash flows, which involves making estimates and assumptions about:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	discount
	rates
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	commodity
	and capacity prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	market
	supply and demand assumptions
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	growth
	opportunities
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	output
	levels
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	competition
	from other companies
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	regulatory
	changes.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	If
	our assumptions change significantly, our requirement to record an impairment charge could also change. There is a risk that adverse changes in key assumptions could result in a future impairment
	of a portion of the goodwill balance relating to Great Lakes. These assumptions could be negatively impacted by factors including changes in customer demand at Great Lakes for pipeline capacity and
	services, weather, North American natural gas production and prices as well as natural gas storage market conditions. Our share of the goodwill related to Great Lakes, net of non-controlling
	interests, was US$243&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;US$246&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;107
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=163,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=758115,FOLIO='107',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EI75607A.;39',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EQ75607_1_108">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Asset retirement obligations
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	When there is a legal obligation to set aside funds to cover future abandonment costs, and we can reasonably estimate them, we recognize the fair value
	of the asset retirement
	obligation (ARO) in our financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	cannot determine when we will retire many of our hydro-electric power plants, oil pipelines, natural gas pipelines and transportation facilities and regulated natural gas storage systems because we
	intend to operate them as long as there is supply and demand, and so we have not recorded obligations for&nbsp;them.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	those we do record, we use the following assumptions:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	when
	we expect to retire the asset
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	scope of abandonment and reclamation activities that are required
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	inflation
	and discount rates.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	ARO is initially recorded when the obligation exists and is subsequently accreted through charges to operating expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	continue to evaluate our future abandonment obligations and costs and monitor developments that could affect the amounts we&nbsp;record.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All financial instruments, including both derivative and non-derivative instruments, are recorded on the balance sheet at fair value unless they were entered
	into and continue
	to be held for the purpose of receipt or delivery in accordance with our normal purchase and normal sales exemptions and are documented as such. In addition, fair value accounting is not required for
	other financial instruments that qualify for certain accounting exemptions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Non-derivative financial instruments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Fair value of non-derivative financial instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The fair value of our notes
	receivable is calculated by discounting future payments of interest and principal using forward interest rates. The fair value of long-term debt has
	been estimated using an income approach based on quoted market prices for the same or similar debt instruments from external data providers. The fair value of available for sale assets has been
	calculated using quoted market prices where available. Credit risk has been taken into consideration when calculating the fair value of non-derivative financial instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Certain
	non-derivative financial instruments including cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, intangibles and other assets, notes payable, accounts payable and other, accrued interest and
	other long-term liabilities have carrying amounts that equal their fair value due to the nature of the item or the short time to&nbsp;maturity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Derivative instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We use derivative instruments to
	reduce volatility associated with fluctuations in commodity prices, interest rates and foreign exchange rates. We apply hedge accounting to
	derivative instruments that qualify and are designated for hedge accounting treatment. The effective portion of the change in the fair value of hedging derivatives for cash flow hedges and hedges of
	our net investment in foreign operations are recorded in other comprehensive income (OCI) in the period of change. Any ineffective portion is recognized in net income in the same financial category as
	the underlying transaction. The change in the fair value of derivative instruments that have been designated as fair value hedges are recorded in net income in interest income and other and interest
	expense.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	majority of derivative instruments that are not designated or do not qualify for hedge accounting treatment have been entered into as economic hedges to manage our exposure to market risk (held
	for trading). Changes in the fair value of held for trading derivative instruments are recorded in net income in the
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	108&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=164,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=714488,FOLIO='108',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EQ75607A.;14',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EQ75607_1_109">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	period
	of change. This may expose us to increased variability in reported operating results since the fair value of the held for trading derivative instruments can fluctuate significantly from period
	to&nbsp;period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	recognition of gains and losses on derivatives for Canadian natural gas regulated pipelines exposures is determined through the regulatory process. Gains and losses arising from changes in the
	fair value of derivatives accounted for as part of RRA, including
	those that qualify for hedge accounting treatment, can be recovered or refunded through the tolls charged by us. As a result, these gains and losses are deferred as regulatory assets or regulatory
	liabilities and are refunded to or collected from the ratepayers in subsequent years when the derivative settles.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Fair value of derivative instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The fair value of foreign
	exchange and interest rate derivatives has been calculated using the income approach which uses year-end market rates and applies a discounted cash
	flow valuation model. The fair value of power and natural gas derivatives has been calculated using quoted market prices where available. In the absence of quoted market prices, third-party broker
	quotes or other valuation techniques have been used. Credit risk has been taken into consideration when calculating the fair value of derivative instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Balance sheet presentation of derivative instruments
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The balance sheet classification of the fair value of derivative instruments is as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>
</P>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

	93
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

</FONT>
</TD>

</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="77%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</TD>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="77%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Other long-term liabilities
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	(411)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Anticipated timing of settlement&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;derivative
	instruments
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The anticipated timing of settlement for derivative instruments assumes constant commodity prices, interest rates and foreign exchange rates. Settlements will vary based on the
	actual value of these factors at the date of&nbsp;settlement.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Realized
	and unrealized gains and losses on held for trading derivative instruments used to purchase and sell power and natural gas are included net in energy revenues.
	Realized and unrealized gains and losses on interest rate and foreign exchange held for trading derivative instruments are included net in interest expense and interest income and other, respectively.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, all hedging relationships were designated as cash flow hedges except for interest rate derivative financial instruments designated as fair
	value hedges with a fair value of $3&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$5&nbsp;million) and a notional amount of US$400&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;US$200&nbsp;million). In 2014, net realized gains on fair value hedges were $7&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6&nbsp;million) and were included in interest expense. In 2014 and 2013, we did not record any amounts in net income related to ineffectiveness for
	fair value&nbsp;hedges.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	effective portion of the change in fair value of derivative instruments in hedging relationships is initially recognized in OCI and reclassified to energy revenues,
	interest expense and interest income and other, as appropriate, as the original hedged item settles. In 2014 and 2013, there were no gains or losses included in net income relating to discontinued
	cash flow hedges where it was probable that the anticipated transaction would not&nbsp;occur.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	No
	amounts have been excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness. Amounts in parentheses indicate losses recorded to&nbsp;OCI.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	110&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=166,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=964660,FOLIO='110',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]EQ75607A.;14',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_EQ75607_1_111">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Credit risk related contingent features of derivative
	instruments
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Derivatives often contain financial assurance provisions that may require us to provide collateral if a credit risk-related contingent event occurs (for&nbsp;example, if our
	credit rating is downgraded to non-investment grade). We may also need to provide collateral if the fair value of our derivative financial instruments exceeds pre-defined exposure limits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Based
	on contracts in place and market prices at December&nbsp;31, 2014, the aggregate fair value of all derivative contracts with credit-risk-related contingent features that were in a net
	liability position was $15&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$16&nbsp;million), with collateral provided in the normal course of business of
	nil&nbsp;(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;nil).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	If
	the credit-risk-related contingent features in these agreements were triggered on December&nbsp;31, 2014, we would have been required to provide additional collateral of $15&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$16&nbsp;million) to our counterparties. We have sufficient liquidity in the form of cash and undrawn committed revolving bank lines to meet these
	contingent obligations should they&nbsp;arise.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	ACCOUNTING CHANGES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Changes in accounting policies for 2014
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Obligations resulting from joint and several liability arrangements
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In February&nbsp;2013, the FASB
	issued guidance for recognizing, measuring, and disclosing obligations resulting from joint and several liability arrangements when the total
	amount of the obligation is fixed at the reporting date. Debt arrangements, other contractual obligations, and settled litigation and judicial rulings are examples of these obligations. This new
	guidance was effective January&nbsp;1, 2014 and there was no material impact on our consolidated financial statements as a result of applying this new&nbsp;standard.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Foreign currency matters&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;cumulative translation adjustment
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In March&nbsp;2013, the FASB issued amended guidance
	related to the release of the cumulative translation adjustment into net income when a parent either sells a part or all
	of its investment in a foreign entity or no longer holds a controlling financial interest in a subsidiary or group of assets that is a business. This new guidance was applied prospectively from
	January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Unrecognized tax benefit
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In July&nbsp;2013, the FASB
	issued amended guidance on the financial statement presentation of an unrecognized tax benefit when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar
	tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward exists. This new guidance was effective January&nbsp;1, 2014 and there was no material impact on our consolidated financial statements as a result of applying
	this new&nbsp;standard.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Future accounting changes
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Reporting discontinued operations
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In April&nbsp;2014, the FASB
	issued amended guidance on the reporting of discontinued operations. The criteria of what will qualify as a discontinued operation has changed
	and there are expanded disclosures required. This new guidance is effective from January&nbsp;1,
	2015 and will be applied prospectively. We do not expect the adoption of this new standard to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Revenue from contracts with customers
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In May&nbsp;2014, the FASB issued
	new guidance on Revenue from Contracts with Customers. This guidance supersedes the current revenue recognition requirements and most
	industry-specific guidance. This new guidance requires that an entity recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration
	to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. This new guidance is effective from January&nbsp;1, 2017 with two methods in which the amendment can be applied:
	(1)&nbsp;retrospectively to each prior reporting period presented, or (2)&nbsp;retrospectively with the cumulative effect recognized at the date of initial application. Early application is not
	permitted. We are currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of this ASU and have not yet determined the effect on our consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_123"></A>

</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;111
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	114&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=170,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=352404,FOLIO='114',FILE='DISK124:[14ZDF7.14ZDF75607]ES75607A.;44',USER='DSCHWAR',CD='12-FEB-2015;20:27' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_ES75607_1_115">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Factors affecting quarterly financial information by business
	segment
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Quarter-over-quarter revenues and net income fluctuate for reasons that vary across our business segments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	Natural Gas Pipelines, except for seasonal fluctuations in short-term throughput volumes on U.S.&nbsp;pipelines, quarter-over-quarter revenues and net income generally remain relatively stable
	during any fiscal year. Over the long term, however, they fluctuate because&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	regulators'
	decisions
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	negotiated
	settlements with shippers
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	acquisitions
	and divestitures
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	developments
	outside of the normal course of operations
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	newly
	constructed assets being placed in service.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	Liquids Pipelines, annual revenues and net income are based on contracted crude oil transportation and uncommitted spot transportation. Quarter-over-quarter revenues and net income are
	affected&nbsp;by:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	developments
	outside of the normal course of operations
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	newly
	constructed assets being placed in service
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	regulatory
	decisions.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	Energy, quarter-over-quarter revenues and net income are affected by:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	weather
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	customer
	demand
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	market
	prices for natural gas and power
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	capacity
	prices and payments
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	planned
	and unplanned plant outages
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	acquisitions
	and divestitures
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	certain
	fair value adjustments
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	developments
	outside of the normal course of operations
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	newly
	constructed assets being placed in service.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Factors affecting financial information by quarter
</B>
</FONT>
<BR>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We calculate comparable measures by adjusting certain GAAP and non-GAAP measures for specific items we believe are significant
	but not reflective of our underlying operations
	in the&nbsp;period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable
	earnings exclude the unrealized gains and losses from changes in the fair value of certain derivatives used to reduce our exposure to certain financial and commodity price risks. These
	derivatives provide effective economic hedges, but do not meet the criteria for hedge accounting. As a result, the changes in fair value are recorded in net income. As these amounts do not accurately
	reflect the gains and losses that will be realized at settlement, we do not consider them part of our underlying operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	fourth quarter 2014, comparable earnings excluded an $8&nbsp;million after-tax gain on the sale of Gas Pacifico/INNERGY.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	second quarter 2014, comparable earnings excluded a $99&nbsp;million after-tax gain on the sale of Cancarb Limited and a $32&nbsp;million after-tax loss related to the termination of the Niska
	Gas Storage contract.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	second quarter 2013, comparable earnings excluded a $25&nbsp;million favourable income tax adjustment due to the enactment of Canadian Federal tax legislation relating to Part&nbsp;VI.I tax in
	June&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	first quarter 2013, comparable earnings excluded $84&nbsp;million of net income in 2013 related to 2012 from the NEB 2013&nbsp;Decision.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_129"></A>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;115
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net income attributable to common shares increased by $38&nbsp;million for the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the same period in
	2013. Net income included a gain on the sale of Gas Pacifico/INNERGY of $8&nbsp;million after tax and unrealized gains and losses from changes in certain risk management activities. Excluding the
	impact of these items, comparable earnings in the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased over the same period in 2013 as discussed below in Comparable earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	items discussed above were excluded from comparable earnings for the relevant periods. Certain unrealized fair value adjustments relating to certain risk management activities are also excluded
	from comparable earnings. The remainder of net
	income is equivalent to comparable earnings. A reconciliation of net income attributable to common shares to comparable earnings is shown in the following table.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	116&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>

</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Comparable earnings
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comparable earnings in fourth quarter 2014
	increased by $101&nbsp;million or $0.14 per share compared to the same period in 2013. This was primarily the net
	effect&nbsp;of:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	incremental
	earnings from the Gulf Coast extension of the Keystone Pipeline&nbsp;System
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from Canadian Mainline due to higher incentive earnings recorded in fourth&nbsp;quarter
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from the Tamazunchale Extension which was placed in service in&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from Eastern Power due to higher contractual earnings at B&eacute;cancour and incremental earnings from solar facilities acquired in
	December&nbsp;2013 and the second half of&nbsp;2014
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	earnings from U.S.&nbsp;Power due to higher generation, higher sales to wholesale, commercial and industrial customers and the impact of higher realized power and
	capacity&nbsp;prices
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	higher
	interest expense from debt issuances and lower capitalized interest on projects placed in&nbsp;service.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	stronger U.S.&nbsp;dollar this quarter compared to the same period in 2013 positively impacted the translated results of our U.S.&nbsp;businesses, however, this impact was mostly offset by a
	corresponding increase in interest
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Management's discussion and analysis
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;117
</FONT>
</P>
