<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	results reflect a 50&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in Northern Border as a result of the Company fully consolidating TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, TransCanada had an ownership interest in TC PipeLines,&nbsp;LP of 28.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;28.9 and
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;33.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent) and its effective ownership of Northern Border, net of non-controlling interests, was 14.2&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;14.5 and 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;16.7&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent).
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, the difference between the carrying value of the investment and the underlying equity in the net assets of Northern Border Pipeline Company is
	US$117&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;US$118&nbsp;million) due to the fair value assessment of assets at the time of&nbsp;acquisition.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, the difference between the carrying value of the investment and the underlying equity in the net assets of Bruce Power is $776&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$820&nbsp;million) due to the fair value assessment of assets at the time of&nbsp;acquisition.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	In
	December&nbsp;2012, TransCanada acquired the remaining 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest in CrossAlta to bring the Company's ownership interest to
	100&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent. The results reflect the Company's 60&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent share of equity income up to that&nbsp;date.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Distributions received from equity investments for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were $726&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$725&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$436&nbsp;million) of which $147&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$120&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$60&nbsp;million) were returns of capital and are included in Deferred Amounts and
	Other in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. The undistributed earnings from equity investments as at December&nbsp;31, 2014 were $551&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$754&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$883&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	142&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	9.
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;RATE-REGULATED
	BUSINESSES
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's businesses that apply RRA currently include Canadian, U.S. and Mexican natural gas pipelines, regulated U.S.&nbsp;natural gas storage and certain Canadian
	liquids pipelines currently under development. Regulatory assets and liabilities represent future revenues that are expected to be recovered from or refunded to customers based on decisions and
	approvals by the applicable regulatory authorities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Canadian Regulated Operations
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Canadian Mainline, NGTL System, Foothills and TQM pipelines are regulated by
	the NEB under the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	National Energy Board
	Act
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(Canada). The NEB regulates the construction and operation of facilities, and the terms and conditions of services, including rates, for the Company's Canadian regulated
	natural gas transmission systems.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's
	Canadian natural gas transmission services are supplied under natural gas transportation tariffs that provide for cost recovery, including return of and return
	on capital as approved by the NEB. Rates charged for these services are typically set through a process that involves filing an application with the regulator wherein forecasted operating costs,
	including a return of and on capital, determine the revenue requirement for the upcoming year or multiple years. To the extent that actual costs and revenues are more or less than the forecasted costs
	and revenues, the regulators generally allow the difference to be deferred to a future period and recovered or refunded in rates at that time. Differences between actual and forecasted costs that the
	regulator does not allow to be deferred are included in the determination of net income in the year they&nbsp;occur.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Canadian Mainline
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On November&nbsp;28, 2014,
	the NEB released its decision on TransCanada's 2015-2030 Tolls Application (the&nbsp;NEB 2014&nbsp;Decision). The
	NEB 2014&nbsp;Decision acknowledged that an off-ramp had been reached on the NEB 2013&nbsp;Decision (discussed below) and approved fixed tolls for 2015 to 2020 as well as certain parameters for a
	toll setting methodology to 2030. Features of the settlement reached with shippers as approved in the NEB 2014&nbsp;Decision include an ROE of 10.1&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on a deemed common equity
	of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent, an incentive mechanism that has both upside and downside risk and a $20&nbsp;million after-tax annual TransCanada contribution to reduce the revenue requirement. Toll
	stabilization is achieved through the continued use of deferral accounts, namely the Long Term Adjustment Account (LTAA) and the Bridging Amortization Account, to capture the surplus or the shortfall
	between the Company's revenues and cost of service for each year over
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;143
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=199,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=297449,FOLIO='143',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FQ75608A.;27',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FQ75608_1_144">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
	six-year fixed toll term of the NEB 2014&nbsp;Decision. TransCanada is required to file&nbsp;a compliance filing with the NEB in first quarter 2015 and a toll review for the 2018 to 2020
	period prior to December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	March&nbsp;2013, TransCanada received a decision from the NEB which set tolls for 2013 through 2017 at competitive levels, fixing tolls for some services and providing
	unlimited pricing discretion for others (the&nbsp;NEB 2013&nbsp;Decision). The decision established an ROE of 11.5&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on a deemed common equity of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and
	included mechanisms to achieve the fixed tolls through the use of a LTAA as well as the establishment of a Tolls Stabilization Account (TSA) to capture the surplus or the shortfall between our
	revenues and our cost of service for each year over the five-year term of the decision. In addition, the decision provided an opportunity to generate incentive earnings by increasing revenues and
	reducing costs. The NEB also identified certain circumstances that would require a new tolls application prior to the end of the five-year term. One of those circumstances occurred
	in 2013 when the TSA balance became positive. In December&nbsp;2013, TransCanada filed the 2015-2030 Tolls Application with the NEB that addressed tolls moving forward including tolls
	for&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Canadian Mainline's 2012 results reflect an ROE of 8.08&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on a deemed common equity of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and excluded incentive earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	NGTL System
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In November&nbsp;2013, the
	NEB approved the NGTL System's 2013-2014 Revenue Requirement Settlement Application. This settlement is structured
	similar to the previous multi-year settlement with fixed annual operating, maintenance and administration (OM&amp;A) costs and a 10.1&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent ROE on a deemed common equity of
	40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent. Any variance between fixed OM&amp;A costs in the settlement and actual costs accrue to TransCanada. The Settlement also establishes an increase in the composite depreciation
	rates to 3.05&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent in 2013 and 3.12&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent in&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	NGTL System's 2012 results reflected a 9.70&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent ROE on a deemed common equity of 40&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and fixed certain annual OM&amp;A costs. Any
	variances between actual costs and those agreed to in the settlement then in effect accrued to TransCanada. All other costs were treated on a flow-through basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Energy East
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Energy East is currently
	in the development stage, awaiting regulatory approval from the NEB. Tolls will be designed to provide for cost recovery
	including return of and on capital as approved by the&nbsp;NEB.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Other Canadian Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Foothills operating
	model for 2012 through 2014 provides for recovery of all revenue requirement components on a flow-through basis. TQM operates
	under a model consisting of fixed and flow-through revenue requirement components for 2012 through 2016. Any variances between actual costs and those included in the fixed component accrue
	to&nbsp;TQM.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	U.S.&nbsp;Regulated Operations
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipelines are "natural gas companies" operating
	under the provisions of the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Natural Gas
	Act of 1938,
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(NGA) and the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Energy Policy Act of
	2005
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, and are subject to the jurisdiction of the FERC. The NGA grants the FERC authority over the construction and operation of pipelines and related facilities. The FERC also
	has authority to regulate rates for natural gas transportation in interstate commerce. The Company's significant regulated U.S.&nbsp;natural gas pipelines are described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	ANR
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANR's natural gas
	transportation and storage services are provided under tariffs regulated by the FERC. These tariffs include maximum and minimum
	rates for services and allow ANR to discount or negotiate rates on a non-discriminatory basis. ANR Pipeline Company rates were established pursuant to a settlement approved by the FERC that was
	effective for all periods presented, beginning in 1997. ANR Pipeline Company is not required to conduct a review of currently effective rates with the FERC at any time in the future, but is not
	prohibited from filing for new rates if&nbsp;necessary.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	144&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=200,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=949116,FOLIO='144',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FQ75608A.;27',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FQ75608_1_145">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANR
	Storage Company rates were established pursuant to a settlement approved by the FERC in August&nbsp;2012. ANR Storage Company is required to file&nbsp;a NGA
	Section&nbsp;4 general rate case no later than July&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TC
	Offshore&nbsp;LLC, another ANR-related regulated entity, began operating under FERC approved tariff rates on November&nbsp;1, 2012. TC Offshore&nbsp;LLC is required
	to file&nbsp;a cost and revenue study to justify its existing approved cost-based rates after its first three years of&nbsp;operation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Great Lakes
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Great Lakes is regulated
	by the FERC and operates in accordance with a FERC-approved tariff that establishes maximum and minimum rates for its
	various services and permits Great Lakes to discount or negotiate rates on a non-discriminatory basis. Great Lakes operated under a July&nbsp;2010 FERC approved rate settlement through
	October&nbsp;2013. Effective November&nbsp;1, 2013, Great Lakes operates under rates established pursuant to a settlement approved by the FERC in November&nbsp;2013. The settlement provides for
	a moratorium between November&nbsp;2013 and March&nbsp;2015 during which Great Lakes and the settling parties are prohibited from taking certain actions under the NGA, including filing to adjust
	rates. Great Lakes is required to file for new rates to be effective no later than January&nbsp;2018.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Other U.S.&nbsp;Pipelines
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	GTN and Bison are regulated
	by the FERC and operate in accordance with FERC-approved tariffs that establish maximum and minimum rates for various
	services. Both pipelines are permitted to discount or negotiate these rates on a non-discriminatory basis. GTN's rates were established pursuant to a settlement approved by the FERC in
	January&nbsp;2012. GTN is required to file for new rates to be effective no later than January&nbsp;2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Bison's
	rates were established pursuant to its initial certificate to construct and operate the pipeline that initiated service in January&nbsp;2011. Bison filed a cost
	and revenue study as required by FERC to justify its existing approved cost-based rates after its first three years of operations. This study was filed by Bison on April&nbsp;10, 2014 and accepted
	by FERC on May&nbsp;20, 2014. At this time Bison is not required to conduct a review of currently effective rates with the FERC at any time in the future but is not prohibited from filing for new
	rates if&nbsp;necessary.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_149"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Mexico Regulated Operations
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's Mexican operations are regulated by the CRE and operate in accordance with CRE-approved tariffs. In 2014, TransCanada began using RRA
	for all natural gas pipelines in Mexico. The rates were established based on CRE approved negotiated contracts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;145
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	These
	regulatory assets are underpinned by non-cash transactions or are recovered without an allowance for return as approved by the regulator. Accordingly, these
	regulatory assets are not included in rate base and do not yield a return on investment during the recovery period.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Operating
	and debt-service regulatory assets and liabilities represent the accumulation of cost and revenue variances approved by the regulatory authority for inclusion in
	determining tolls for the following calendar year. Pre-tax operating results in 2014 would have been $28&nbsp;million higher (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$76&nbsp;million higher;
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$50&nbsp;million lower) had these amounts not been recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	These
	balances represent the regulatory offset to pension plan and other post retirement obligations to the extent the amounts are expected to be collected from customers
	in future rates. The balances are excluded from the rate base and do not earn a return on investment. Pre-tax operating
	results in 2014 would have been $46&nbsp;million lower (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$171&nbsp;million higher; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$61&nbsp;million
	lower) had these amounts not been recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	LTAA was established in compliance with the NEB 2013&nbsp;Decision which is comprised of amounts that were deferred and recoverable in future years. The TSA, also
	established in the NEB 2013&nbsp;Decision, includes the variances between revenue and costs. A positive balance in the TSA was realized in 2013 and 2014 and, as specified in the NEB
	2013&nbsp;Decision and the NEB 2014&nbsp;Decision, the TSA, net of incentive earnings, was combined with the LTAA on December&nbsp;31, 2013 and&nbsp;2014.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	5
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Pre-tax
	operating results in 2014 would have been $2&nbsp;million higher (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$2&nbsp;million higher;
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$66&nbsp;million higher) had these amounts not been recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	6
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Foreign
	exchange on long-term debt of the NGTL System and Foothills represents the variance resulting from revaluing foreign currency-denominated debt instruments to the
	current foreign exchange rate from the historical foreign exchange rate at the time of issue. Foreign exchange gains and losses realized when foreign debt matures or is redeemed early are expected to
	be recovered or refunded through the determination of future tolls. In the absence of RRA, GAAP would have required the inclusion of these unrealized gains or losses in Net&nbsp;Income.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	146&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=202,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1011674,FOLIO='146',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FQ75608A.;27',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FQ75608_1_147">
</A>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	7
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Under
	the terms of the settlement of ANR's last rate settlement, ANR will be required to make refunds to its customers, pursuant to a refund plan to be approved by FERC in
	a future rate proceeding, of those amounts in the postretirement benefit trust fund that have not been used to pay benefits to its employees. This regulatory liability represents the difference
	between the amount collected in rates and the amount of postretirement benefits expense. ANR can but is not required to file for new rates. Therefore, the settlement/recovery period is not
	determinable. Pre-tax operating results in 2014 would have been $13&nbsp;million higher (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$16&nbsp;million higher;
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$8&nbsp;million higher) had these amounts not been recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Allowance for Funds Used During Construction
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The total amount of AFUDC included in the Consolidated Statement of Income was $95&nbsp;million in
	2014, $19&nbsp;million in 2013 and
	$15&nbsp;million in&nbsp;2012.
</FONT>
</P>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	TransCanada
	held a note receivable from the seller of Ravenswood of $213&nbsp;million (US$184&nbsp;million) and $226&nbsp;million (US$212&nbsp;million) as at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and at December&nbsp;31, 2013, respectively which bears interest at 6.75&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and matures in 2040. The current portion included in Other Current Assets was
	$46&nbsp;million (US$40&nbsp;million) at December&nbsp;31, 2014, and $43&nbsp;million (US$40&nbsp;million) at December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

	Amortization expense for these PPAs was $52&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 (2013 and

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Notes Payable consists of commercial paper issued by TransCanada PipeLines Limited (TCPL), TransCanada PipeLine USA&nbsp;Ltd. (TCPL
	USA), TransCanada American Investments&nbsp;Ltd. (TAIL), and TransCanada Keystone Pipeline,&nbsp;LP (TC&nbsp;Keystone) and drawings on credit facilities. The TC Keystone commercial paper program
	and facility were terminated in November&nbsp;2013. The TAIL commercial paper program was initiated in November&nbsp;2013, replacing the TCPL USA program which was terminated in April&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Notes
	Payable also includes a US$170&nbsp;million short-term loan, which was issued on October&nbsp;1, 2014, by TC&nbsp;Pipelines&nbsp;LP.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, total committed revolving and demand credit facilities of $6.7&nbsp;billion (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6.2&nbsp;billion)
	were available. When drawn, interest on these lines of credit is charged at prime rates of
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	148&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Interest
	rates are the effective interest rates except for those pertaining to Long-Term Debt issued for the Company's Canadian regulated natural gas operations, in which
	case the weighted average interest rate is presented as approved by the regulators. Weighted average and effective interest rates are stated as at the respective outstanding dates.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Debentures
	issued by NGTL in the amount of $225&nbsp;million have retraction provisions that entitle the holders to require redemption of up to
	eight&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the then outstanding principal plus accrued and unpaid interest on specified repayment dates. No redemptions were made in 2014 or&nbsp;2013.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Secured
	by shipper transportation contracts, existing and new guarantees, letters of credit and collateral requirements.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	150&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Amortization
	and other financial charges includes amortization of transaction costs and debt discounts calculated using the effective interest method and changes in the
	fair value of derivatives used to manage the Company's exposure to changes in interest&nbsp;rates.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company made interest payments of $1,123&nbsp;million in 2014
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$985&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$966&nbsp;million) on Long-Term Debt and Junior Subordinated Notes, net of interest
	capitalized.
</FONT>
</P>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	A
	valuation allowance was recorded in 2014 as the Company believes that it is more likely than not that the tax benefit related to the unrealized foreign exchange losses
	on the long term debt will not be realized in the&nbsp;future.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company has recognized the benefit of unused non-capital loss carryforwards of $1,131&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$1,026&nbsp;million) for federal and provincial purposes in Canada, which expire from 2015 to&nbsp;2034.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company has recognized the benefit of unused net operating loss carryforwards of US$2,267&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;US$1,432&nbsp;million) for federal purposes in the U.S., which expire from 2028 to&nbsp;2034.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Unremitted Earnings of Foreign Investments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Income taxes have not been provided on the unremitted earnings of foreign
	investments that the Company does not intend to repatriate in the
	foreseeable future. Deferred income tax liabilities would have increased at December&nbsp;31, 2014 by approximately $236&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$182&nbsp;million) if there had been a provision for these&nbsp;taxes.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_163"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Income Tax Payments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Income tax payments of $109&nbsp;million, net of refunds, were made in 2014
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;payments, net of refunds,
	of $202&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;refunds, net of payments made, of $190&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada recognized a favourable income tax adjustment of approximately $25&nbsp;million due to the enactment of certain
	Canadian Federal tax legislation in June&nbsp;2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Subject
	to the results of audit examinations by taxing authorities and other legislative amendments, TransCanada does not anticipate further adjustments to the unrecognized
	tax benefits during the next twelve months that would have a material impact on its financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	and its subsidiaries are subject to either Canadian federal and provincial income tax, U.S.&nbsp;federal, state and local income tax or the relevant income tax
	in other international jurisdictions. The Company has substantially concluded all Canadian federal and provincial income tax matters for the years through 2009. Substantially all material
	U.S.&nbsp;federal income tax matters have been concluded for years through 2007 and U.S.&nbsp;state and local income tax matters through&nbsp;2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	154&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>

</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's practice is to recognize interest and penalties related to income tax uncertainties in Income Tax Expense. Income Tax Expense for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 reflects a $1&nbsp;million reversal of Interest Expense and nil for penalties (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$1&nbsp;million increase of Interest Expense
	and nil for penalties; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$2&nbsp;million reversal for Interest Expense and nil for penalties). At December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company had
	$5&nbsp;million accrued for Interest Expense and nil accrued for penalties (December&nbsp;31, 2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6&nbsp;million accrued for Interest Expense and nil
	accrued for&nbsp;penalties).
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Junior Subordinated Notes of US$1.0&nbsp;billion mature in 2067 and bear interest at 6.35&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent per annum until
	May&nbsp;15, 2017, when interest will convert to a floating rate that is reset quarterly to the three-month London Interbank Offered Rate plus 221&nbsp;basis points. The Company has the option to
	defer payment of interest for periods of up to 10&nbsp;years without giving rise to a default or permitting acceleration of payment under the terms of the Junior Subordinated Notes, however, the
	Company would be prohibited from paying dividends during any such deferral period. The Junior Subordinated Notes are subordinated in right of payment to existing and future senior indebtedness and are
	effectively subordinated to all indebtedness and other obligations of TCPL. The Junior Subordinated Notes are callable at the Company's option at any time on or after May&nbsp;15, 2017 at
	100&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the principal amount of the Junior Subordinated Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption. The Junior Subordinated Notes are callable earlier, in
	whole or in part, upon the occurrence of certain events and at the Company's option at an amount equal to the greater of 100&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent of the principal amount of the Junior Subordinated
	Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption and an amount determined by a specified formula in accordance with the terms of the Junior Subordinated Notes.
</FONT>
</P>

<TD WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	5
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

</FONT>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	During&nbsp;2014, the non-controlling interest in TC PipeLines,&nbsp;LP increased from 71.1&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent to
	71.7&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent due to the issuance of common units in TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP to non-controlling interests. The non-controlling interest in TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP from
	May&nbsp;2013 to August&nbsp;2014 was 71.1&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and from May&nbsp;2011 to May&nbsp;2013 was 66.7&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	non-controlling interest in Portland as at December&nbsp;31, 2014 represented the 38.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent interest not owned by TransCanada (2013 and
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;38.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	October&nbsp;15, 2013, TCPL redeemed all of the four million outstanding 5.60&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent cumulative redeemable first preferred shares Series&nbsp;U at a
	price of $50 per share plus $0.5907 representing accrued and unpaid dividends to the redemption&nbsp;date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	On
	March&nbsp;5, 2014, TCPL redeemed all of the four million outstanding 5.60&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent cumulative redeemable first preferred shares Series&nbsp;Y at a
	price of $50 per share plus $0.2455 representing accrued and unpaid dividends to the redemption&nbsp;date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	2014, TransCanada received fees of $3&nbsp;million from TC&nbsp;PipeLines,&nbsp;LP (2013 and 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$3&nbsp;million) and
	$8&nbsp;million from Portland (2013 and 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$7&nbsp;million) for services provided.
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_168"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Basic and Diluted Net Income per Share
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net income per share is calculated by dividing Net Income Attributable to Common
	Shares by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.
	The higher weighted average number of shares for the diluted earnings per share calculation is due to options exercisable under TransCanada's Stock Option&nbsp;Plan.
</FONT>
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="69%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	An additional 8.2&nbsp;million common shares were reserved for future issuance under TransCanada's Stock Option Plan at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The weighted average fair value of options granted to purchase common shares under the Company's Stock Option Plan was determined to be $5.54 for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$5.74; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$5.08). The contractual life of options granted is seven years. Options may
	be exercised at a price determined at the time the option is awarded and vest 33.3&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent on the anniversary date in each
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;157
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	of
	the three years following the award. Forfeiture of stock options results from their expiration and, if not previously vested, upon resignation or termination of the option holder's employment.
</FONT>

	The amount expensed for stock options, with a corresponding increase in Additional Paid-In Capital, was $9&nbsp;million in 2014
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$6&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$5&nbsp;million).

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2014, the aggregate intrinsic value of the total options exercisable was $85&nbsp;million and the total
	intrinsic value of options outstanding was $118&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Shareholder Rights Plan
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's Shareholder Rights Plan is designed to provide the Board with
	sufficient time to explore and develop alternatives for maximizing
	shareholder value in the event of a takeover offer for the Company and to encourage the fair treatment of shareholders in connection with any such offer. Attached to each common share is one right
	that, under certain circumstances, entitles certain holders to purchase two common shares of the Company for the then current market price of&nbsp;one.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	158&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	holder is entitled to receive a fixed, cumulative, quarterly preferential dividend, as declared by the Board with the exception of Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares.
	The holders of Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares are entitled to receive quarterly, floating rate, cumulative, preferential dividends as declared by the&nbsp;Board.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Series&nbsp;2
	preferred shares are redeemable by TransCanada at any time for $25.50 per share plus all accrued and unpaid dividends on such redemption date, unless
	redeemed on a designated redemption option date, or any fifth anniversary thereafter, in which case they are redeemable at $25.00 per share plus all accrued and unpaid dividends. For all other series
	of preferred shares, TransCanada may, at its option, redeem all or a portion of the outstanding shares for the redemption price per share, plus all accrued and unpaid dividends on the redemption
	option date and on every fifth anniversary thereafter.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	holder will have the right, subject to certain conditions, to convert their first preferred shares of a specified series into first preferred shares of another
	specified series on the conversion option date and every fifth anniversary thereafter.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	4
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	With
	the exception of Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares, if converted each series will be entitled to receive floating rate, cumulative, quarterly, preferential dividends
	per share at an annualized rate equal to the 90-day Government of Canada Treasury bill rate&nbsp;+&nbsp;1.92&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;2), 1.28&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent
	(Series&nbsp;4), 1.54&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;6), 2.38&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;8), and&nbsp;2.35&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;10). Holders of Series&nbsp;1
	preferred shares will receive fixed, cumulative, quarterly preferential dividends if converted.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	5
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	With
	the exception of Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares, and where the redemption and/or conversion option is not exercised on a designated conversion date, the dividend
	rate on the fixed rate, cumulative, quarterly, preferential dividends will reset on the redemption and conversion option date and every fifth year thereafter to an annualized rate equal to the then
	five-year Government of Canada bond yield&nbsp;+&nbsp;1.92&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;1), 1.28&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent
	(Series&nbsp;3), 1.54&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;5), 2.38&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;7), and&nbsp;2.35&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent (Series&nbsp;9). Holders of Series&nbsp;2
	preferred shares will receive floating rate, cumulative, quarterly, preferential dividends.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	6
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Net
	of underwriting commissions and deferred income taxes.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	7
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Commencing
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, the floating quarterly dividend rate for the Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares is 2.82&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent and will reset each
	quarter going forward.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In January&nbsp;2014, TransCanada completed a public offering of 18&nbsp;million Series&nbsp;9 cumulative redeemable first
	preferred shares at a price of $25.00 per share, resulting in gross proceeds of $450&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, holders of 12,501,577&nbsp;Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares exercised their option to convert to Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares and receive
	floating rate, cumulative, quarterly, preferential dividends at a rate equal to the then 90-day Government of Canada Treasury bill rate&nbsp;+&nbsp;1.92&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent until
	December&nbsp;31, 2019. The floating quarterly dividend rate for the Series&nbsp;2 preferred shares for the first quarterly floating rate period (being the period from December&nbsp;31, 2014 to
	but excluding March&nbsp;31, 2015) is 2.82&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent per annum and will reset every quarter. The 9,498,423&nbsp;Series&nbsp;1 preferred shares will pay on a quarterly basis, for the
	five-year period beginning on December&nbsp;31, 2014 a fixed quarterly dividend based on an annual fixed dividend rate of 3.27&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;159
</FONT>
</P>

<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	All
	amounts are net of tax. Amounts in parentheses indicate losses recorded to&nbsp;OCI.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	OCI
	before reclassifications on currency translation adjustments is net of non-controlling interest gains of $130&nbsp;million in 2014
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$66&nbsp;million gains; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$21&nbsp;million losses).
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	3
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Losses
	related to cash flow hedges reported in AOCI and expected to be reclassified to net income in the next 12&nbsp;months are estimated to be $95&nbsp;million
	($55&nbsp;million, net of tax) at December&nbsp;31, 2014. These estimates assume constant commodity prices, interest rates and foreign exchange rates over time, however, the amounts reclassified
	will vary based on the actual value of these factors at the date of&nbsp;settlement.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	All
	amounts in parentheses indicate expenses to the Consolidated Statement of&nbsp;Income.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	These
	Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss components are included in the computation of net benefit cost. Refer to Note&nbsp;22 for additional detail.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	22.
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;EMPLOYEE POST-RETIREMENT
	BENEFITS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company sponsors DB Plans for its employees. Pension benefits provided under the DB Plans are based on years of service and highest average earnings over three consecutive
	years of employment. Upon commencement of retirement, pension benefits in the Canadian DB Plan increase annually by a portion of the increase in the Consumer Price Index. Past service costs are
	amortized over the expected average remaining service life of employees, which is approximately nine years (2013 and 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;nine years).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company also provides its employees with a savings plan in Canada, DC Plans consisting of 401(k) Plans in the U.S., and post-employment benefits other than pensions,
	including termination benefits and life insurance and medical benefits beyond those provided by government-sponsored plans. Past service costs are amortized over the expected average remaining life
	expectancy of former employees, which was approximately 12&nbsp;years at December&nbsp;31, 2014 (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;11&nbsp;years;
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;12&nbsp;years). In 2014, the Company expensed $37&nbsp;million (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$29&nbsp;million;
	2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$24&nbsp;million) for the savings plan and DC&nbsp;Plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	162&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

	cash payments for employee post-retirement benefits, consisting of cash contributed by the Company were as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Current Canadian pension legislation allows for partial funding of solvency requirements over a number of years through letters of
	credit in lieu of cash contributions, up to certain limits. As such, in addition to the cash contributions noted above, in 2014 the Company provided a $47&nbsp;million letter of credit to the
	Canadian DB&nbsp;Plan (2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$59&nbsp;million; 2012&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$48&nbsp;million), resulting in a total of $181&nbsp;million
	provided to the Canadian DB&nbsp;Plan under letters of credit at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	most recent actuarial valuation of the pension plans for funding purposes was as at January&nbsp;1, 2014 and the next required valuation will be as at
	January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="70%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=9 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	benefit obligation for the Company's pension benefit plans represents the projected benefit obligation. The benefit obligation for the Company's other post-retirement
	benefit plans represents the accumulated post-retirement benefit obligation.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	2
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	Excludes
	$181&nbsp;million in letters of credit provided to the Canadian DB Plans for funding purposes
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$134&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>

	TransCanada

	Consolidated financial statements

	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;163

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Included in the above benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were the following amounts for plans that are not
	fully&nbsp;funded:
</FONT>

<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-9PT;'>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TOP:-2PT;ADD_SUP:2PT;">
	1
</FONT>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:9PT;">
	The
	projected benefit obligation for the pension benefit plan differs from the accumulated benefit obligation in that it includes an assumption with respect to future
	compensation levels.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The accumulated benefit obligation for all DB pension plans at December&nbsp;31, 2014 is $2,437&nbsp;million
	(2013&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$2,039&nbsp;million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	funded status based on the accumulated benefit obligation for all DB Plans is as&nbsp;follows:
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Pension plan assets are managed on a going concern basis, subject to legislative restrictions, and are diversified across asset
	classes to maximize returns at an acceptable level of risk. Asset mix strategies consider plan demographics and may include traditional equity and debt securities, as well as alternative assets such
	as infrastructure, private equity, real estate and derivatives to diversify risk. Derivatives are not used for speculative purposes and the use of leveraged derivatives is&nbsp;prohibited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All
	investments are measured at fair value using market prices. Where the fair value cannot be readily determined by reference to generally available price quotations, the
	fair value is determined by considering the discounted cash flows on a risk-adjusted basis and by comparison to similar assets which are publicly traded. In Level&nbsp;I, the fair value of assets is
	determined by reference to quoted prices in active markets for identical assets that the Company has the ability to access at the measurement date. In Level&nbsp;II, the fair value of assets is
	determined using valuation techniques, such as option pricing models and extrapolation using significant inputs, which are observable directly or indirectly. In Level&nbsp;III, the fair value of
	assets is determined using a market approach based on inputs that are unobservable and significant to the overall fair value measurement. For further information on the fair value hierarchy, refer to
	Note&nbsp;23.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;165
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FU75608_1_166">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	following table presents plan assets for DB Plans and other post-retirement benefits measured at fair value, which have been categorized into the three categories based
	on a fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company's expected funding contributions in 2015 are approximately $70&nbsp;million for the DB Plans, approximately
	$7&nbsp;million for the other post-retirement benefit plans and approximately $36&nbsp;million for the savings plan and DC Plans. The Company expects to provide an additional estimated
	$35&nbsp;million letter of credit to the Canadian DB&nbsp;Plan for the funding of solvency requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	166&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014
</FONT>

</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	728
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	51
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<HR NOSHADE>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</TABLE>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The rate used to discount pension and other post-retirement benefit plan obligations was developed based on a yield curve of
	corporate AA bond yields at December&nbsp;31, 2014. This yield curve is used to develop spot rates that vary based on the duration of the obligations. The estimated future cash flows for the pension
	and other post-retirement obligations were matched to the corresponding rates on the spot rate curve to derive a weighted average discount&nbsp;rate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

	significant weighted average actuarial assumptions adopted in measuring the Company's benefit obligations were as&nbsp;follows:

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The overall expected long-term rate of return on plan assets is based on historical and projected rates of return for the portfolio
	in aggregate and for each asset class in the portfolio. Assumed projected rates of return are selected after analyzing historical experience and estimating future levels and volatility of returns.
	Asset class benchmark returns, asset mix and anticipated benefit payments from plan assets are also considered in determining the overall expected rate of return. The discount rate is based on market
	interest rates of high-quality bonds that match the timing and benefits expected to be paid under each&nbsp;plan.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_190"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A
	7.5&nbsp;per&nbsp;cent average annual rate of increase in the per capita cost of covered health care benefits was assumed for 2015 measurement purposes. The rate was
	assumed to decrease gradually to five per&nbsp;cent by
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;167
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=223,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=743533,FOLIO='167',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FU75608A.;20',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FU75608_1_168">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2020
	and remain at this level thereafter. A one per&nbsp;cent change in assumed health care cost trend rates would have the following effects:
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="69%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="69%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(millions of Canadian dollars)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Increase
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="13%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Decrease
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=5 STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#0C2E82">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="69%" VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Effect on total of service and interest cost components
</FONT>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The estimated net loss and prior service cost for the DB Plans that will be amortized from AOCI into net periodic benefit cost in
	2015 are $27&nbsp;million and $2&nbsp;million, respectively. The estimated net loss and prior service cost for the other post-retirement plans that will be amortized from AOCI into net periodic
	benefit cost in 2015 is $2&nbsp;million and nil, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>

<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

</FONT>
</TD>

<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=224,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=549989,FOLIO='168',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FU75608A.;20',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FW75608_1_169">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	23.
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;RISK MANAGEMENT AND FINANCIAL
	INSTRUMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Risk Management Overview
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada has exposure to market risk and counterparty credit risk, and has strategies, policies and limits in place to manage the impact of these
	risks on earnings, cash flow and, ultimately, shareholder value.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Risk
	management strategies, policies and limits are designed to ensure TransCanada's risks and related exposures are in line with the Company's business objectives and risk
	tolerance. Market risk and counterparty credit risk are managed within limits ultimately established by the Company's Board of Directors, implemented by senior management and monitored by the
	Company's risk management and internal audit groups. The Board of Directors' Audit Committee oversees how management monitors compliance with market risk and counterparty credit risk management
	policies and procedures, and oversees management's review of the adequacy of the risk management framework. Internal audit personnel assist the Audit Committee in its oversight role by performing
	regular and ad-hoc reviews of risk management controls and procedures, the results of which are reported to the Audit Committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Market Risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company constructs and invests in energy infrastructure projects, purchases and
	sells energy commodities, issues short-term and long-term debt,
	including amounts in foreign currencies, and invests in foreign operations. Certain of these activities expose the Company to market risk from changes in commodity prices, foreign exchange rates and
	interest rates, which may affect the Company's earnings and the value of the financial instruments it&nbsp;holds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company uses derivatives as part of its overall risk management strategy to assist in managing the exposure to market risk that results from these activities. These
	derivative contracts may consist of the&nbsp;following:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Forwards
	and futures contracts&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;contractual agreements to purchase or sell a specific financial instrument or commodity at a specified
	price and date in the future. TransCanada enters into foreign exchange and commodity forwards and futures to manage the impact of volatility in foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Swaps&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;contractual
	agreements between two parties to exchange streams of payments over time according to specified terms. The Company
	enters into interest rate, cross-currency and commodity swaps to manage the impact of changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Options&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;contractual
	agreements that convey the right, but not the obligation of the purchaser to buy or sell a specific amount of a
	financial instrument or commodity at a fixed price, either at a fixed date or at any time within a specified period. The Company enters into option agreements to manage the impact of changes in
	interest rates, foreign exchange rates and commodity prices.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Commodity Price Risk
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company is exposed to
	commodity price movements as part of its normal business operations, particularly in relation to the prices of electricity
	and natural gas. A number of strategies are used to manage these exposures, including the&nbsp;following:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Subject
	to its overall risk management strategy, the Company commits a portion of its expected power supply to fixed-price medium-term or long-term sales contracts, while
	reserving an amount of unsold supply to manage operational and price risks in its asset portfolio.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company purchases a portion of the natural gas required for its power plants or enters into contracts that base the sale price of electricity on the cost of natural gas,
	effectively locking in a&nbsp;margin.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company's power sales commitments are fulfilled through power generation or through purchased contracts, thereby reducing the Company's exposure to fluctuating commodity
	prices.
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company enters into offsetting or back-to-back positions using derivative instruments to manage price risk exposure in power and natural gas commodities created by
	certain fixed and variable pricing arrangements for different pricing indices and delivery points.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;169
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=225,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=863525,FOLIO='169',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FW75608A.;18',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FW75608_1_170">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Natural Gas Storage Commodity Price Risk
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada manages its
	exposure to seasonal natural gas price spreads in its non-regulated Natural Gas Storage business by economically hedging
	storage capacity with a portfolio of third-party storage capacity contracts and proprietary natural gas purchases and sales. TransCanada simultaneously enters into a forward purchase of natural gas
	for injection into storage and an offsetting forward sale of natural gas for withdrawal at a later period, thereby locking in future positive margins
	and effectively eliminating exposure to natural gas price movements. Unrealized gains and losses on fair value adjustments recorded each period on these forward contracts are not necessarily
	representative of the amounts that will be realized on&nbsp;settlement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Exchange and Interest Rate Risk
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Foreign exchange and
	interest rate risk is created by fluctuations in the fair value or cash flow of financial instruments due to changes in foreign
	exchange rates and interest&nbsp;rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	A
	portion of TransCanada's earnings from its Natural Gas Pipelines, Liquids Pipelines and Energy segments is generated in U.S.&nbsp;dollars and, therefore, fluctuations in
	the value of the Canadian dollar relative to the U.S.&nbsp;dollar can affect TransCanada's net income. As the Company's U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated operations continue to grow, exposure to
	changes in currency rates increases; some of this foreign exchange impact is partially offset by interest expense on U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated debt and by using foreign exchange derivatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company uses foreign currency and interest rate derivatives to manage the foreign exchange and interest rate risks related to other U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated
	transactions including those that may arise on some of the Company's regulated assets, in which case certain of the realized gains and losses on these derivatives would be deferred as regulatory
	assets and liabilities until they are recovered from or paid to the shippers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	has floating interest rate debt which subjects it to interest rate cash flow risk. The Company uses a combination of interest rate swaps and options to manage
	its exposure to this&nbsp;risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Net Investment in Foreign Operations
<BR>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The Company hedges its net
	investment in foreign operations (on&nbsp;an after-tax basis) with U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated debt, cross-currency
	interest rate swaps, foreign exchange forward contracts and foreign exchange options.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_193"></A>

</FONT>

</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="39%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">

	at December&nbsp;31

	(millions of Canadian dollars, unless noted otherwise)

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Counterparty Credit Risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Counterparty credit risk represents the financial loss the Company would experience if a
	counterparty to a financial instrument failed to meet its
	obligations in accordance with the terms and conditions of the related contract or agreement with the&nbsp;Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company manages its exposure to this potential loss by using recognized credit management techniques, including:
<BR>
</FONT>
</P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Dealing
	with creditworthy counterparties&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;a significant amount of the Company's credit exposure is with investment grade
	counterparties or, if not, is generally partially supported by financial assurances from investment grade&nbsp;parties
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Setting
	limits on the amount TransCanada can transact with any one counterparty&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;the Company monitors and manages the concentration of
	risk exposure with any one counterparty, and reduces the exposure when needed and when it is allowed under the terms of the&nbsp;contracts
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Using
	contract netting arrangements and obtaining financial assurances such as guarantees, letters of credit or cash when deemed necessary.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	There
	is no guarantee that these techniques will protect the Company from material losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada's
	maximum counterparty credit exposure with respect to financial instruments at December&nbsp;31, 2014, without taking into account security held, consisted of
	accounts receivable, portfolio investments recorded at fair value, the fair value of derivative assets and notes, loans and advances receivable. The Company regularly reviews its accounts receivable
	and records an allowance for doubtful accounts as necessary using the specific identification method. At December&nbsp;31, 2014, there were no significant amounts past due or impaired, and there
	were no significant credit losses during the year. The Company had a credit risk concentration due from a counterparty of $258&nbsp;million (US$222&nbsp;million) and $240&nbsp;million
	(US$225&nbsp;million) at December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively. This amount is expected to be fully collectible and is secured by a guarantee from the counterparty's investment grade
	parent&nbsp;company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
	has significant credit and performance exposures to financial institutions as they hold cash deposits and provide committed credit lines and letters of credit
	that help manage our exposure to counterparties and provide liquidity in commodity, foreign exchange and interest rate derivative markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Financial Instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	All financial instruments, including both derivative and non-derivative instruments,
	are recorded on the balance sheet at fair value unless they were
	entered into and continue to be held for the purpose of receipt or delivery in accordance with the Company's normal purchase and normal sales exemptions and are documented as such. In addition, fair
	value accounting is not required for other financial instruments that qualify for certain accounting exemptions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Fair Value of Non-Derivative Financial Instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The fair value of the Company's notes receivable is calculated by discounting
	future payments of interest and principal using forward interest rates.
	The fair value of Long-Term Debt is estimated using an income approach based on quoted market prices for the same or similar debt instruments from external data service providers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	TransCanada
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Consolidated financial statements
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2014&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;171
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=227,EFW="2222941",CP="TRANSCANADA CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=211706,FOLIO='171',FILE='DISK125:[14ZDF8.14ZDF75608]FW75608A.;18',USER='SSTALKE',CD='12-FEB-2015;19:44' -->
<A NAME="A2222941Z40-F_HTM_PAGE_FW75608_1_172">
</A>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	fair value of available for sale assets has been calculated using quoted market prices where available. Credit risk has been taken into consideration when calculating the fair value of
	non-derivative instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Certain
	non-derivative financial instruments included in Cash and Cash Equivalents, Accounts Receivable, Intangible and Other Assets, Notes Payable, Accounts Payable and
	Other, Accrued Interest and Other Long-Term Liabilities have carrying amounts that approximates their fair value due to the nature of the item or the short time to maturity and would be classified in
	Level&nbsp;II of the fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT COLOR="#0C2E82" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Balance Sheet Presentation of Non-Derivative Financial Instruments
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The following table details the fair value of the non-derivative financial
	instruments, excluding those where carrying amounts equal fair value, and
	would be classified in Level&nbsp;II of the fair value hierarchy:
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="78%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">

<FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TXTHEX,"PMS287" -->
</FONT>
